analyzed: sace pana
translated: If he makes it flap its wings, though not taking it from its place,

analyzed: evam phandāpane tassa thullaccayam udīritam
translated: In making it flap its wings, it is said that there is a serious offense.

original: Aggahetvā gahetvā vā, hatthena pana attano;🔽Ṭhānā cāveti ce moraṃ, sayaṃ ṭhānā cuto siyā.
analyzed: aggahetvā gahetvā vā hatthena pana attano  ṭhānā ca aveti ce moram sayam ṭhānā siyā
translated: Without catching it or after catching it with his own hand,🔽If he makes the peacock move from its place, it may move from its place by itself.

analyzed: phuṭṭha ukāsam mukha aggena kalāpa ggena vā pana
translated: If he touches the space occupied by the head or the space occupied by the beak or the space occupied by the feathers,

original: Kalāpaggena vā phuṭṭhaṃ, mukhatuṇḍena bhikkhu ce.
analyzed: kalā paggena vā phuṭṭham mukha tuṇḍena bhikkhu ce
translated: If the monk touches it with his beak or his mouth or his feathers,

original: Atikkāmeyya yo moraṃ, ṭhānā cāveti nāma so;
analyzed: yaḥ moram nāma so
translated: If he makes the peacock go beyond the space occupied by it, it is said that he makes it move from its place.

analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ pāda sikhā pakkhesu dīpitaḥ
translated: This is the method shown for the foot, the crest, and the wings.

original: Gagane pana gacchanto, kare moro nilīyati;
analyzed: gagane pana kare moraḥ nilīyati
translated: But if the peacock, while going in the sky, stops,

analyzed: tam karena iva cārentaḥ phandāpeti iti vuccati
translated: When he is doing this, he is said to be “making it move”.

original: Sace gaṇhāti taṃ moraṃ, itarena karena so;
analyzed: sace gaṇhāti tam moram itarena karena saḥ
translated: If he seizes the peacock, then, by the other one’s action,

original: Cāvitattā pana ṭhānā, bhikkhu ṭhānā cuto siyā.
analyzed: cāvitattā pana ṭhānā bhikkhu ṭhānā cutaḥ siyā
translated: the monk is dislodged from his place and is then “dislodged”.

original: Itaraṃ pana morassa, upaneti sace karaṃ;
analyzed: itaram pana mā urassaḥ upaneti sace karam
translated: But if the other one brings the peacock’s foot to him,

original: Na doso tattha uḍḍetvā, sayameva nilīyati.
analyzed: na dosaḥ tattha uḍḍetvā sayam eva nilīyati
translated: there is no offense. The peacock settles down by itself.

original: Disvā aṅge nilīnaṃ taṃ, theyyacittena gacchato;
analyzed: disvā aṅge nilīnam tam theyya cittena gacchataḥ
translated: If he sees the peacock settled down on a part of its body, and he moves with the intention of stealing it,

original: Pāde thullaccayaṃ hoti, dutiye ca parājayo.🔽Bhūmiyaṃ ṭhitamorassa, tīṇi ṭhānāni paṇḍito;
analyzed: pāde thullaccayam dutiye ca parājayaḥ  tīṇi ṭhānāni paṇḍito
translated: there is a serious offense for each foot, and at the second he is expelled.🔽The wise one should explain the three cases🔽of the peacock standing on the ground

original: Pādānañca kalāpassa, vasena paridīpaye.🔽Tato kesaggamattampi, moraṃ pathavito pana;
analyzed: pādānam ca kalāpassa vasena paridīpaye  tato kesagga mattam pi moram pathavito pana
translated: in terms of the feet and the tuft.🔽But if the monk lifts up the peacock even by the tip of a hair,

analyzed: hoti pārājikam tassa ukkhipantassa bhikkhuno
translated: he is expelled.

original: Chijjamānaṃ suvaṇṇādiṃ, patte patati ce pana;🔽Hatthena uddharantassa, tassa pārājikaṃ siyā.
analyzed: chijjamānam suvaṇṇa ādim patte patati ce pana  hatthena uddharantassa tassa pārājikam siyā
translated: If gold, etc., is being cut and a piece falls into a dish,🔽if he takes it with his hand, he is expelled.

analyzed: sace an uddharitvā ava theyya cittena gacchati
translated: But if he does not take it, but moves with the intention of stealing it,

analyzed: dutiye pada vārasmin pārājikam udīraye
translated: at the second step he is expelled.

original: Eseva ca nayo ñeyyo, hatthe vattheva matthake;
analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ ñeyyaḥ hatthe vatthā iva matthake
translated: This is the way to understand it: in the hand, in the cloth, on the head.

original: Taṃ taṃ tassa bhave ṭhānaṃ, yattha yattha patiṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: tam tam tassa bhave ṭhānam yattha yattha patiṭṭhitam
translated: Wherever it is placed, that is the place for it.

analyzed: ākāsa aṭṭhakathā
translated: The discussion of the sky.

analyzed: theyya cittena yam kiñci mañca pīṭha ādi suṭṭhitam
translated: Whatever is placed on a bed, a bench, and so on, with the intention to steal it,

analyzed: āmāsam pi an āmāsam āmasantassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: even if it is not worth a māsaka coin, it is an offense of wrong conduct for one who touches it.

original: Saṃharitvā sace vaṃse, ṭhapitaṃ hoti cīvaraṃ;
analyzed: saṃharitvā sace vaṃse ṭhapitam hoti cīvaram
translated: If a robe is placed in a bamboo robe rack,

original: Katvā punorato bhogaṃ, tathā antañca pārato.
analyzed: katvā punoratas bhogam tathā antam ca
translated: having made it into a roll, and then again into a bundle, in the same way at the end and at the side.

analyzed: cīvarena phuṭṭha ukāsaḥ ṭhānam tassa pavuccati
translated: The space covered by the robe is called the place for it.

original: Na tu cīvaravaṃso so, hotīti sakalo mato.🔽Orimantena okāsaṃ, phuṭṭhaṃ tamitarena vā;
analyzed: na tu cīvara vaṃsaḥ saḥ hoti iti sakalaḥ mataḥ  orimantena okāsam phuṭṭham tam itarena vā
translated: But the whole bamboo robe rack is not considered to be the robe.🔽If the space is covered by the end or by the middle,

original: Itarenapi vā phuṭṭhaṃ, orimantena vā puna.
analyzed: itarena api vā orimantena vā punar
translated: or if it is covered by the other end or by the middle,

analyzed: dakkhiṇa antena phuṭṭham vā vā
translated: or if the space is covered by the right side or by the left side,

original: Vāmantena phuṭṭhaṭṭhānaṃ, atikkāmayato cuti.🔽Uddhaṃ vā ukkhipantassa, cīvaraṃ pana vaṃsato;
analyzed: vāmantena phuṭṭha ṭṭhānam atikkāmayataḥ cuti  uddham vā ukkhipantassa cīvaram pana vaṃsataḥ
translated: then there is disavowal if one crosses the place that is covered by the left side.🔽If one lifts up the robe from the bamboo robe rack above,

analyzed: kesagga matte ukkhitte tassa pārājikam bhave
translated: then if it is lifted up even by a hair’s breadth, there is an offense entailing expulsion.

original: Rajjukena ca bandhitvā, ṭhapitaṃ pana cīvaraṃ;🔽Thullaccayaṃ vimocento, mutte pārājikaṃ phuse.🔽Veṭhetvā ṭhapitaṃ vaṃse, nibbeṭhentassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: rajjukena ca bandhitvā ṭhapitam pana cīvaram  thullaccayam vimocentaḥ mutte pārājikam phuse  veṭhetvā ṭhapitam vaṃse nibbeṭhentassa bhikkhuno
translated: A robe that’s been hung up, tied with a rope,

analyzed: valayam chindataḥ vā api mocentaḥ sa api ayam nayaḥ
translated: If he frees it, there’s a serious offense; if he touches it, there’s expulsion.

original: Cīvarassa pasāretvā, ṭhapitassa hi vaṃsake;🔽Saṃharitvā tu nikkhitte, cīvare viya nicchayo.
analyzed: cīvarassa pasāretvā ṭhapitassa hi vaṃsake  saṃharitvā tu nikkhitte cīvare viya nicchayo
translated: A robe that’s been hung up, tied to a bamboo pole,🔽If he frees it, there’s a serious offense; if he cuts the bamboo, the same.

original: Sikkāya pakkhipitvā yaṃ, laggitaṃ hoti bhaṇḍakaṃ;
analyzed: sikkāya pakkhipitvā yam laggitam hoti bhaṇḍakam
translated: A robe that’s been hung up, stretched out on a bamboo rack,

original: Sikkāto taṃ haranto vā, saha sikkāya vā cuto.
analyzed: tam harantaḥ vā saha sikkāya vā cutaḥ
translated: If he gathers it up and removes it, the same.

original: Kuntādiṃ nāgadantesu, ṭhitesu paṭipāṭiyā;🔽Agge vā pana bunde vā, gahetvā parikaḍḍhato.
analyzed: kunta ādim nāga dantesu ṭhitesu paṭipāṭiyā  agge vā pana bunde vā gahetvā parikaḍḍhato
translated: An article that’s been put into a bag,🔽If he removes it from the bag, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.🔽If a snake, etc., is in a bamboo pole,🔽If he takes hold of the top or the bottom and pulls it out,

analyzed: pārājikam phuṭṭha ukāsam atikkāmayataḥ siyā
translated: If he goes beyond the place that’s been touched by the expulsion offense,

original: Ujukaṃ ukkhipantassa, kesaggena parājayo.🔽Pākārābhimukho ṭhatvā, ākaḍḍhati sace pana;
analyzed: ujukam ukkhipantassa kesaggena parājayaḥ  ākāra abhimukhaḥ ākaḍḍhati sace pana
translated: If he pulls it out straight, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.🔽If he stands facing a wall and pulls it out,

analyzed: oḥ rimanta phuṭṭha okāsam itaranta caye cutaḥ
translated: If he goes beyond the place that’s been touched by the expulsion offense, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: tathā iva paratas tassa pellentassa api bhikkhuno
translated: The same for a monk who pulls it out from the other side.

original: Bhittiṃ pana ca nissāya, ṭhapitepi ayaṃ nayo.🔽Cālentassa ca tālassa, phalaṃ vatthu hi pūrati;
analyzed: bhittim pana ca nissāya ṭhapite pi ayam nayo  cālentassa ca tālassa phalam vatthu hi pūrati
translated: But the same method applies to a tree that is planted against a wall.🔽If a tree is shaken, the fruit fills the place where it falls;

original: Yenassa bandhanā mutte, tasmiṃ pārājikaṃ bhave.
analyzed: bandhanā mutte tasmin pārājikam bhave
translated: If the tree is released from its bonds, there is an offense entailing expulsion for that.

original: Piṇḍiṃ chindati tālassa, sace pārājikaṃ siyā;
analyzed: piṇḍim chindati tālassa sace pārājikam siyā
translated: If one cuts a piece of a palm fruit, and if it is an offense entailing expulsion,

analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ sesa rukkha puppha phalesu pi
translated: The same method applies to the flowers and fruits of other trees.

analyzed: vehāsa aṭṭhakathā
translated: The section on the flying fox.

original: Gacchato hi nidhiṭṭhānaṃ, padavārena dukkaṭaṃ;🔽Udake pana gambhīre, tathā nimujjanādisu.
analyzed: gacchataḥ hi nidhi ṭṭhānam pada vārena dukkaṭam  udake pana gambhīre tathā nimujjana ādisu
translated: If one is walking to a hidden treasure, there is an offense of wrong conduct for each step;🔽But in deep water, if one sinks, and so on.

analyzed: tattha jātaka pupphesu yena pupphena pūrati
translated: In the case of flowers growing there, with whatever flower the place is filled,

original: Vatthu taṃ chindato pupphaṃ, tassa pārājikaṃ vade.
analyzed: vatthu tam chindataḥ puppham tassa pārājikam vade
translated: If one cuts that flower, it is said that there is an offense entailing expulsion for that.

analyzed: eka nāḷassa vā passe vāko uppala jātiyā
translated: On one side of a reed, there is a frog and a blue lotus.

original: Na chijjati tato yāva, tāva naṃ parirakkhati.
analyzed: na chijjati tatas yāva tāva nam parirakkhati
translated: As long as it does not cut that, it protects it.

analyzed: sāmikehi iva pupphesu chinditvā ṭhapitesu pi
translated: In the case of flowers belonging to someone else, which have been cut and left there,

original: Pubbe vuttanayeneva, veditabbo vinicchayo.🔽Bhārabaddhāni pupphāni, chasvākāresu kenaci;
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ  bhāra baddhāni pupphāni chasu ākāresu kenacid
translated: The decision should be understood in the same way as stated previously.🔽If flowers are bound together in a bundle, and someone moves them

original: Ākārena sace tāni, ṭhānā cāveti nassati.
analyzed: ākārena sace tāni cāveti nassati
translated: in any way so that they leave their place and are lost,

analyzed: ṭhapitam pana pupphānam kalāpam jala piṭṭhiyam
translated: But if he moves a bunch of flowers placed on the surface of the water,

original: Cāletvā udakaṃ puppha-ṭṭhānā cāveti ce cuto.
analyzed: cāletvā udakam puppha ṭṭhānā cāveti ce cuto
translated: and the water moves away from the place where the flowers are, he is an offender.

analyzed: parikappeti ce ettha gahessāmi iti rakkhati
translated: If he arranges the flowers, thinking, “I will pick them here,” and he guards them,

analyzed: uddharantaḥ gata ṭṭhānāḥ bhaṭṭhaḥ nāma pavuccati
translated: but picks them from a different place, he is called a thief.

original: Accuggatassa taṃ ṭhānaṃ, jalato sakalaṃ jalaṃ;
analyzed: accuggatassa tam ṭhānam jalataḥ sakalam jalam
translated: The place belongs to the owner of the water; the whole of the water belongs to the owner of the water.

original: Uppāṭetvā tato pupphaṃ, ujumuddharato pana.🔽Nāḷante jalato mutta-matte pārājikaṃ bhave;
analyzed: uppāṭetvā tatas puppham ujum uddharataḥ pana  jalataḥ mutta matte pārājikam bhave
translated: If he picks the flowers from the water,🔽but the flowers are not yet out of the water when he takes hold of the stalk, there is an offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: tasmin thullaccayam udīritam
translated: If the flowers are out of the water when he takes hold of the stalk,🔽then it is said that there is a serious offense.

original: Pupphe gahetvā nāmetvā, uppāṭeti sace pana;
analyzed: pupphe gahetvā nāmetvā uppāṭeti sace pana
translated: If he picks the flowers, names them,

original: Na tassa udakaṃ ṭhānaṃ, naṭṭho uppāṭitakkhaṇe.
analyzed: na tassa udakam ṭhānam naṭṭhaḥ uppāṭita kkhaṇe
translated: and then picks them, then the water is not the place, and they are lost at the moment he names them.

original: Yo hi sassāmike macche, theyyacittena gaṇhati;
analyzed: yaḥ hi sa sāmike macche theyya cittena gaṇhati
translated: If someone with a thieving mind takes fish that belong to someone else,

analyzed: baḷisena api jālena hatthena kuminena vā
translated: whether with a net or a basket, or with his hands or with his fists,

original: Tassevaṃ gaṇhato vatthu, yena macchena pūrati;🔽Tasmiṃ uddhaṭamattasmiṃ, jalā hoti parājayo.
analyzed: tassa ivam gaṇhataḥ vatthu yena macchena pūrati  tasmin uddhaṭa mattasmin parājayaḥ
translated: then as he is taking them, the value of the fish that fill the net,🔽the basket, or whatever it is, is the value of the stolen goods.

analyzed: ṭhānam salila jānan hi kevalam sakalam jalam
translated: The place belongs to the owner of the water; the whole of the water belongs to the owner of the water.

analyzed: pārājikaḥ bhave
translated: If he frees the water, he becomes an offender with a defeated one.

original: Nīrato uppatitvā yo, tīre patati vārijo;
analyzed: nīrataḥ uppatitvā yaḥ tīre patati vāri jaḥ
translated: If a crocodile jumps out of the water and lands on the bank,

analyzed: gaṇhataḥ tam pana āpattim bhaṇḍagghena viniddise
translated: The offense for catching it should be determined by the value of the goods.

analyzed: macchānam taḷāke vā
translated: If, for the purpose of killing fish, he puts poison in a pond or a river,

original: Ninne macchavisaṃ nāma, pakkhipitvā gate pana.🔽Pacchā macchavisaṃ macchā, khāditvā pilavanti ce;
analyzed: ninne macchavisam nāma pakkhipitvā gate pana  pacchā maccha visam macchā khāditvā pilavanti ce
translated: And then, after leaving, the fish die because of the fish poison,🔽And the water is drunk by cattle and people,

analyzed: pārājikam mate macche theyya cittena gaṇhato
translated: If he catches the dead fish with the intention to steal, he becomes an offender with a defeated one.

original: Paṃsukūlikasaññāya, na doso koci gaṇhato;🔽Sāmikesvāharantesu, bhaṇḍadeyyamudīritaṃ.
analyzed: paṃsukūlika saññāya na doso koci gaṇhato  sāmikeṣu āharantesu bhaṇḍadeyyam udīritam
translated: If he catches them with the perception that they are rags, there is no offense at all.🔽If the owners take them away, it is said that he should make restitution for the goods.

original: Gahetvā sāmikā macche, sace yanti nirālayā;
analyzed: sāmikāḥ macche sace yanti nirālayā
translated: If the owners take the fish away, leaving nothing behind,

original: Gaṇhato pana te sese, theyyacittena dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇhataḥ pana te sese theyya cittena dukkaṭam
translated: But if he catches the remaining fish with the intention to steal, it is a serious offense.

analyzed: amatesu anāpattim vadanti vinayaññunaḥ
translated: The experts on the Monastic Law say that there is no offense if they are dead.

original: Eseva ca nayo sese, kacchapādimhi vārije.
analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ sese kacchapa ādimhi vāri je
translated: This is the method for the remaining water creatures, such as turtles.

analyzed: uda kaṭṭhakathā
translated: The discussion of water is finished.

analyzed: nāvam nāvaṭṭham vā bhaṇḍam thenetvā gaṇhissāmi iti
translated: “I’ll steal the boat or the goods on the boat after cutting the rope,”

analyzed: pāduddhāre dosāḥ vuttāḥ bhikkhussa ivam gacchantassa
translated: The experts on the Monastic Law say that there is an offense for a monk who goes there.

analyzed: baddhāya nāvāya hi caṇḍasote
translated: For a boat that is tied up in a strong current,

analyzed: ṭhānam matam bandhanam ekam eva
translated: The place and the one tie are the only things that are fixed;

analyzed: bhikkhussa tasmin mutta matte
translated: When the monk has let go of it,

analyzed: pārājikam tassa vadanti dhīrā
translated: The wise say that he has committed an offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: niccale udake nāvam abandhanam avaṭṭhitam
translated: If the boat is not tied up in still water,

original: Purato pacchato vāpi, passato vāpi kaḍḍhato.
analyzed: puratas pacchatas vā api passataḥ vā api kaḍḍhataḥ
translated: whether it is pulled forward or backward or to the side,

analyzed: ekena antena samphuṭṭham okāsam itarena tam
translated: and if he crosses the boundary while in contact with it,

analyzed: atikkāmayataḥ nāvam tassa pārājikam siyā
translated: then he commits an offense entailing expulsion.

original: 121. Tathā –🔽Uddhaṃ kesaggamattampi, udakamhā vimocite;🔽Adhonāvātalaṃ tena, phuṭṭhañca mukhavaṭṭiyā.
analyzed: tathā  uddham kesagga mattam pi udakamhā vimocite  adhas nāvā talam tena phuṭṭham ca mukhavaṭṭiyā
translated: And also:🔽If he lets go of it even to the height of a hair tip above the water,🔽and the boat is touched by the waterline and by the rim of his mouth,

original: Bandhitvā pana yā tīre, ṭhapitā niccale jale;
analyzed: bandhitvā pana yā tīre ṭhapitā niccale jale
translated: but he has tied it to the bank,

original: Bandhanañca ṭhitokāso, ṭhānaṃ tassā dvidhā mataṃ.
analyzed: bandhanam ca ṭhita ukāsaḥ ṭhānam tassā dvidhā matam
translated: then the place is considered to be twofold: the boat and the space where it is fixed.

analyzed: hoti thullaccayam pubbam bandhanassa vimocane
translated: There is a serious offense for the first disconnection of the tie;

original: Pacchā kenacupāyena, ṭhānā cāveti ce cuto.
analyzed: pacchā kenacupāyena ṭhānā ca ava iti ce
translated: after that, if he moves it by some means, he is expelled.

analyzed: cāvetvā paṭhamam pacchā bandhana mocane
translated: If he first moves it from the place and then disconnects the tie,

original: Eseva ca nayo vutto, theyyacittassa bhikkhuno.
analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ vuttaḥ theyya cittassa bhikkhuno
translated: this is the same as what was said about a monk with a stealing mind.

analyzed: ussāretvā nikujjitvā ṭhapitāya thale pana
translated: When it’s lifted up and then let go, and it comes to rest on dry land,

analyzed: phuṭṭha ukāsā uva hi ṭhānam nāvāya mukhavaṭṭiyā
translated: The place where it touches is the place

analyzed: ñeyyaḥ ṭhāna paricchedaḥ
translated: That should be understood as the boundary

analyzed: ākāreha iva pañcahi
translated: By the five characteristics.

analyzed: yatas kutocid
translated: If he moves it from wherever it is,

analyzed: hoti pārājikaḥ naraḥ
translated: That man becomes an offender.🔽And this is the method to be understood

analyzed: ca nayaḥ ñeyyaḥ
translated: When the boat is turned over,🔽Or when it’s tied up, or when it’s on the bank,

analyzed: nāvāya
translated: Or when it’s on the top of a basket.🔽If he boards a boat that’s moored🔽At a landing stage that’s under surveillance,

original: Theyyā titthe ṭhitaṃ nāvaṃ, āruhitvā sace pana;
analyzed: theyyā titthe ṭhitam nāvam āruhitvā sace pana
translated: And then sails away, even if only a little,

original: Arittena phiyenāpi, pājentassa parājayo.🔽Sace chattaṃ paṇāmetvā, ussāpetvāva cīvaraṃ;
analyzed: arittena phiyena api pājentassa parājayaḥ  sace chattam paṇāmetvā ussāpetvā ava cīvaram
translated: He becomes an offender.🔽If he has the boatman lower the sail,🔽Lift up the sail,

original: Laṅkārasadisaṃ katvā, gaṇhāpeti samīraṇaṃ.🔽Āgamma balavā vāto, nāvaṃ harati ce pana;
analyzed: laṅkā rasa disam katvā samīraṇam  āgamma balavā vātaḥ nāvam harati ce pana
translated: And then take down the sail, which is like an ornament,🔽And then a strong wind comes and carries the boat away,🔽Then the boat has been carried away by the wind,

original: Vāteneva haṭā nāvā, na doso koci vijjati.
analyzed: vātena iva haṭā nāvā na dosaḥ koci vijjati
translated: And there’s no offense for him.

analyzed: sayam eva ca yam kiñci gāma tittham upāgatam
translated: If he himself goes to a village or a landing stage,

original: Acāventova taṃ ṭhānā, kiṇitvā ce palāyati.
analyzed: tam tam ce palāyati
translated: And then moves it from that place, and he sells it,

analyzed: avahāraḥ na bhikkhussa bhaṇḍa deyyam udīritam
translated: There’s no offense for the monk,🔽But the goods should be forfeited.🔽If he goes to a place that’s not a landing stage,

original: Sayameva ca gacchantiṃ, ṭhānā cāveti ce cuto.
analyzed: sayam eva ca gacchantim ca
translated: And then moves it from that place, he’s expelled.

analyzed: na avaṭṭhakathā
translated: The discussion of vehicles is finished.

original: Yānaṃ nāma ratho vayhaṃ, sakaṭaṃ sandamānikā;
analyzed: yānam nāma rathaḥ vayham sakaṭam sandamānikā
translated: A vehicle: a chariot, a boat, a cart, a palanquin.

analyzed: yānam avaharissāmi yāna aṭṭham iti vā pana
translated: I’ll steal a vehicle, or I’ll steal what’s in a vehicle.

analyzed: gacchataḥ dukkaṭam vuttam dutiyam pariyesataḥ
translated: When going, it’s said there’s a serious offense; when searching for a second time,

analyzed: ṭhānā ca avana yogasmin vijjamāne parājayaḥ
translated: when moving it from its base, if there’s a harness, there’s a defeat.

analyzed: yānassa duka yuttassa dasa ṭhānāni dīpaye
translated: For a vehicle with two yokes, there are ten bases.

original: Yānaṃ pājayato tassa, nisīditvā dhure pana.
analyzed: yānam tassa nisīditvā dhure pana
translated: For one who’s defeated by a vehicle, while sitting on the pole,

analyzed: thullaccayam tu goṇānam pād uddhāre viniddise
translated: there’s a serious offense for oxen, when the yoke is lifted, when the yoke is lowered.

analyzed: parābhavaḥ
translated: When the wheels have gone beyond the standing place, there’s a defeat.

analyzed: ayuttakassa api ca yānakassa ṭhitassa
translated: And for a vehicle that’s not yoked, when standing with the pole in place,

original: Vasenupatthambhanicakkakānaṃ, ṭhānāni tīṇeva bhavanti tassa.🔽Tathā dhurena dārūnaṃ, upariṭṭhapitassa ca;
analyzed: ṭhānāni tīṇi iva bhavanti tassa  tathā dhurena dārūnaṃ upari ṭhapitassa ca
translated: there are three bases for the wheels to be in place.🔽In the same way, when the pole is placed on top of the wood,

analyzed: dhurena iva tathā iva ṭhapitassa ca
translated: and on the ground, when the pole is placed in the same way,

original: Purato pacchato vāpi, ṭhānā cāveti ce pana;
analyzed: puratas pacchatas vā api ṭhānā ce pana
translated: if one moves it from its place, either in front or behind,

original: Thullaccayaṃ tu tiṇṇampi, ṭhānā cāve parājayo.
analyzed: thullaccayam tu tiṇṇam pi cāve parājayaḥ
translated: there’s a serious offense for all three, and a defeat when moving it from its place.”

analyzed: apanetvāna cakkāni akkhānam sīsakehi tu
translated: Having removed the wheels, and the axles with the yoking-poles,

analyzed: ṭhitassu upari ṭhānāni dve viniddise
translated: And having marked two places on the wood,

original: Kaḍḍhanto ukkhipanto vā, phuṭṭhokāsaccaye cuto;🔽Ṭhapitassa panaññassa, bhūmiyaṃ yassa kassaci.
analyzed: kaḍḍhantaḥ ukkhipantaḥ vā phuṭṭha ukāsa caye cutaḥ  ṭhapitassa panaññassa bhūmiyam yassa kassaci
translated: While he is pulling or lifting, if he breaks what is broken up,🔽Or if he puts down another one, on the ground, of anyone at all,

analyzed: akkhuddhīnam dhurassa ati pañca ṭhānāni dīpaye
translated: If he is not aiming at the wheels, or at the yoke-pole, he is showing five places:

original: Uddhīsu vā gahetvā taṃ, ṭhānā cāveti ce cuto.
analyzed: vā tam tam
translated: If he moves it from its place, having seized it by the yoking-poles, he is broken.

original: Ṭhapitassa hi cakkassa, nābhiyā pana bhūmiyaṃ;
analyzed: ṭhapitassa hi cakkassa nābhiyā pana bhūmiyam
translated: For the wheel that is put down, on the ground, by the nave,

analyzed: ekam eva siyāḥ ṭhānam paricchedaḥ api pañcadhā
translated: There is only one place, and the delimitation is fivefold.

original: Phusitvā yaṃ ṭhitaṃ bhūmiṃ, nemipassena nābhiyā;
analyzed: phusitvā yam ṭhitam bhūmim nemi passena nābhiyā
translated: If it is standing touching the ground, by the side of the wheel-rim, by the nave,

analyzed: ṭhānāni dve bhavantassa naṭṭhaḥ tesam atikkame
translated: There are two places for it, and it is lost if he goes beyond them.

original: Disvā yānamanārakkhaṃ, paṭipannaṃ mahāpathe;🔽Āruhitvā acodetvā, kiṇitvā yāti vaṭṭati.
analyzed: disvā yānam anārakkham paṭipannam mahāpathe  āruhitvā a codetvā kiṇitvā yāti vaṭṭati
translated: Having seen a vehicle without a keeper, that is going along the main road,

original: Yānaṭṭhakathā.🔽Sīsakkhandhakaṭolamba-vasā bhāro catubbidho;🔽Tattha sīsagataṃ bhāraṃ, āmasantassa dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: yāna aṭṭhakathā 🔽sīsa khandha kaṭaḥ lamba vasā bhāraḥ catubbidhaḥ 🔽tattha sīsa gatam bhāram āmasantassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: Having mounted it, and not having announced himself, if he goes after buying it, it is allowable.

original: Ito cito ca ghaṃsanto, theyyacittena yo pana;
analyzed: itas citas ca theyya cittena yaḥ pana
translated: If, while looking here and there, he should think, ‘I’ll steal it,’

analyzed: tassa thullaccayam siyā
translated: and should move it from its base, then there is a serious offense.

original: Khandhaṃ oropite bhāre, tassa pārājikaṃ mataṃ;
analyzed: khandhaṃ oropite bhāre tassa pārājikam matam
translated: If he lowers the load, then it is considered a pārājika offense;

analyzed: sīsataḥ mocentaḥ api parājito
translated: if he frees even a hair from the head, then he is defeated.

analyzed: bhāram pathaviyam kiñci ṭhapetvā suddha mānasaḥ
translated: If he places the load on the ground, with a pure mind,

analyzed: pacchā tam theyya cittena uddharantaḥ
translated: and later, with a thought to steal, picks it up, then he is defeated.

analyzed: ettha vutta nayena iva sesesu pi asesataḥ
translated: In the same way as stated here, in the rest of the cases as well,

analyzed: bhāresu mati sārena veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: the decision should be understood by the meaning of the words in the load.

analyzed: bhāraṭṭhakathā
translated: The Discussion of the Load.

analyzed: dukkaṭam muninā vuttam ārāmam abhiyuñjataḥ
translated: The one who asks for a monastery is said by the Sage to commit an offense of wrong conduct;

original: Parājeti paraṃ dhammaṃ, caranto ce parājito.522🔽Vimatiṃ janayantassa, tassa thullaccayaṃ siyā;
analyzed: parājeti param dhammam caranto ce  vimatim janayantassa tassa thullaccayam siyā
translated: if he moves it, then he is defeated if he is acting according to the Teaching of another.🔽If he causes uncertainty, then there is a serious offense for him;

original: Parajjati sayaṃ dhammaṃ, caranto yopi tassa ca.
analyzed: parajjati sayam dhammam carantaḥ yaḥ pi tassa ca
translated: if he is acting according to his own Teaching, then he is defeated.

analyzed: sāminaḥ dhura nikkhepe na dassāmi iti cattano
translated: If the owners remove the burden, saying, “We won’t give,”

analyzed: pārājikam bhave tassa sabbesam kūṭa sakkhinam
translated: then there is a pārājika offense for all of them, if they are dishonest.

analyzed: ārāmaṭṭhakathā
translated: The Discussion of the Monastery.

analyzed: vihāram saṅghikam kiñci gaṇhitum
translated: If he takes away, having cut off, anything from a monastery belonging to the Sangha,

analyzed: sabbesam dhura nikkhepa abhāvataḥ uva na sijjhati
translated: It is not allowable because of the absence of the laying down of the burden for all.

analyzed: vihāra aṭṭhakathā  sīsāni gaṇhataḥ
translated: The explanation of the monastery.🔽If he takes away, having filled his mouth with the heads of rice, etc.,

original: Asitena ca lāyitvā, chinditvā vā karena ca.
analyzed: asitena ca lāyitvā chinditvā vā karena ca
translated: And having loosened it with his teeth, having cut it with his nails, and with his hand,

original: Yasmiṃ bījepi vā vatthu, sīse pūreti muṭṭhiyaṃ;
analyzed: yasmin bīje api vā vatthu sīse pūreti muṭṭhiyam
translated: In whatever seed-plot, in the head, the mouth is filled with a handful,

original: Bandhanā mocite tasmiṃ, tassa pārājikaṃ bhave.🔽Acchinno pana daṇḍo vā, taco vā appamattako;
analyzed: bandhanā mocite tasmin tassa pārājikam bhave  acchinnaḥ pana daṇḍaḥ vā tacaḥ vā appamattako
translated: When the binding is released, there is an offence involving defeat for him.🔽But if the stalk or the husk is not cut off, even a little,

original: Vīhināḷampi vā dīghaṃ, anikkhantova rakkhati.🔽Sace so parikappeti, “madditvā panidaṃ ahaṃ;
analyzed: vīhi nāḷam pi vā dīgham a nikkhantaḥ uva rakkhati  sace saḥ parikappeti madditvā aham
translated: Or if the stem or the reed is not taken out, he guards it.🔽If he thinks, “Having pounded this, I will put it aside,”

analyzed: papphoṭetvā itas sāram gaṇhissāmi iti rakkhati
translated: And he guards it thinking, “Having rubbed it here, I will take the essence,”

analyzed: madda uddharaṇe natthi doso papphoṭane pi vā
translated: There is no offence in the extracting of the juice or in the rubbing,

analyzed: attanaḥ bhājana gatam karontassa parājayaḥ
translated: But there is defeat for him who makes it go into his own vessel.

analyzed: jānam kesagga mattam pi pathavim
translated: If he knows that the earth, even as much as the tip of a hair, belongs to another,

analyzed: theyya cittena ce khīlam saṅkāmeti parājayaḥ
translated: And if he moves a peg with the thought of stealing, there is an offence involving defeat.

original: Tañca kho sāmikānaṃ tu, dhuranikkhepane sati;
analyzed: tat ca kho sāmikānam tu dhura nikkhepane sati
translated: But if the owners have given up their claim,

original: Anagghā bhūmi nāmesā, tasmā evamudīritaṃ.🔽Gahetabbā sace hoti, dvīhi khīlehi yā pana;
analyzed: anagghā bhūmi nāma isā tasmai evam udīritam  gahetabbā sace hoti dvīhi khīlehi yā pana
translated: This land is priceless, and so it is called.🔽If it can be taken, then, by two means:

analyzed: thullaccayam tesu dutiyā iva parājayo
translated: If it is taken by these two means, there is a serious offense at first, and defeat for the second.

analyzed: ñāpetu kāmaḥ yaḥ bhikkhu mama idam santakan ti ca
translated: If a monk wants to point out, “This belongs to me,”

original: Rajjuṃ vāpi pasāreti, yaṭṭhiṃ pāteti dukkaṭaṃ.🔽Yehi dvīhi payogehi, attano santakaṃ siyā;
analyzed: rajjum vā api pasāreti yaṭṭhim pāteti dukkaṭam  yehi dvīhi payogehi attanaḥ santakam siyā
translated: And he stretches out a rope or a stick, it is wrong conduct.

original: Ādo thullaccayaṃ tesu, dutiye ca parājayo.
analyzed: thullaccayam tesu dutiye ca parājayaḥ
translated: If it is taken by these two means, there is a serious offense at first, and defeat for the second.

analyzed: khetta ṭṭhakathā  khette vutta nayena iva vatthuṭṭhassa vinicchayaḥ
translated: The discussion of fields.🔽The decision about a field is in the same way as for a field.

original: Gāmaṭṭhepi ca vattabbaṃ, apubbaṃ natthi kiñcipi.
analyzed: ca vattabbam apubbam natthi kiñci pi
translated: And it should be said for a village, too: there is nothing new.

analyzed: vatthu ṭṭha gāma ṭṭha kathā
translated: The discussion of fields and villages.

original: Tiṇaṃ vā pana paṇṇaṃ vā, lataṃ vā kaṭṭhameva vā;
analyzed: tiṇam vā pana paṇṇam vā latam vā kaṭṭham eva vā
translated: If he takes grass, leaves, creepers, or wood,

original: Bhaṇḍaggheneva kātabbo, gaṇhanto tatthajātakaṃ.🔽Mahagghe pana rukkhasmiṃ, chinnamattepi nassati;
analyzed: bhaṇḍagghena iva kātabbaḥ gaṇhantaḥ tattha jātakam  mahagghe pana rukkhasmiṃ chinna matte pi nassati
translated: It should be treated as goods, and he is guilty of the offense.🔽But if the tree is valuable, it is lost as soon as it is cut down.

original: Tacchetvā ṭhapito rukkho, gahetabbo na kocipi.
analyzed: tat śetvā ṭhapitaḥ rukkhaḥ gahetabbaḥ na koci api
translated: And no one may take a tree that has been cut down and left there.

analyzed: chinditvā ṭhapitam mūle rukkha maddha gatam pana
translated: If it’s cut down and left at the root, or if it’s half on a tree stump,

analyzed: chaḍḍitaḥ sāmikehi iti gahetum pana vaṭṭati
translated: It’s allowable to take it if it’s been abandoned by the owner.

original: Lakkhaṇe challiyonaddhe, na doso koci gaṇhato;🔽Ajjhāvutthaṃ kataṃ vāpi, vinassantañca gaṇhato.
analyzed: lakkhaṇe challiyā unaddhe na doso koci gaṇhato  ajjhāvuttham katam vā api vinassantam ca gaṇhataḥ
translated: If it’s marked with a sign or bound with a creeper, there’s no offense in taking it;🔽Nor if it’s been recited or made, or if it’s being destroyed.

analyzed: yaḥ ca ārakkha ṭṭhānam patvā katvā kammaṭṭhāna ādīni
translated: If someone goes to a place of danger, and after doing walking meditation, etc.,

original: Citte cintento vā aññaṃ, bhaṇḍadeyyaṃ hotevassa.
analyzed: citte cintentaḥ vā aññam bhaṇḍa deyyam
translated: Or thinking about the mind, or something else, it becomes the property of the owner.

analyzed: varāha byaggha chata racchaka āditaḥ
translated: If a boar, a tiger, a snake, a rat, or something else

analyzed: upaddavā muccitu kāma tāya yaḥ
translated: Has damaged it, and the owner wants to free it,

analyzed: tathā iva tam ṭhānam atikkameti ce
translated: And he then goes beyond that place,

analyzed: na koci dosaḥ pana bhaṇḍadeyyakam
translated: There’s no offense, but it becomes the property of the owner.

analyzed: idam ārakkhaṇa ṭṭhānam garukam suṅka ghātato
translated: This place of danger is serious, more so than a trap.

analyzed: tasmā dukkaṭam uddiṭṭham tam an ukkamma gacchataḥ
translated: Therefore, if you go after announcing it, it’s a wrong-doing.

analyzed: etam pariharantassa theyya cittena satthunā
translated: If you avoid it, but with the intention to steal you take it

analyzed: pārājikam an uddiṭṭham ākāsena api gacchataḥ
translated: From the owner, it’s an offense entailing expulsion, even if you carry it through the air.

analyzed: tasmai ettha visesena sati sampanna cetasā
translated: Therefore, with a mind endowed with mindfulness,

analyzed: appamattena hotabbam piya sīlena bhikkhunā 🔽arañña aṭṭhakathā
translated: A monk who is dear to the virtuous should be heedful in this respect.

analyzed: bhājane gopitam jalam
translated: If the water is scarce, and the water is hidden in a vessel,

original: Āviñjitvā pavesetvā, chiddaṃ katvāpi vā tathā.
analyzed: āviñjitvā pavesetvā chiddam katvā api vā tathā
translated: Having taken it out and having brought it in, or having made a hole in it,

original: Vāpiyaṃ vā taḷāke vā, bhājanaṃ attano pana;🔽Gaṇhantassa pavesetvā, bhaṇḍagghena viniddise.
analyzed: vāpiyam vā taḷāke vā bhājanam pana  gaṇhantassa pavesetvā bhaṇḍagghena viniddise
translated: In a tank or in a pond, in one’s own vessel,🔽Having taken it and having brought it in, one is to be charged with the value of the goods.

analyzed: chindataḥ mariyādam tu adinna ādāna pubbataḥ
translated: If one cuts the boundary, but before the stealing,

analyzed: bhūta gāmena dukkaṭam paridīpitam
translated: Together with the being-spirit, it is said to be a fault.

original: Anto ṭhatvā bahi ṭhatvā, chindanto ubhayatthapi;
analyzed: antar ṭhatvā bahi ṭhatvā chindantaḥ ubhayattha api
translated: Standing inside and standing outside, cutting in both places,

analyzed: bahi antena kātabbaḥ antar antena majjhataḥ
translated: The outside-inside should be done, the inside-inside from the middle.

analyzed: udaka kathā  vārena sāmaṇerāḥ yam dantakaṭṭham araññataḥ
translated: The discussion of water.🔽If the novices, in turn, having brought back a tooth-stick from the forest,

analyzed: āharanti sace pana
translated: And if they bring it to the teachers, too,

original: Chinditvā yāva saṅghassa, na niyyādenti te pana;
analyzed: chinditvā yāva saṅghassa na niyyādenti te pana
translated: Having cut it, as long as they do not hand it over to the Community,

original: Ābhataṃ tāva taṃ sabbaṃ, tesameva ca santakaṃ.
analyzed: ābhatam tāva tat sabbam tesam eva ca santakam
translated: All that is brought is the property of them alone.

original: Tasmā taṃ theyyacittena, gaṇhantassa ca bhikkhuno;
analyzed: tasmā tam theyya cittena gaṇhantassa ca bhikkhunaḥ
translated: Therefore, if a monk takes it with a mind of theft,

analyzed: saṅghassa bhaṇḍagghena parābhavaḥ
translated: And the heavy goods of the Community, he is defeated with the value of the goods.

original: Yadā niyyāditaṃ tehi, tato paṭṭhāya saṅghikaṃ;
analyzed: yadā niyyāditam tehi tatas paṭṭhāya saṅghikam
translated: When it is handed over by them, from then on it is the property of the Community;

analyzed: gaṇhantassa api theyyāya avahāraḥ na vijjati
translated: If he takes it, there is no offense entailing relinquishment for stealing.

analyzed: a rakkhattā yathāvuḍḍham a bhājetabbataḥ pi ca
translated: Because it is not guarded, because it is not to be divided according to seniority,

original: Sabbasādhāraṇattā ca, aññaṃ viya na hotidaṃ.
analyzed: sabba sādhāraṇa ttā ca aññam viya na
translated: and because it is shared by all, it is not like the other cases.

analyzed: dantakaṭṭhakathā
translated: The discussion of tooth cleaners.

original: Aggiṃ vā deti satthena, ākoṭeti samantato;🔽Ākoṭeti visaṃ vāpi, maṇḍūkaṇṭakanāmakaṃ.
analyzed: aggim vā deti satthena ākoṭeti samantataḥ  ākoṭa iti visam vā api maṇḍūkaṇṭaka nāmakam
translated: If he gives fire, if he strikes with a weapon all around,🔽if he strikes with poison called “frog’s thorn”,

original: Yena vā tena vā rukkho, vinassati ca ḍayhati;
analyzed: yena vā tena vā rukkhaḥ vinassati ca ḍayhati
translated: if the tree is destroyed and burns down

analyzed: sabbattha bhikkhuno tassa bhaṇḍa deyyam pakāsitam
translated: in any way, the penalty for the monk is declared to be the value of the property.

original: Vanappatikathā.🔽Sīsato kaṇṇato vāpi, gīvato hatthatopi vā;
analyzed: vanappati kathā  sīsataḥ kaṇṇataḥ vā api gīvataḥ hatthataḥ pi vā
translated: The discussion of the forest.🔽If he cuts or releases🔽from the head, the ears, the neck, or the hand,

original: Chinditvā vāpi mocetvā, gaṇhato theyyacetasā.🔽Hoti mocitamattasmiṃ, sīsādīhi parājayo;🔽Thullaccayaṃ karontassa, ākaḍḍhanavikaḍḍhanaṃ.🔽Hatthā anīharitvāva, valayaṃ kaṭakampi vā;
analyzed: chinditvā vā api gaṇhataḥ theyya cetasā  mocita mattasmin sīsa ādīhi  thullaccayam karontassa ākaḍḍhana vikaḍḍhanam  hatthāḥ valayam kaṭakam pi vā
translated: and seizes it with the intention to steal,🔽there is failure by the head, etc., as soon as it is released.🔽If he is acting with a serious offense, pulling and dragging,

analyzed: agga bāhum ca ghaṃsantaḥ cāreti apara aparam
translated: without removing the hand, the bracelet, or the anklet,🔽and he moves the upper arm back and forth,

analyzed: tam ākāsa gatam coraḥ karoti yadi rakkhati
translated: if the thief makes it fly up into the air and guards it,

analyzed: mūle valayam va na hoti dam
translated: it is not like a bracelet at the root with consciousness.

original: Nivatthaṃ pana vatthaṃ yo, acchindati parassa ce;
analyzed: nivattham pana vattham yaḥ a chindati parassa ce
translated: But if someone else seizes the garment That has been taken off by the owner,

original: Paropi pana lajjāya, sahasā taṃ na muñcati.🔽Ākaḍḍhati ca coropi, so paro tāva rakkhati;
analyzed: paraḥ api pana lajjāya sahasā tam na muñcati  ākaḍḍhati ca coro pi so paro tāva rakkhati
translated: And the owner, out of shame, Does not immediately let go of it,🔽And the thief pulls it, The owner protects it.

original: Parassa hatthato vatthe, muttamatte parājayo.🔽Sabhaṇḍahārakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ, nentassa paṭhame pade;🔽Thullaccayamatikkante, dutiyeva cuto siyā.
analyzed: parassa hatthataḥ vatthe mutta matte parājayaḥ  sa bhaṇḍa hārakam bhaṇḍam nentassa paṭhame pade  thullaccayam atikkante dutiyā iva cutaḥ siyā
translated: As soon as the garment is let go of by the other, There is defeat.

original: Pātāpeti sace bhaṇḍaṃ, tajjetvā theyyacetano;🔽Parassa hatthato bhaṇḍe, muttamatte parājayo.
analyzed: sace bhaṇḍam tat jetvā  parassa hatthataḥ bhaṇḍe mutta matte parājayaḥ
translated: If the thief takes away the goods, Having threatened the owner,🔽As soon as the goods are let go of by the other, There is defeat.

original: Athāpi parikappetvā, pātāpeti va yo pana;
analyzed: atha api parikappetvā yaḥ pana
translated: But if, after having threatened, He makes the other take it away,

analyzed: tassa pāta āpane vuttam dukkaṭa āmasane pi ca
translated: Then for the one who makes him take it away, The offense is as stated for the one who makes him carry it.

original: Phandāpeti yathāvatthuṃ, ṭhānā cāveti ce cuto;
analyzed: phandā apeti yathāvatthum ṭhānā ca aveti ce cuto
translated: If he threatens in the right way, And moves it from its base, he is defeated.

original: “Tiṭṭha tiṭṭhā”ti vadato, na doso chaḍḍitepi ca.
analyzed: tiṭṭha tiṭṭha ati vadataḥ na dosaḥ chaḍḍite pi ca
translated: If he says, “Stop, stop,” There is no offense if he lets go.🔽If he comes with the intention to steal, And then seizes it, there is no offense.

original: Āgantvā theyyacittena, pacchā taṃ gaṇhato siyā;🔽Pārājikaṃ taduddhāre, sālaye sāmike gate.
analyzed: āgantvā theyya cittena pacchā tam gaṇhataḥ siyā  pārājikam tad uddhāre sa ālaye sāmike gate
translated: If he takes it out of the enclosure, And the owner has gone,

analyzed: gaṇhato saka saññāya gahaṇe pana rakkhati
translated: If he seizes it, thinking it is his own, But then protects it when he realizes it is not his,

analyzed: bhaṇḍa deyyam tathā paṃsukūla saññāya gaṇhataḥ
translated: And the same applies to taking away what is thrown away, if he perceives it as rubbish.

original: “Tiṭṭha tiṭṭhā”ti vutto ca, chaḍḍetvā pana bhaṇḍakaṃ;🔽Katvāva dhuranikkhepaṃ, bhīto corā palāyati.
analyzed: tiṭṭha tiṭṭha ati vuttaḥ ca chaḍḍetvā pana bhaṇḍakam  katvā ava dhura nikkhepam bhītaḥ corā palāyati
translated: If he is told, “Stop, stop!” and he throws down the goods,🔽But then, after putting down his burden, he runs away out of fear,

analyzed: gaṇhato theyya cittena uddhāre dukkaṭam puna
translated: Then, if he is taking it with the intention of stealing, there is an offense of wrong conduct for each taking up;

analyzed: dātabbam āhara apente a dentassa parājayaḥ
translated: If he makes the other person take it back, there is a serious offense for not giving it up.

analyzed: kasmā tassa payogena sādaram
translated: “Why? Because it was thrown away by his effort,” he should be pressed.

analyzed: mahā aṭṭhakathā ayam tu vuttam aññāsu na āgatam
translated: But in the Great Commentary, it is said that the rest should be treated as in the following rule.

analyzed: haraṇa kathā
translated: The rule on stealing.

analyzed: sampajāna musāvādam na gaṇhāmi iti
translated: If he lies in full awareness, saying, “I’m not taking it,”

analyzed: adinnādāna pubbattā dukkaṭam hoti bhikkhuno
translated: then, since it is preceded by stealing, there is an offense of wrong conduct for the monk.

original: “Raho mayā panetassa, ṭhapitaṃ kiṃ nu dassati”;🔽Iccevaṃ vimatuppāde, tassa thullaccayaṃ siyā.
analyzed: rahaḥ mayā pana itassa ṭhapitam kim nu dassati  icc evam vimati uppāde tassa thullaccayam siyā
translated: “I’ve hidden it from him. What will he do now?”🔽If he thinks like this, then, when the other person has the thought, there is a serious offense for him.

original: Tasmiṃ dāne nirussāhe, paro ce nikkhipe dhuraṃ;
analyzed: tasmim dāne nirussāhe paras ce nikkhipe dhuram
translated: If the other person puts down his burden,

analyzed: ubhinnam dhura nikkhepe bhikkhu hoti parājitaḥ
translated: then, since both have put down their burden, the monk is defeated.

analyzed: cittena ādātu kāmaḥ uva dassāmi iti mukhena ce
translated: If he only wants to take it in his mind, but says, “I’ll give it,”

analyzed: vadataḥ dhura nikkhepe sāminaḥ hi parājayaḥ
translated: then, since it is the owner who has put down his burden, he is defeated.

original: Upanidhikathā.🔽Suṅkaghātassa antova, ṭhatvā pāteti ce bahi;
analyzed: upanidhi kathā  suṅkaghātassa antar iva ṭhatvā pāta iti ce bahi
translated: The story of the buried treasure.🔽If he stands inside the house and throws it out,

original: Dhuvaṃ patati ce hatthā, muttamatte parājayo.🔽Taṃ rukkhe khāṇuke vāpi, hutvā paṭihataṃ puna;
analyzed: patati ce hatthā mutta matte parājayaḥ  tam rukkhe khāṇuke vā api hutvā paṭihatam puna
translated: and it falls outside, he loses it as soon as it leaves his hand.🔽If it hits a tree or a post, and then falls outside,

original: Vātukkhittampi vā anto, sace patati rakkhati.
analyzed: vātukkhittam pi vā anto sace patati rakkhati
translated: or if it is thrown inside and falls outside, he keeps it.

original: Patitvā bhūmiyaṃ pacchā, vaṭṭantaṃ pana bhaṇḍakaṃ;
analyzed: patitvā bhūmiyam pacchā vaṭṭantam pana bhaṇḍakam
translated: But if the goods fall on the ground and roll out,

original: Sace pavisatyantova, tassa pārājikaṃ siyā.🔽Ṭhatvā ṭhatvā pavaṭṭantaṃ, paviṭṭhaṃ ce parājayo;
analyzed: sace tassa pārājikam siyā  ṭhatvā ṭhatvā pavaṭṭantam paviṭṭham ce parājayaḥ
translated: and if they enter inside, he commits an offense entailing expulsion.🔽If he stands and watches it rolling, and it enters inside, he loses it.

original: Atiṭṭhamānaṃ vaṭṭitvā, paviṭṭhaṃ pana rakkhati.🔽Iti vuttaṃ daḷhaṃ katvā, kurundaṭṭhakathādisu;
analyzed: a tiṭṭhamānam vaṭṭitvā paviṭṭham pana rakkhati  iti vuttam daḷham katvā kurunda ṭṭhakathā ādisu
translated: But if he stands and watches it rolling, and it enters inside while he is still standing, he keeps it.🔽Having understood this firmly,

original: Sārato taṃ gahetabbaṃ, yuttaṃ viya ca dissati.
analyzed: sārataḥ tam gahetabbam yuttam viya ca dissati
translated: one should understand it well, as it is appropriate, in the stories of the Kurara Pond and so on.

original: Sayaṃ vā yadi vaṭṭeti, vaṭṭāpeti parena vā;
analyzed: sayam vā yadi vaṭṭeti vaṭṭāpa iti parena vā
translated: If he rolls it himself or he has it rolled,

original: Aṭṭhatvā vaṭṭamānaṃ taṃ, gataṃ nāsakaraṃ siyā.🔽Ṭhatvā ṭhatvā sace anto, bahi gacchati rakkhati;
analyzed: a ṭhatvā vaṭṭamānam tam gatam nāsa karam siyā  ṭhatvā ṭhatvā sace antar bahi gacchati rakkhati
translated: and it rolls without stopping, it is not to be given up.🔽But if he stands and watches it rolling, and it goes outside, he keeps it.

analyzed: ṭhapite suddha cittena sayam vaṭṭati vaṭṭati
translated: If he stands and watches it rolling, and it rolls inside while he is still standing, he keeps it.

original: Gacchante pana yāne vā, gaje vā taṃ ṭhapeti ce;
analyzed: gacchante pana yāne vā gaje vā tam ce
translated: If he puts it down while the vehicle or the elephant is moving,

original: Bahi nīharaṇatthāya, nāvahāropi nīhaṭe.🔽Ṭhapite ṭhitayāne vā, payogena vinā gate;🔽Satipi theyyacittasmiṃ, avahāro na vijjati.
analyzed: bahi nīharaṇa tthāya na avahāraḥ api nīhaṭe  ṭhapite ṭhita yāne vā payogena vinā gate  theyya cittasmin avahāraḥ na vijjati
translated: and if it is taken away for the purpose of taking it outside, there is no offense for the one who takes it.🔽If he puts it down while the vehicle is standing still,🔽and it moves off without his effort, there is no offense for the one who takes it, even though he has the intention to steal.

original: Sace pājeti taṃ yānaṃ, ṭhapetvā yānake maṇiṃ;
analyzed: sace pājā iti tam yānam ṭhapetvā yānake maṇim
translated: If he makes the vehicle move, but not the jewel,

original: Siyā pārājikaṃ tassa, sīmātikkamane pana.🔽Suṅkaṭṭhāne mataṃ suṅkaṃ, gantuṃ datvāva vaṭṭati;
analyzed: siyā pārājikam tassa sīmā atikkamane pana  suṅka ṭṭhāne matam suṅkam gantum vaṭṭati
translated: there is an offense entailing expulsion if the vehicle crosses the boundary.🔽If the goods are in a shop, and the goods are dead,

analyzed: sesaḥ idha kathā maggaḥ araññaṭṭhakathā samo
translated: it is allowable to go after giving notice. The rest of the discussion here is the same as in the discussion of the wilderness.

original: Suṅkaghātakathā.🔽Antojātaṃ dhanakkītaṃ, dinnaṃ vā pana kenaci;
analyzed: suṅka ghāta kathā  antar jātam dhanakkītam dinnam vā pana kenacid
translated: The discussion of shopkeepers.🔽If he steals a slave who is born in the house, who has been bought with money,

analyzed: dāsam karamara ānītam harantassa parājayaḥ
translated: who has been given by someone, or who has been brought by a hired man, there is expulsion.

original: Bhujissaṃ vā harantassa, mānusaṃ mātarāpi vā;
analyzed: bhujissam vā harantassa mānusam mātarā api vā
translated: If he steals a slave who is a hired worker, or a human being, even if it is his mother,

original: Pitarāṭhapitaṃ vāpi, avahāro na vijjati.🔽Taṃ palāpetukāmova, ukkhipitvā bhujehi vā;🔽Taṃ ṭhitaṭṭhānato kiñci, saṅkāmeti parājayo.
analyzed: vā api avahāraḥ na vijjati  tam ukkhipitvā bhujehi vā  tam ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ kiñci saṅkāmeti parājayaḥ
translated: or his father, or his father’s wife, there is no offense for the one who takes him.🔽If he wants to make him run away, and he lifts him up with his arms,🔽and he moves him from the place where he is standing, there is expulsion.

analyzed: tat jetvā padasā dāsam nentassa pada vārataḥ
translated: If he threatens a slave with his feet, and he makes him go, then for each step there is an offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: honti āpattiyaḥ vuttā tassa thullaccaya ādayaḥ
translated: There are offenses that are mentioned, For him, serious offenses, and so on.

original: Hatthādīsu gahetvā taṃ, kaḍḍhatopi parājayo;🔽“Gaccha yāhi palāyā”ti, vadatopi ayaṃ nayo.
analyzed: hattha ādīsu gahetvā tam parājayaḥ  gaccha yāhi palāyāti ayam ayam
translated: If he seizes him by the hand, etc., and drags him away, there is also defeat.🔽If he says, “Go away! Go! Run away!” this rule is also applicable.

analyzed: palāyantam palāyāti ca
translated: If he runs away on his own initiative, and if he says, “Run away!”

original: Hoti pārājikenassa, anāpatti hi bhikkhuno.🔽Saṇikaṃ pana gacchantaṃ, sace vadati sopi ca;
analyzed: hoti pārājikenassa anāpatti hi bhikkhuno  saṇikam pana gacchantam sace vadati saḥ upi ca
translated: There is an offense entailing suspension for him, but no offense for the monk.🔽But if he is walking slowly, and if he says,

original: Sīghaṃ gacchati ce tassa, vacanena parājayo.
analyzed: sīgham gacchati ce tassa vacanena parājayaḥ
translated: and if he goes quickly, there is defeat for him because of his statement.

original: Palāyitvā sace aññaṃ, gāmaṃ vā nigamampi vā;
analyzed: palāyitvā sace aññam gāmam vā nigamam pi vā
translated: If he runs away and then goes to another village or town,

original: Gataṃ disvā tato tañce, palāpeti parājayo.
analyzed: gatam disvā palāpa iti
translated: and if he sees him there and then makes him run away, there is defeat.

analyzed: pāṇa kathā
translated: The section on snakes.

analyzed: theyyā sa pakaraṇḍam ce parāmasati dukkaṭaṃ
translated: If he touches a basket with a snake in it, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: phandā apeti yathāvatthum ṭhānataḥ cāvane cutaḥ
translated: If he makes it move, there is an offense entailing suspension, according to the object.

analyzed: ugghāṭetvā karaṇḍam tu sappam uddharataḥ pana
translated: But if he opens the basket and takes out the snake,

analyzed: karaṇḍa talataḥ mutte naṅguṭṭhe tu parājayaḥ
translated: there is defeat when the snake’s head is free from the basket.

analyzed: ghaṃsitvā sappam naṅguṭṭhe mukha vaṭṭitaḥ
translated: If he squeezes the snake and pulls it out, from the head or the neck,

analyzed: tassa sa pakaraṇḍassa mutta matte parājayaḥ
translated: there is defeat when the snake is completely out of the basket.

analyzed: karaṇḍam vivaritvā ce pakkosantassa nāmataḥ
translated: If he opens the box, and the snake comes out when he calls out the name,

original: So nikkhamati ce sappo, tassa pārājikaṃ siyā.
analyzed: saḥ nikkhamati ce sappo tassa pārājikam siyā
translated: then there is an offense entailing expulsion for him.

original: Tathā katvā tu maṇḍūka-mūsikānaṃ ravampi vā;
analyzed: tathā katvā tu vā
translated: And in the same way, if he does the same thing with a frog or a mouse,

analyzed: pakkosantassa nāmena nikkhante pi parājayaḥ
translated: then there is an offense entailing expulsion for him if it comes out when he calls out the name.

analyzed: mukham karontaḥ sevam eva ca
translated: But if he does it without opening his mouth,

original: Yena kenaci nikkhante, sappe pārājikaṃ siyā.
analyzed: yena kenacid nikkhante sappe pārājikam siyā
translated: then there is an offense entailing expulsion for him if the snake comes out in any way.

analyzed: mukhe vivarite sappaḥ sayam eva palāyati
translated: But if the snake escapes by itself after he has opened his mouth,🔽and he does not call it out,

analyzed: na pakkosati ce tassa bhaṇḍadeyyam udīritam
translated: then it is declared to be a case of “worth of being thrown out”.

analyzed: a pada kathā
translated: The section on non-venomous animals.

analyzed: theyya cittena yaḥ hatthim
translated: If someone with the intention to steal makes an elephant, a horse, a buffalo, a bull, an ox, a gayal, a deer, a goat, or a sheep disappear,

original: Honti āpattiyo tassa, tividhā dukkaṭādayo.🔽Sālāyaṃ ṭhitahatthissa, antovatthaṅgaṇesupi;
analyzed: honti āpattiyaḥ tassa tividhāḥ dukkaṭa ādayaḥ  sālāyam ṭhita hatthissa antar vattha aṅgaṇesu pi
translated: he commits an offense that is serious, that is a very grave offense, or that is an offense entailing expulsion.🔽The elephant’s place is the building, the courtyard, and the area where it is tethered.

original: Ṭhānaṃ sālā ca vatthu ca, aṅgaṇaṃ sakalaṃ siyā.
analyzed: ṭhānam sālā ca vatthu ca aṅgaṇam sakalam siyā
translated: The building and the area where it is tethered are the site.

analyzed: abaddhassa hi baddhassa ṭhita ṭṭhānam ca bandhanam
translated: The area where it is tethered and the tethering post are the support.

original: Tasmā tesaṃ vasā hatthiṃ, harato kāraye budho.
analyzed: tasmā tesam vasā hatthim harataḥ kāraye budhaḥ
translated: Therefore, a wise person should make the elephant disappear in the presence of the owner.

original: Nagarassa bahiddhā tu, ṭhitassa pana hatthino;
analyzed: nagarassa bahiddhā tu ṭhitassa pana hatthino
translated: But if the elephant is outside the town,

analyzed: ṭhita ṭṭhānam bhave ṭhānam pada vārena kāraye
translated: The place where it stands still is the place where it is. He should make it go by the step.

original: Nipannassa gajassekaṃ, ṭhānaṃ taṃ uṭṭhapeti ce;
analyzed: nipannassa gajassa ikam ṭhānam tam uṭṭhapeti ce
translated: If he makes it get up from the place where it is lying down,

original: Tasmiṃ uṭṭhitamatte tu, tassa pārājikaṃ siyā.
analyzed: tasmin uṭṭhita matte tu tassa pārājikam siyā
translated: then as soon as it has got up, there is an offense entailing expulsion for him.

analyzed: ca nayaḥ ñeyyaḥ turaṅga mahisa ādisu
translated: This is the same method to be understood in the case of horses and oxen,

analyzed: natthi kiñci pi vattabbam dvipade pi bahuppade
translated: and there is nothing to be said in the case of bipeds and quadrupeds.

analyzed: catuppada kathā
translated: The discussion of quadrupeds.

analyzed: vijānitvā paresam santakam dhanam
translated: Having recognized the property of others as such,

original: Garukaṃ theyyacittena, ṭhānā cāveti ce cuto.
analyzed: garukam theyya cittena ṭhānā ca aveti ce cuto
translated: if he moves the heavy one with the intention to steal it, he is expelled.

original: Anāpatti sasaññissa, tiracchānapariggahe;🔽Tāvakālikavissāsa-ggāhe petapariggahe.🔽Yo panettha ca vattabbo, pāḷimuttavinicchayo;🔽Taṃ mayaṃ paratoyeva, bhaṇissāma pakiṇṇake.
analyzed: anāpatti sa saññissa tiracchāna pariggahe  tāvakālika vissāsa ggāhe peta pariggahe  yaḥ pana ittha ca vattabbaḥ pāḷimutta vinicchayaḥ  tam mayam paratoyā iva bhaṇissāma pakiṇṇake
translated: There is no offense if he perceives it as his own, or it is the property of animals,🔽or it is a temporary borrowing, or it is the property of a ghost.🔽But what should be said here, the decision beyond the text,

analyzed: parājita aneka malena vuttam  pārājikam yam dutiyam jinena
translated: we will speak of only in the appendix.

analyzed: vuttaḥ samāsena mayassa ca atthaḥ
translated: The second offense entailing expulsion spoken of by the Victor with many terms,🔽the meaning of which I have stated in brief,

analyzed: vattum asesena hi kaḥ samatthaḥ
translated: who is able to state it in full?

analyzed: iti vinaya vinicchaye dutiya pārājika kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The discussion of the second offense entailing expulsion in the Vinaya-mātṛkā is finished.

analyzed: tatiya pārājika kathā
translated: The discussion of the third offense entailing expulsion

original: Manussajātiṃ jānanto, jīvitā yo viyojaye;🔽Nikkhipeyyassa satthaṃ vā, vadeyya maraṇe guṇaṃ.
analyzed: manussa jātim jānantaḥ jīvitā yaḥ viyojaye  nikkhipeyyassa sattham vā vadeyya maraṇe guṇam
translated: Knowing that it is a human being, if he should deprive him of life,🔽He might place a knife on him, or speak of the virtue in death.

analyzed: deseyya maraṇūpāyam hotā ayam pi parājitaḥ
translated: He might teach a method of dying, even if he is the supporter, he is defeated;

original: Asandheyyova so ñeyyo, dvedhā bhinnasilā viya.
analyzed: asandheyyā uva saḥ ñeyyaḥ dvedhā bhinna silā
translated: He should be known as one who cannot be reconciled, like a stone split in two.

analyzed: vuttā pāṇātipātassa payogā cha mahesinā
translated: The six kinds of effort in killing a living being were stated by the Great Sage;

analyzed: sāhatthikaḥ tathā āṇatti nissaggi thāvara ādayaḥ
translated: With one’s own hand, and likewise instigation, sending, and the lowest, etc.

original: Tattha kāyena vā kāya-paṭibaddhena vā sayaṃ;
analyzed: tattha kāyena vā kāya paṭibaddhena vā sayam
translated: There, either with one’s own body or with what is connected to the body, oneself;

original: Mārentassa paraṃ ghāto, ayaṃ sāhatthiko mato.
analyzed: mārentassa param ghātaḥ ayam sāhatthikaḥ mato
translated: The killing of another is called with one’s own hand.

original: “Evaṃ tvaṃ paharitvā taṃ, mārehī”ti ca bhikkhuno;
analyzed: evam tvam paharitvā tam mārehi iti ca bhikkhunaḥ
translated: “Thus you should strike him and kill him,” and to a monk;

analyzed: parassāṇāpanam nāma ayam āṇattikaḥ nayaḥ
translated: The instigation of another is called the method of instigation.

analyzed: dūram māretu kāmassa usu ādi nipātanam
translated: For one who wishes to kill at a distance, the hurling of a stone, etc.;

analyzed: kāyena paṭibaddhena ayam nissaggiyaḥ vidhi
translated: With what is connected to the body, this is the method of sending.

analyzed: asañcārim upāyena māraṇa attham parassa ca
translated: By means of a non-moving method, for the purpose of killing another;

analyzed: tu payogaḥ thāvaraḥ ayam
translated: The laying of a trap, etc., however, is the effort of the lowest.

analyzed: param māretu kāmassa vijjāya jappanam pana
translated: For one who wishes to kill another, the reciting of a spell, however,

original: Ayaṃ vijjāmayo nāma, payogo pañcamo mato.
analyzed: ayam vijjāmayaḥ nāma payogaḥ pañcamaḥ mataḥ
translated: This is called the spell-effort, the fifth kind of effort is considered.

original: Samatthā māraṇe yā ca, iddhi kammavipākajā;
analyzed: samatthā māraṇe yā ca iddhi kamma vipāka jā
translated: And that success in killing, and the supernormal power, born of kamma’s result,

original: Ayamiddhimayo nāma, payogo samudīrito.🔽Ekeko duvidho tattha, hotīti paridīpito;
analyzed: ayam iddhi mayaḥ nāma payogaḥ samudīrito  ekekaḥ duvidhaḥ tattha hoti iti paridīpito
translated: This is called the “power kind”🔽Of the means, which is proclaimed.🔽Each of them is shown as twofold

analyzed: uddesaḥ api anuddesaḥ bhedo pana
translated: There, and this is their analysis.

original: Bahusvapi yamuddissa, pahāraṃ deti ce pana;
analyzed: bahusu api yam uddissa pahāram deti ce pana
translated: If he aims at many and strikes one,

original: Maraṇena ca tasseva, kammunā tena bajjhati.
analyzed: maraṇena ca tassa iva kammunā tena bajjhati
translated: He is guilty of the offence of killing only the one he aimed at.

analyzed: an uddissa pahāre pi yassa kassaci dehinaḥ
translated: If he aims at no one in particular,🔽And strikes some being or other,🔽If the latter dies, he is guilty

analyzed: pahāra ppaccayā tassa maraṇam ce parājayo
translated: Of the offence of killing that being.🔽If he strikes one who dies afterwards,

original: Mate pahaṭamatte vā, pacchā mubhayathāpi ca;
analyzed: mate pahaṭa matte vā pacchā ca
translated: Or both die simultaneously,🔽The striker is guilty of the offence

analyzed: hantā pahaṭa mattasmim kammunā tena bajjhati
translated: As soon as he has struck.

original: Evaṃ sāhatthiko ñeyyo, tathā āṇattikopi ca;
analyzed: evam sāhatthikaḥ ñeyyaḥ tathā āṇattikaḥ api ca
translated: So too with the “at his instruction” kind.🔽Thus far the two kinds of means

original: Ettāvatā samāsena, dve payogā hi dassitā.
analyzed: ettāvatā samāsena dve payogā hi dassitā
translated: Have been shown in brief.🔽The basis, the time, the place,

original: Vatthu kālo ca deso ca, satthañca iriyāpatho;
analyzed: vatthu kālo ca deso ca satthañca iriyāpatho
translated: The weapon, the posture, and the manner🔽Of doing are the six determiners

analyzed: karaṇassa visesaḥ ti cha āṇatti niyāmakā
translated: Of the “at his instruction” kind.🔽The one who is to be killed there

original: Māretabbo hi yo tattha, so “vatthū”ti pavuccati;
analyzed: māretabbaḥ hi yaḥ tattha saḥ vatthu iti pavuccati
translated: Is called the “basis.”🔽The time may be morning, etc.,

original: Pubbaṇhādi siyā kālo, sattānaṃ yobbanādi ca.
analyzed: pubbaṇha ādi siyā kālaḥ sattānam yobbana ādi ca
translated: And the beings’ youth, and so on.

original: Deso gāmādi viññeyyo, satthaṃ taṃ sattamāraṇaṃ;
analyzed: desaḥ gāma ādi viññeyyaḥ sattham tam satta māraṇam
translated: The place should be known as a village, etc., The weapon is the one that kills the seven,

original: Māretabbassa sattassa, nisajjādiriyāpatho.🔽Vijjhanaṃ bhedanañcāpi, chedanaṃ tāḷanampi vā;
analyzed: māretabbassa sattassa  vijjhanam bhedanam ca api chedanam tāḷanam pi vā
translated: The being to be killed is the one who is to be killed, The posture, etc., are the method.🔽The killing, the cutting, the stabbing, the burning,

original: Evamādividhoneko, viseso karaṇassa tu.🔽“Yaṃ mārehī”ti āṇatto, aññaṃ māreti ce tato;🔽“Purato paharitvāna, mārehī”ti ca bhāsito.
analyzed: evamādi vidhaḥ na ekaḥ visesaḥ karaṇassa tu  yam mārehi iti āṇattaḥ aññam māreti ce tatas  puratas paharitvāna mārehi iti ca bhāsitaḥ
translated: And so on are the different kinds of killing, But the difference in the action is this.🔽If one who is told “Kill this” kills another,🔽Or if one is told “Kill in front” and kills one behind,

original: Pacchato passato vāpi, paharitvāna mārite;🔽Vatthāṇatti visaṅketā, mūlaṭṭho pana muccati.
analyzed: pacchatas passatas vā api paharitvāna mārite  visaṅketā mūla ṭṭhaḥ pana muccati
translated: Or if one is told “Kill one who is looking” and kills one who is not looking,🔽The place, the posture, the signal, the root meaning are not fulfilled.🔽If one kills without abandoning the place,

analyzed: vatthum tam a virajjhitvā yathā āṇattim ca mārite
translated: And as the posture was, and as the signal,

analyzed: ubhayesam yathākālam kammabaddhaḥ udīritaḥ
translated: The bond of action is declared for both, according to the time.

original: Āṇatto “ajja pubbaṇhe, mārehī”ti ca yo pana;🔽So ce māreti sāyanhe, mūlaṭṭho parimuccati.
analyzed: āṇattaḥ ajja pubbaṇhe mārehi iti ca yaḥ pana  saḥ ce māreti sāyanhe mūlaṭṭhaḥ parimuccati
translated: If one is told “Kill in the morning” and kills in the evening,🔽The root meaning is fulfilled,🔽But it is said that the bond of action

analyzed: āṇattassa iva saḥ vutto  kamma baddhaḥ mahesinā
translated: Is for the one who was told.

analyzed: kālassa hi visaṅketā
translated: Because of the difference in the signal of the time,

analyzed: dosaḥ nāṇāpakassa so
translated: The fault is not the same for the one who was told.

analyzed: ajja mārehi pubbaṇhe su eva ati a niyāmite
translated: If one is told “Kill in the morning today, tomorrow in the evening,” without a fixed time,

original: Yadā kadāci pubbaṇhe, visaṅketo na mārite.
analyzed: yadā kadāci pubbaṇhe visaṅketaḥ na mārite
translated: Sometimes in the morning, if the doubt is not killed.

analyzed: etena iva upāyena kāla bhedesu sabbaso
translated: In this way, in all the divisions of time,

analyzed: saṅketaḥ ca visaṅketaḥ veditabbaḥ vibhāvinā
translated: The learned one should know the difference between the doubt and the killing of the doubt.

original: “Imaṃ gāme ṭhitaṃ veriṃ, mārehī”ti ca bhāsito;
analyzed: imam gāme ṭhitam verim mārehi iti ca
translated: “Kill the enemy who is in this village,” if he is told,

original: Sace so pana māreti, ṭhitaṃ taṃ yattha katthaci.
analyzed: sace saḥ pana māreti ṭhitam tam yattha katthaci
translated: If he kills him, he is guilty wherever he is.

original: Natthi tassa visaṅketo, ubho bajjhanti kammunā;🔽“Gāmeyevā”ti āṇatto, vane vā sāvadhāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: natthi tassa visaṅketaḥ ubho bajjhanti kammunā  āṇattaḥ vane vā sa avadhāraṇam
translated: There is no doubt about it, both are guilty by the action.🔽If he is told, “In the village only,” or “In the forest,”

original: “Vaneyevā”ti vā vutto, gāme māreti cepi vā;
analyzed: vaneyā iva iti vā vuttaḥ gāme māreti vā
translated: Or if he is told, “In the forest only,” if he kills in the village,

analyzed: visaṅketaḥ viññātabbaḥ mūlaṭṭhaḥ parimuccati
translated: The doubt should be known, the root is free.

analyzed: etena iva upāyena sabba desesu bhedato
translated: In this way, in all the directions, by the divisions,

analyzed: saṅketo ca visaṅketo veditabbaḥ uva viññunā
translated: The learned one should know the difference between the doubt and the killing of the doubt.

analyzed: satthena pana mārehi āṇatto ti ca kenaci
translated: “But kill with a weapon,” if he is told by someone,

original: Yena kenaci satthena, visaṅketo na mārite.
analyzed: yena kenacid satthena visaṅketaḥ na mārite
translated: With whatever weapon, if the doubt is not killed.

analyzed: iminā vāsinā hi iti vuttaḥ aññena vāsinā
translated: “With this sword,” if he is told, with another sword,

analyzed: vā api tvam māraya
translated: “Or with this sword, you should kill him with this blade.”

original: Iti vutto sace veriṃ, dhārāya itarāya vā;
analyzed: iti vuttaḥ sace verim dhārāya itarāya vā
translated: If he is told, if he kills the enemy with that blade or another,

analyzed: tharunā vā api tuṇḍena mārite
translated: But if the other kills him with a blow, there is no offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: etena iva upāyena sabbāvudhaka jātisu
translated: In the same way, in the case of all weapons and all kinds of killing,

analyzed: saṅketaḥ ca visaṅketaḥ veditabbaḥ visesataḥ
translated: the distinction between “with an appointment” and “without an appointment” should be understood.

analyzed: gacchantam enam mārehi iti vuttaḥ parena so
translated: If the other is told, “Kill him while he is walking,”

original: Māreti naṃ nisinnaṃ ce, visaṅketo na vijjati.🔽“Nisinnaṃyeva mārehi”, “gacchantaṃyeva vā”ti ca;
analyzed: mā āreti nam nisinnam ced visaṅketaḥ na vijjati  nisinnaṃyā iva mā ārehi gacchantaṃyā iva vāti ca
translated: and he kills him while sitting, there is no offense entailing expulsion.🔽If the other is told, “Kill him while sitting,” or “Kill him while walking,”

original: Vutto māreti gacchantaṃ, nisinnaṃ vā yathākkamaṃ.
analyzed: vuttaḥ mā āreti gacchantam nisinnam vā yathākkamam
translated: and he kills him while walking or sitting,

analyzed: visaṅketam ti ñātabbam bhikkhunā vinaya ññunā
translated: then the monk who knows the Monastic Law should understand that there is no offense entailing expulsion.

original: Eseva ca nayo ñeyyo, sabbiriyāpathesu ca.
analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ ñeyyaḥ sat viriyāpathesu ca
translated: This is the method to be understood in all the modes of action.

original: “Mārehī”ti ca vijjhitvā, āṇatto hi parena so;
analyzed: mārehi iti ca vijjhitvā āṇattaḥ hi parena so
translated: If the other is told, “Kill him after stabbing him,”

analyzed: vijjhitvā ava tam āreti visaṅketaḥ na vijjati
translated: and he kills him after stabbing him, there is no offense entailing expulsion.

original: “Mārehī”ti ca vijjhitvā, āṇatto hi parena so;
analyzed: mārehi iti ca vijjhitvā āṇattaḥ hi parena so
translated: If the other is told, “Kill him after stabbing him,”

original: Chinditvā yadi māreti, visaṅketova hoti so.
analyzed: chinditvā yadi mā āreti visaṅketaḥ uva hoti saḥ
translated: and he kills him after cutting him, there is an offense entailing expulsion.

analyzed: etena iva upāyena sabbesu karaṇesu pi
translated: In the same way, in the case of all instruments,

analyzed: saṅkete ca visaṅkete veditabbaḥ vinicchayaḥ
translated: the distinction between “with an appointment” and “without an appointment” should be understood.

original: Dīghaṃ rassaṃ kisaṃ thūlaṃ, kāḷaṃ odātameva vā;
analyzed: dīgham rassam kisam thūlam kāḷam odātam eva vā
translated: Long, short, thin, fat, dark, or fair,

analyzed: āṇattaḥ mārehi iti ca kenacid
translated: Or someone orders, “Without examining, kill!”

original: Sopi yaṃ kiñci āṇatto, sace māreti tādisaṃ;
analyzed: saḥ api yam kiñci āṇattaḥ sace māreti tādisam
translated: If he kills someone like that,

analyzed: natthi tattha visaṅketaḥ ubhinnam pi parājayaḥ
translated: There’s no doubt: he’s expelled for both.🔽If someone orders, “Dig a pitfall,”

original: Manussaṃ kiñci uddissa, sace khaṇativāṭakaṃ;🔽Khaṇantassa ca opātaṃ, hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: manussam kiñci uddissa sace khaṇa tivāṭakam  khaṇantassa ca opātam hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ
translated: And he digs it for any human,🔽Then there’s an offense of wrong conduct🔽For digging the pitfall.🔽If someone dies because of the pain,

analyzed: dukkha ssuppattiyā tattha tassa thullaccayam siyā
translated: There’s a serious offense for him.🔽But if that person falls in and dies,

original: Patitvā ca mate tasmiṃ, tassa pārājikaṃ bhave.🔽Nipatitvā panaññasmiṃ, mate doso na vijjati;
analyzed: patitvā ca mate tasmin tassa pārājikam bhave  nipatitvā pana aññasmin mate doso na vijjati
translated: He’s expelled.🔽But if someone else falls in and dies,🔽There’s no offense for him.

analyzed: an uddissa kamā upātaḥ khataḥ hoti sace pana
translated: If he digs a pitfall without aiming at anyone in particular,

original: “Patitvā ettha yo koci, maratū”ti hi yattakā;
analyzed: patitvā ettha yaḥ koci maratu uti hi yattakā
translated: But if he says, “Whoever falls in here will die,”🔽And if someone dies by falling in,

original: Maranti nipatitvā ce, dosā hontissa tattakā.
analyzed: maranti nipatitvā ce dosāḥ honti tattakā
translated: There’s an offense for him.🔽In the case of the immediate offenses,

analyzed: ānantariya vatthusmim ānantariyakam vade
translated: Say the immediate offenses;🔽So too for the serious offenses, etc.,

analyzed: tathā thullaccaya ādīnam honti thullaccaya ādayaḥ
translated: There are serious offenses, etc.🔽If a pregnant woman falls in,

original: Patitvā gabbhinī tasmiṃ, sagabbhā ce marissati;
analyzed: patitvā gabbhinī tasmin sa gabbhā ce marissati
translated: And if she miscarries,

original: Honti pāṇātipātā dve, ekovekekadhaṃsane.🔽Anubandhettha corehi, patitvā ce marissati;
analyzed: honti pāṇa atipātāḥ dve  anubandha ittha corehi patitvā ce marissati
translated: There are two kinds of living beings: those that move about and those that don’t.🔽If one is followed by thieves, and if one dies after falling into a pit,

original: Opātakhaṇakasseva, hoti pārājikaṃ kira.🔽Verino tattha pātetvā, sace mārenti verino;
analyzed: opāta khaṇakassa iva hoti pārājikam kira  verino tattha pātetvā sace mārenti verino
translated: then it seems that one commits an offense entailing expulsion for killing an animal.🔽If one throws an enemy into a pit, and if the enemy kills the enemy,

original: Patitaṃ tattha mārenti, nīharitvā sace bahi.🔽Nibbattitvā hi opāte, matā ce opapātikā;
analyzed: patitam nīharitvā sace bahi  nibbattitvā hi opāte matā ce opapātikā
translated: or if one throws an enemy into a pit, and if the enemy dies after being pulled out,🔽or if the enemy dies after being born in the pit,

original: Asakkontā ca nikkhantuṃ, sabbattha ca parājayo.🔽Yakkhādayo panuddissa, khaṇane dukkhasambhave;
analyzed: a sakkontā ca nikkhantum sabbattha ca parājayaḥ  yakkha ādayaḥ pan uddissa khaṇane dukkha sambhave
translated: or if the enemy dies because of being unable to get out, then in all these cases there is an offense entailing expulsion.🔽If one digs a pit with the aim of killing non-human beings, and if suffering arises,

analyzed: dukkaṭam maraṇe vatthu vasā thullaccaya ādayaḥ
translated: then there is an offense of wrong conduct. If the being dies, the offense is serious.

analyzed: manussā iya iva uddissa khate opātake pana
translated: But if one digs a pit with the aim of killing only human beings,

analyzed: anāpatti patitvā hi yakkha ādīsu matesu pi
translated: then there is no offense if the non-human being dies after falling into it.

original: Tathā yakkhādayo pāṇe, khate uddissa bhikkhunā;
analyzed: tathā yakkha ādayaḥ pāṇe khate uddissa bhikkhunā
translated: In the same way, if a monk digs a pit with the aim of killing non-human beings,

original: Nipatitvā marantesu, manussesupyayaṃ nayo.🔽“Pāṇino ettha bajjhitvā, marantū”ti anuddisaṃ;
analyzed: nipatitvā marantesu manussesu pi ayam nayaḥ  pāṇinaḥ ettha bajjhitvā marantu iti anuddisam
translated: and if a human being dies after falling into it, the same method applies.

original: Pāsaṃ oḍḍeti yo tattha, sace bajjhanti pāṇino.
analyzed: pāsam oḍḍeti yaḥ tattha sace bajjhanti pāṇinaḥ
translated: If one sets a snare without aiming it at any particular being,🔽and if a living being gets caught in it,

analyzed: hatthataḥ mutta mattasmin tassa pārājikam siyā
translated: As soon as it is released from the hand, there is an offense entailing expulsion for him.

original: Ānantariyavatthusmiṃ, ānantariyameva ca.🔽Uddissa hi kate pāse, yaṃ panuddissa oḍḍito;
analyzed: ānantariya vatthusmin ānantariyam eva ca  uddissa hi kate pāse yam panuddissa oḍḍitaḥ
translated: In the case of the immediate offenses, there is an immediate offense.

analyzed: bandhanesu tad aññesam anāpatti pakāsitā
translated: In the case of a snare that has been set out on purpose, there is no offense for anyone else who catches whatever it was that the snare was set out for.

original: Mūlena vā mudhā vāpi, dinne pāse parassa hi;
analyzed: mūlena vā mudhā vā api dinne pāse parassa hi
translated: If a snare has been set out by someone else, whether by the root or by fraud,

analyzed: mūla ṭṭhassa iva hoti iti kamma baddhaḥ niyāmitaḥ
translated: then the one who set it out is bound by the action, is tied to it.

original: Yena laddho sace lopi, pāsamuggaḷitampi vā;
analyzed: yena laddhaḥ sace vā
translated: If the owner of the snare, whether it is closed or open,

analyzed: thiram vā api karota iva kamma bandhanam
translated: or if he makes it firm in this way, then both are bound by the action.

original: Yo pāsaṃ uggaḷāpetvā, yāti pāpabhayā sace;
analyzed: yaḥ pāsam uggaḷāpetvā yāti pāpa bhayā sace
translated: If someone opens a snare and leaves because of fear of wrongdoing,

original: Taṃ disvā puna aññopi, saṇṭhapeti hi tattha ca.
analyzed: tam disvā puna aññaḥ api saṇṭhapeti hi tattha ca
translated: and then someone else sees it and sets it up again there,

original: Baddhā baddhā maranti ce, mūlaṭṭho na ca muccati;
analyzed: baddhāḥ baddhāḥ maranti ce mūlaṭṭhaḥ na ca muccati
translated: and if those caught in it die, the one who set it out is not released.

analyzed: ṭhapetvā gahita ṭṭhāne pāsa yaṭṭhim vimuccati
translated: Except for the place where it was caught, he is released from the snare.

original: Gopetvāpi na mokkho hi, pāsayaṭṭhiṃ sayaṃkataṃ;
analyzed: gopetvā api na mokkhaḥ hi pāsa yaṭṭhim sayaṃkatam
translated: But there is no release for one who guards it, for the snare that he made himself.

original: Tamañño puna gaṇhitvā, saṇṭhapeti sace pana.
analyzed: tam aññaḥ puna gaṇhitvā saṇṭhapeti sace pana
translated: If another catches it and sets it up again,

original: Tappaccayā marantesu, mūlaṭṭho na ca muccati;
analyzed: tad paccayā marantesu mūlaṭṭhaḥ na ca muccati
translated: and if those who depend on it die, the one who set it out is not released.

original: Nāsetvā sabbaso vā taṃ, jhāpetvā vā vimuccati.
analyzed: nāsetvā sabbasas vā tam jhāpetvā vā vimuccati
translated: Or, having completely removed it, Or having burned it, he is free.

original: Ropentassa ca sūlaṃ vā, sajjentassa adūhalaṃ;🔽Opātena ca pāsena, sadisova vinicchayo.🔽Anāpatti asañcicca, ajānantassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: ropentassa ca sūlam vā sajjentassa adūhalam  opātena ca pāsena sadisā uva vinicchayo  anāpatti a sañcicca a jānantassa bhikkhuno
translated: For one who plants a stake, Or who sets a trap, Or with a snare, The decision is the same.

analyzed: tathā amaraṇa cittassa mate pi ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: There is no offense if it is unintentional, If the monk does not know, If he does not have the thought to kill, If the person dies after he has recovered from his madness, and so on.

analyzed: manussa pāṇimhi ca pāṇa saññi tā  sacassa cittam maraṇa upasaṃhitam
translated: If it is a human being, and he perceives it as such;🔽If his mind is bent on death;

analyzed: upakkamaḥ tena ca tassa nāsaḥ
translated: If he makes an effort, and the other dies because of it;

analyzed: pañca ittha aṅgāni manussa ghāte
translated: Then there are five factors in killing a human being.

analyzed: iti vinaya vinicchaye tatiya pārājika kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The section on the third offense entailing expulsion in the Khandhaka on the Monastic Law is finished.

analyzed: catuttha pārājika kathā  a santa mattaḥ sitam eva katvā
translated: The section on the fourth offense entailing expulsion🔽Having made it seem as if it does not exist,

analyzed: bhavam adhiṭṭhāya ca vattamānam
translated: And it is still existing, having determined it to be so,

original: Aññāpadesañca vinādhimānaṃ;🔽Jhānādibhedaṃ samudācareyya.🔽Kāyena vācāyapi vā tadatthe;
analyzed: aññā apadesam ca vinā adhimānam  jhāna ādi bhedam samudācareyya  vā tad atthe
translated: And having made a claim of knowledge,🔽One should declare it, having distinguished it as absorption, and so on.

original: Ñāteva viññattipathe abhabbo;🔽Yatheva tālo pana matthakasmiṃ;
analyzed: ñātā iva viññatti pathe abhabbaḥ  yathā iva matthakasmin
translated: By body or by speech, or by a means of communication that is ineffective,

analyzed: chinnaḥ abhabbo puna ruḷhi bhāve
translated: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth.

analyzed: a santam eva ttani yaḥ parassa
translated: If one who does not have any spiritual power

original: Dīpeti jhānādimanantaraṃ so;🔽Jānāti ce hoti cuto hi no ce;
analyzed: dīpa iti jhāna ādim anantaram saḥ  jānāti ce hoti cutaḥ hi no ce
translated: He shines forth, after the jhāna, etc.,🔽If he knows, there is a grave offense; if he does not know,

analyzed: jānāti thullaccayam assa hoti
translated: There is an offense entailing suspension.
