translated: Then if he takes it with a wet hand, it is allowable.

original: Sace iṭṭhakapākāro, yebhuyyakathale pana;🔽Ṭhāne tiṭṭhati so tasmā, vikopeyya yathāsukhaṃ.
analyzed: sace iṭṭhaka pā kāraḥ yebhuyyaka thale pana  ṭhāne tiṭṭhati saḥ tasmai vikopeyya yathāsukham
translated: If the rampart is made of bricks, and the greater part is on the ground,🔽Then it is earth, and he can dig it up as he likes.

original: Abbhokāse ṭhitaṃ thambhaṃ, cāletvā panito cito;
analyzed: abbhokāse ṭhitam thambham cāletvā panitaḥ citaḥ
translated: If he moves a post that is standing in an open space, and it is lifted up,

original: Pathaviṃ tu vikopetvā, gahetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: pathavim tu vikopetvā gahetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: Then he should not take the earth after digging it up.

original: Aññampi sukkharukkhaṃ vā, khāṇukaṃ vāpi gaṇhato;
analyzed: aññam pi sukkha rukkham vā khāṇukam vā api gaṇhato
translated: If he takes a dry tree or a log,

original: Ayameva nayo doso, ujumuddharato na ca.
analyzed: ayam eva nayaḥ dosaḥ ujum uddharataḥ na ca
translated: This is the same offence as before; if he takes it out straight, there is no offence.

original: Pāsāṇaṃ yadi vā rukkhaṃ, uccāletvā pavaṭṭati;
analyzed: pāsāṇam yadi vā rukkham uccāletvā pavaṭṭati
translated: If he moves a stone or a tree, and it rolls,

original: Na doso suddhacittassa, sace pathavi bhijjati.
analyzed: na dosaḥ suddha cittassa sace pathavi bhijjati
translated: There is no offence if the earth splits, if he is not aiming at the earth.

analyzed: dārūni sākhā ādīni ca
translated: If he breaks up even dry wood, Or pulls off branches and so on,

analyzed: ayam eva nayaḥ vuttaḥ bhūmiyam suddha cetasaḥ
translated: This very same method is stated For one with a pure mind on the ground.

original: Kaṇṭakaṃ sūcimaṭṭhiṃ vā, khilaṃ vā bhūmiyaṃ pana;
analyzed: kaṇṭakam sūcim aṭṭhim vā khilam vā pana
translated: A thorn, a needle, a bone, or a splinter On the ground,

original: Ākoṭetuṃ pavesetuṃ, bhikkhuno na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: ākoṭetum pavesetum bhikkhunaḥ na ca vaṭṭati
translated: It is not allowable for a monk To kick them or to tread on them.

analyzed: aham passa avadhārāya bhindissāmi iti medinim
translated: “I will break the earth For the sake of a urinal,”

original: Bhikkhussa pana passāva-mevaṃ kātuṃ na vaṭṭati.🔽Anāpatti karontassa, sace bhijjati medinī;
analyzed: bhikkhussa pana passāvam evam kātum na vaṭṭati  anāpatti karontassa sace bhijjati medinī
translated: It is not allowable for a monk To make a urinal in this way on the earth.🔽There is no offense if he is doing it And the earth breaks up;

original: Samajjato samaṃ kātuṃ, ghaṃsituṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: samajjataḥ samam kātum ghaṃsitum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: It is not allowable to make it level By beating it with the hands.

original: Pādaṅguṭṭhena vā bhūmiṃ, likhitumpi na vaṭṭati;
analyzed: pādaṅguṭṭhena vā bhūmim likhitum pi na vaṭṭati
translated: It is not allowable to draw on the ground With the big toe,

original: Bhindantena ca pādehi, tathā caṅkamitumpi vā.🔽Pathaviṃ allahatthena, chupitvā sukhumaṃ rajaṃ;
analyzed: bhindantena ca pādehi tathā vā  pathavim allahatthena chupitvā su khumam rajam
translated: Or to break it up with the feet, Or to walk about in the same way.🔽If he takes up fine dust, Having moistened the ground with his wet hand,

original: Aghaṃsanto gahetvā ce, hatthaṃ dhovati vaṭṭati.
analyzed: a ghaṃsantaḥ gahetvā ce hattham dhovati vaṭṭati
translated: And, shaking it off, washes his hand, it is allowable.

original: Sayaṃ dahati ce bhūmiṃ, dahāpeti parehi vā;
analyzed: sayam dahati ced bhūmim daha apa iti parehi vā
translated: If he himself burns the ground, Or he has it burned,

analyzed: pattam dahantassa api bhikkhuno
translated: The monk who is burning incurs an offense As soon as the fire reaches the ground.

original: Ṭhānesu yattakesvaggiṃ, deti dāpeti vā pana;
analyzed: ṭhānesu yattakesu aggim deti dāpeti vā pana
translated: If he gives or has given a fire In as many places as he likes,

analyzed: tattakāni eva bhikkhussa honti pācittiyāni pi
translated: Are the same for the monk, and so are the offenses entailing confession.

original: Ṭhapetuṃ bhikkhuno aggiṃ, bhūmiyaṃ na ca vaṭṭati;
analyzed: ṭhapetum bhikkhunaḥ aggim bhūmiyam na ca vaṭṭati
translated: It is not allowable for a monk to light a fire on the ground;

analyzed: kapāle pattapacane ṭhapetum pana vaṭṭati
translated: But it is allowable to light a fire on a potsherd or in a pan.

original: Aggiṃ upari dārūnaṃ, ṭhapetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati;
analyzed: aggim upari ṭhapetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: It is not allowable to place wood above the fire;

original: Dahanto tāni gantvā so, bhūmiṃ dahati ce pana.
analyzed: dahantaḥ tāni gantvā saḥ bhūmim dahati ced pana
translated: If it burns and the fire spreads to the ground,

analyzed: esa iva ca nayaḥ vutto iṭṭhaka āvāsaka ādisu
translated: This is the same as the rule given for the brick house, etc.;

analyzed: ṭhapetum iṭṭhaka ādīnam matthakesu eva vaṭṭati
translated: It is allowable to place the bricks, etc., only on the top.

original: Kasmā panāti ce? Tesa-manupādānabhāvato;🔽Khāṇuke sukkharukkhe vā, aggiṃ dātuṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: kasmā  khāṇuke sukkha rukkhe vā aggim dātum na vaṭṭati
translated: And why is that? Because they are not the support;🔽It is not allowable to put a fire on a log or a dry tree.

original: Anāpatti tiṇukkaṃ tu, gahetvā pana gacchato;🔽Ḍayhamāne tu hatthasmiṃ, sace pāteti bhūmiyaṃ.
analyzed: anāpatti tiṇukkam tu gahetvā pana gacchataḥ  ḍayhamāne tu hatthasmin sace pāta iti
translated: But there is no offense if he takes grass or sticks🔽And puts them on the ground if his hand is burning.🔽And if he puts the fire back in the place where it fell,

original: Puna taṃ patitaṭṭhāne, datvā tassa panindhanaṃ;
analyzed: puna tam patita ṭṭhāne da tvā tassa
translated: And then lights a fire using that as fuel,

analyzed: aggim vaṭṭati mahā paccariyam rutam
translated: It is allowable, so it is said in the Mahaapaccariya.

analyzed: pathavī iti ca saññino
translated: If he thinks that the place is not the ground,

analyzed: vimatiḥ ubhayatthā api dukkaṭam
translated: And if he is unsure of the danger, then too there is an offense.

analyzed: anāpatti imam jāne imam āhara dehi iti
translated: There’s no offense if he says, “Know this,” “Bring this,” “Give this”;

analyzed: vadantassa sa cittam ca ti samuṭṭhānam eva ca
translated: If he’s speaking with the right mind, and the three conditions are fulfilled.

analyzed: pathavī khaṇana kathā
translated: The discussion of digging the earth.

analyzed: musāvāda vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on lying is finished.

original: Bhavantassa ca bhūtassa, bhūtagāmassa bhikkhuno;🔽Pātabyatānimittaṃ tu, pācittiyamudīritaṃ.
analyzed: bhavantassa ca bhūtassa bhūtagāmassa bhikkhuno  pātabya tā nimittam tu pācittiyam udīritam
translated: For one who is, and for one who is not, a spirit; for a monk,🔽And for one who is not sure of the sign; the offense entailing confession is announced.

original: Udakaṭṭho thalaṭṭhoti, duvidho hoti so pana;
analyzed: udaka ṭṭho thala ṭṭho ti duvidhaḥ hoti saḥ pana
translated: It is of two kinds: in water and on land.

analyzed: tila bīja ādikaḥ tattha sa paṇṇaḥ api apaṇṇako
translated: Therein, sesame seeds, rice, etc., are with husk or without husk.

analyzed: udakaṭṭho ti viññeyyaḥ sabbaḥ sevāla jātiko
translated: All that grows in water should be understood as being in water;

original: Vikopentassa taṃ sabbaṃ, tassa pācittiyaṃ siyā.
analyzed: vikopentassa tat sabbam tassa pācittiyam siyā
translated: For one who spoils it, there is an offense entailing confession for all of it.

original: Viyūhitvā tu hatthena, nhāyituṃ pana vaṭṭati;
analyzed: viyūhitvā tu hatthena nhāyitum pana vaṭṭati
translated: But it is allowable to bathe after removing it with the hand.

original: Hoti tassa ca sabbampi, ṭhānañhi sakalaṃ jalaṃ.
analyzed: hoti tassa ca sabbam pi ṭhānam hi sakalam jalam
translated: And all of it is in the water, for the whole place is water.

original: Udakena vinā cecca, taṃ panuddharituṃ jalā;
analyzed: udakena vinā ced ca tam jalā
translated: If one takes it out of the water,

original: Na ca vaṭṭati bhikkhussa, ṭhānasaṅkamanañhi taṃ.
analyzed: na ca vaṭṭati bhikkhussa ṭhāna saṅkamanam hi tam
translated: it is not allowable for a monk to move it from its base.🔽But if one throws it into the water,

analyzed: udakena ukkhipitvā tam pakkhipantassa vārisu
translated: and then puts it back in the water,

analyzed: vaṭṭati iti ca niddiṭṭham sabba aṭṭhakathāsu pi
translated: that is allowed, it is said in all the commentaries.

original: Jale vallitiṇādīni, uddharantassa toyato;🔽Vikopentassa vā tattha, hoti pācitti bhikkhuno.
analyzed: jale valli tiṇa ādīni uddharantassa toyataḥ  vikopentassa vā tattha hoti pācitti bhikkhuno
translated: If he pulls out water plants, etc., from the water,🔽Or if he disturbs the water, he commits an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: parehi uppāṭitān ettha vikopentassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: If he disturbs what has been uprooted by others, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Gacchanti hi yato tāni, bījagāmena saṅgahaṃ.
analyzed: gacchanti hi yatas tāni bīja gāmena saṅgaham
translated: Because they are included in the category of seeds when they are carried away.

analyzed: thala ṭṭhe chinna rukkhānam ṭhitaḥ haritakhāṇuko
translated: If a stump of a tree that has been cut down on dry land is still green,

analyzed: uddham vaḍḍhanakaḥ tassa bhūtagāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: The new growth is included in the category of plants.

analyzed: na vaḍḍhati
translated: The stump of a coconut palm, etc., does not grow upwards.

original: Tasmā tassa kato hoti, bījagāmena saṅgaho.
analyzed: tasmā tassa kataḥ hoti bīja gāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: Therefore it is included in the category of seeds.

analyzed: tathā kadaliyā khāṇu phalitāya pakāsitaḥ
translated: So too the stump of a plantain tree, if it has borne fruit and is visible,

original: Aphalitāya yo khāṇu, bhūtagāmena so mato.🔽Phalitā kadalī yāva, nīlapaṇṇā ca tāva sā;
analyzed: a phalitāya yaḥ bhūta gāmena saḥ mataḥ  phalitā kadalī nīla paṇṇā ca sā
translated: But if the stump has not borne fruit, it is considered to be included in the category of plants.🔽As long as the plantain tree is green, with blue leaves,

analyzed: naḷa veḷu tiṇa ādīnam ayam eva
translated: So too is the case with reed, bamboo, and grass.

original: Aggato pana paṭṭhāya, yadāyaṃ veḷu sussati;
analyzed: aggataḥ pana paṭṭhāya yadā ayam veḷu sussati
translated: But when the bamboo dries up from the top,

analyzed: tadā saṅgahitaḥ bījagāmena
translated: It is then included in the category of seeds.

analyzed: inda sāla ādi rukkhānam bīja gāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: The same is the case with the Indasāla tree, etc.

analyzed: chinditvā tu viññeyyaḥ vinayaññunā
translated: But one who is knowledgeable in the Monastic Law should determine the status of those that have been cut down.

analyzed: maṇḍapa ādīnam atthāya nikkhaṇanti ca te sace
translated: If they come out for the sake of the roots, etc.,

analyzed: niggate mūla paṇṇasmim bhūta gāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: Then, when the root and leaf have come out, they are included in the living being.🔽But if they come out for the sake of the root,

original: Mūlamattepi vā yesaṃ, paṇṇamattepi vā pana;🔽Niggatepi kato tesaṃ, bījagāmena saṅgaho.
analyzed: mūla matte api vā paṇṇa matte api vā pana  niggate pi kataḥ tesam bīja gāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: Or even for the sake of the leaf, then, when they have come out,🔽They are included in the seed.

analyzed: sakandā pana tālaṭṭhi bījagāmaḥ ti vuccati
translated: But a palm stump is called a seed,

original: Pattavaṭṭi yadā nīlā, niggacchati tadā na ca.
analyzed: patta vaṭṭi yadā nīlā niggacchati tadā na ca
translated: When the green top comes out, then it is not.

analyzed: nāḷikera tacam dantasūcī iva aṅkuraḥ
translated: Having split the rind of a coconut,

analyzed: niggacchati tadā saḥ api bīja gāmaḥ ti vuccati
translated: The sprout comes out like a tooth-pick; then that is also called a seed.

analyzed: miga siṅga samānāya satiyā patta vaṭṭiyā
translated: When the green top is like the horn of a deer,

analyzed: a niggate pi mūlasmiṃ bhūta gāmaḥ ti vuccati
translated: Even though the root has not come out, it is called a living being.

analyzed: na honti haritā
translated: As long as the shoots of the grain, etc., are not green,

analyzed: niggatesu pi paṇṇesu bīja gāmena saṅgahaḥ
translated: Even though the leaves have come out, they are included in the seed.

analyzed: cattāro bhāṇavārāḥ niṭṭhitā
translated: The four sections are finished.

analyzed: amba jambuṭṭhikā ādīnam esa iva ca vinicchayaḥ
translated: The same decision applies to mango, rose-apple, bread-fruit, etc.,

original: Vandākā vāpi aññaṃ vā, rukkhe jāyati yaṃ pana.
analyzed: vandākā vā api aññam vā rukkhe jāyati yam pana
translated: Or whatever else grows on a tree, even if it is a shoot of bamboo,

original: Rukkhovassa siyā ṭhānaṃ, vikopetuṃ na vaṭṭati;
analyzed: rukkhovassa siyā ṭhānam vikopetum na vaṭṭati
translated: The tree is the place for the growth, it is not allowable to destroy it;

analyzed: vinicchayaḥ
translated: The explanation of the root-creeper, etc., is finished.

analyzed: pākāra ādīsu sevālo aggabījanti vuccati
translated: In a wall, etc., a creeper is called the chief seed;

original: Yāva dve tīṇi pattāni, na sañjāyanti tāva so.
analyzed: yāva dve tīṇi pattāni na sañjāyanti tāva saḥ
translated: As long as there are not two or three leaves, it is that.

original: Pattesu pana jātesu, vatthu pācittiyassa so;
analyzed: pattesu pana jātesu vatthu pācittiyassa so
translated: But when the leaves have grown, the basis is an offense entailing confession.

original: Ghaṃsitvā pana taṃ tasmā, apanetuṃ na vaṭṭati.🔽Sevāle bahi pānīya-ghaṭādīnaṃ tu dukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: ghaṃsitvā pana tam tasmai apanetum na vaṭṭati  sevāle bahi pānīya ghaṭa ādīnam tu dukkaṭam
translated: But after breaking it off, it is not allowable to remove it from there.🔽Outside the creeper, it is a wrong-doing to use a water pot, etc.;

analyzed: saḥ antaḥ pūva ādīsu pi kaṇṇakam
translated: But it is allowable to use it inside. It is the same with cakes, etc.

analyzed: ca
translated: Stones, pebbles, root-creepers, and creeping vines,

original: Honti dukkaṭavatthūni, apattānīti niddise.🔽Pupphitaṃ tu ahicchattaṃ, abbohārikataṃ gataṃ;
analyzed: honti dukkaṭa vatthūni apattāni iti niddise  pupphitam tu ahicchattam abbohārika tat gatam
translated: These are the bases for wrong-doing, and they are not leaves.🔽But the flowering ironwood tree is allowable to use;

original: Sace taṃ makuḷaṃ hoti, hoti dukkaṭavatthukaṃ.
analyzed: sace tam makuḷam hoti hoti dukkaṭa vatthukam
translated: If it is a bud, it is a basis for wrong-doing.

original: Rukkhe tacaṃ vikopetvā, tathā pappaṭikampi ca;
analyzed: rukkhe tacam vikopetvā tathā ca
translated: Having damaged the bark of a tree, and also a shoot,

original: Niyyāsampi panallasmiṃ, gahetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: niyyāsam pi panallasmim gahetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: And also a sapling, it is not allowable to take it.

analyzed: nuhi ādīsu rukkhesu tāla paṇṇa ādikesu vā
translated: In trees such as the nuhi, or in palm leaves, etc.,

analyzed: likhataḥ tattha jātesu pācittiyam udīraye
translated: If one draws on them, one should announce a confession offense for what has grown there.

original: Pupphaṃ paṇḍupalāsaṃ vā, phalaṃ vā pakkameva vā;
analyzed: puppham paṇḍu palāsam vā phalam vā pakkam eva vā
translated: A flower, a withered leaf, or a fruit, or one that is ripe,

analyzed: pātentassa ca cāletvā pācittiyam udīritam
translated: And shaking a tree: an offense of wrong conduct is declared.

original: Nāmetvā phaliniṃ sākhaṃ, dātuṃ vaṭṭati gaṇhato;
analyzed: nāma itvā phalinim sākham dātum vaṭṭati gaṇhataḥ
translated: If he names a branch with fruit, it’s allowable to pick it;

original: Sayaṃ khāditukāmo ce, dātumevaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: sayam khāditu kāmaḥ ce dātum evam na vaṭṭati
translated: But if he wants to eat it himself, it’s not allowable to give it.

original: Ukkhipitvā paraṃ kañci, gāhāpetumpi vaṭṭati;🔽Pupphāni ocinantesu, ayameva vinicchayo.
analyzed: ukkhipitvā param kañci gāhāpetum pi vaṭṭati  pupphāni ocinantesu ayam eva vinicchayaḥ
translated: If he lifts it up, it’s allowable to have another pick it;🔽This is the decision regarding picking flowers.

original: Yesaṃ ruhati rukkhānaṃ, sākhā tesampi sākhinaṃ;
analyzed: yesam ruhati rukkhānam sākhā tesam pi sākhinam
translated: And for those trees whose branches grow over the boundary of another,

analyzed: kappiyam tam a kāretvā vikopentassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: If he makes it allowable, there’s no offense in damaging it.

analyzed: ayam eva nayaḥ alla siṅgivera ādike supi
translated: This is also the rule for fresh bamboo and so on;

analyzed: dukkaṭam bīja gāmesu niddiṭṭha ttā mahesinā
translated: There’s wrong conduct in seeds and plants, because it’s been declared by the great sage.

original: “Rukkhaṃ chinda lataṃ chinda, kandaṃ mūlampi uddhara;
analyzed: rukkham chinda latam chinda kandam mūlam pi uddhara
translated: “Cut the tree, cut the creeper, dig up the tuber, dig up the root;

analyzed: uppāṭehi iti vattum pi vaṭṭatā iva a niyāmataḥ
translated: Pull it out,” it’s allowable to say this, because of the rule.

original: “Ambaṃ jambumpi nimbaṃ vā, chinda bhinduddharā”ti vā;
analyzed: ambam jambum pi nimbam vā chinda vā
translated: “Cut the mango, cut the rose-apple, cut the neem tree,” or “Dig it up,”

analyzed: gahetvā pana nāmam pi vaṭṭatā iva a niyāmataḥ
translated: But if he says, “Pick this,” it’s not allowable, because of the rule.

original: “Imaṃ rukkhaṃ imaṃ valliṃ, imaṃ challiṃ imaṃ lataṃ;
analyzed: imam rukkham imam vallim imam challim imam latam
translated: “This tree, this creeper, this grass, this creeper,”

original: Chinda bhindā”ti vā vattuṃ, niyametvā na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: chinda bhinda ati vā vattum niyametvā na vaṭṭati
translated: “Cut it, dig it up,” it’s not allowable to say this, because of the rule.

analyzed: pūretvā ucchukhaṇḍānam pacchiyaḥ āharanti ce
translated: If they bring back a load of sugar-lumps, having filled it,🔽

original: Sabbameva kataṃ hoti, ekasmiṃ kappiye kate.
analyzed: sabbam eva katam hoti ekasmim kappiye kate
translated: If they fill it with pieces of cane And bring it back, all is allowable, If one thing is allowable.

original: Ekato pana baddhāni, ucchudārūni honti ce;
analyzed: ekatas pana baddhāni ucchu dārūni honti ce
translated: But if the pieces of wood are bound together,

original: Kappiyaṃ karonto pana, dāruṃ vijjhati vaṭṭati.
analyzed: kappiyam karontaḥ pana dārum vijjhati vaṭṭati
translated: And while making it allowable, the wood breaks up, it is allowable.

original: Valliyā rajjuyā vāpi, yāya baddhāni tāni hi;
analyzed: baddhāni tāni hi
translated: But if it is bound with creepers or with string,

original: Bhājanena samānattā, taṃ vijjhati na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: bhājanena samānattā tam vijjhati na vaṭṭati
translated: Because of its similarity to a vessel, it is not allowable to break it up.

analyzed: bhattam marica pakkehi missetvā āharanti ce
translated: If they bring back rice together with pepper-corns,

analyzed: eka sitthe pi bhattassa sace vijjhati vaṭṭati
translated: If it is allowable to break up the rice in one container,

analyzed: ayam eva nayaḥ tila taṇḍulaka ādisu
translated: The same method applies to sesame seeds, rice, etc.,

original: Ekābaddhe kapitthepi, kaṭāhe kappiyaṃ kare.🔽Kaṭāhaṃ yadi muñcitvā, anto carati miñjakaṃ;
analyzed: eka ābaddhe kapitthe ipi kaṭāhe kappiyam kare  kaṭāham yadi muñcitvā carati miñjakam
translated: And to a fruit such as a wood-apple.🔽But if, after opening the wood-apple,🔽The fruit inside moves about, the wood-apple should be broken up,

original: Bhindāpetvā kapitthaṃ taṃ, kāretabbaṃ tu kappiyaṃ.
analyzed: bhindāpetvā kapittham tam kāretabbam tu kappiyam
translated: And it should be made allowable.🔽If, with regard to seeds of plants and seeds of trees,

analyzed: abhūtagāma bījesu bhūtagāma ādi saññinaḥ
translated: He perceives them as plants and trees,

analyzed: tattha vematikassa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: Then if he is unsure, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: a tathā saññinaḥ tattha ca
translated: If he does not perceive them as such, if he does not know,

analyzed: ummattaka ādikānam ca anāpatti pakāsitā
translated: And for those who are insane and so on, No offense has been declared.

analyzed: idam ca ti samuṭṭhānam kriyam saññā vimokkhakam
translated: This originates in three ways; It is an action, and it is liberated by perception;

analyzed: kāya kammam vacī kammam ti cittam ca ti vedanam
translated: It is bodily and verbal action, And it has three kinds of consciousness and three kinds of feelings.

analyzed: bhūta gāma kathā
translated: The sub-chapter on plants

analyzed: kate saṅghena kammasmiṃ añña vāda vihesake
translated: When the Sangha has done a legal procedure, And one disputes it and causes it to be disputed;

original: Tathā puna karontassa, hoti pācittiyadvayaṃ.🔽Tikapācittiyaṃ dhamme, adhamme tikadukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: tathā puna karontassa hoti pācittiya dvayam  tika pācittiyam dhamme adhamme tika dukkaṭam
translated: And then does it again, There are two offenses entailing confession.🔽Three offenses entailing confession are in the true Teaching, And three offenses of wrong conduct are in the non-teaching;

original: Kamme aropite cevaṃ, vadantassa ca dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: kamme a ropite ca ivam vadantassa ca dukkaṭam
translated: When the procedure is done in this way, And when one speaks, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: āpattim vā api āpannam a jānantassa bhaṇḍanam
translated: And one who has committed an offense, Who does not know, “There will be quarreling;

analyzed: bhavissati iti saññissa gilānassa na dosa tā
translated: There will be arguments; There will be disputes,” And who is sick, is not at fault.

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ
translated: The origins and so on are the same as for stealing.

analyzed: kriyākriyam idam vuttam vedanā dukkha vedanā
translated: It is said that this is an action, And it has only painful feeling.

analyzed: aññavāda kathā
translated: The sub-chapter on disputing

analyzed: ayasam kattu kāmaḥ iva sammatassa hi bhikkhuno
translated: One who wants to make someone else feel remorse, And who accuses a monk who is agreed upon;

original: Vadanto upasampanne, ujjhāpeti ca khīyati.🔽Tasmiṃ vatthudvaye tassa, hoti pācittiyadvayaṃ;
analyzed: vadantaḥ upasampanne ca khīyati  tasmim vatthu dvaye tassa hoti pācittiya dvayam
translated: When speaking to one who is fully ordained, There is agitation and there is resentment.🔽In these two cases, there are two offenses entailing confession;

analyzed: tika pācittiyam dhamme adhamme tika dukkaṭam
translated: Three offenses entailing confession are in the true Teaching, And three offenses of wrong conduct are in the non-teaching.

original: Avaṇṇaṃnupasampanna-santike pana bhikkhuno;🔽Asammatassa bhikkhussa, bhāsato yassa kassaci.
analyzed: a vaṇṇaṃ na upasampanna santike pana bhikkhuno  a sammatassa bhikkhussa bhāsataḥ yassa kassaci
translated: But if a monk praises himself in the presence of one who is not fully ordained,🔽Or if anyone speaks about the qualities of a monk who has not been approved,

analyzed: sāmaṇerassa vā vaṇṇam sammata a sammatassa api
translated: Or if anyone speaks about the qualities of a novice monk, whether he has been approved or not,

original: Vadato dukkaṭaṃ hoti, yassa kassaci santike.🔽Chandādīnaṃ vaseneva, karontaṃ bhaṇato pana;
analyzed: vadataḥ dukkaṭam hoti yassa kassaci santike  chanda ādīnam vasena iva karontam bhaṇataḥ pana
translated: Then there is an offense of wrong conduct.🔽But if he does it because of desire, etc.,

analyzed: anāpatti kriyāsesam anantarasamam matam
translated: Then there is no offense if he is continuing the same procedure, if he is doing it immediately before, or if he is doing it immediately after.

original: Ujjhāpanakathā.🔽Ajjhokāse tu mañcādiṃ, attano vā parassa vā;
analyzed: ujjhāpana kathā  ajjhokāse tu mañca ādim attanaḥ vā parassa vā
translated: The discussion of complaining.🔽If he has a bed or a bench that belongs to the Sangha, either his own or that of another,

analyzed: atthāya santharāpetvā santharitvā api vā pana
translated: Spread in the open air for a purpose, or even if he has it spread,

original: Nevuddhareyya saṅghassa, uddharāpeyya vā na taṃ;
analyzed: na iva uddhareyya saṅghassa uddhara āpeyya vā na tam
translated: He should neither remove it nor have it removed from where it is.

original: Pakkamanto sace tassa, hoti pācitti bhikkhuno.
analyzed: pakkamantaḥ sace tassa hoti pācitti bhikkhuno
translated: If he leaves, then there is an offense entailing confession for that monk.

original: Vassike caturo māse, sace devo na vassati;
analyzed: vassike caturaḥ māse sace devaḥ na vassati
translated: If it is the four months of the rainy season, and if it does not rain,

original: Ajjhokāse tathā cāpi, ṭhapetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: ajjhokāse tathā ca api ṭhapetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: Then it is not allowable to leave it like that in the open air.

original: Yattha vassati hemante, cattāro aparepi ca;
analyzed: yattha vassati hemante cattāraḥ apare pi ca
translated: But if it rains during the four winter months,

original: Ṭhapetuṃ tattha mañcādiṃ, aṭṭha māse na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: ṭhapetum tattha mañca ādim aṭṭha māse na vaṭṭati
translated: Then it is not allowable to leave a bed or a bench there for eight months.

analyzed: kāka ādīnam nivāsasmim rukkha mūle kadāci pi
translated: Or if it is under a tree, where crows, etc., live,

original: Mañcādiṃ pana saṅghassa, ṭhapetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: mañca ādim pana saṅghassa ṭhapetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: But a bed, etc., belonging to the Sangha, it is not allowable to store.

original: Aññassatthāya yaṃ kiñci, santhataṃ yadi saṅghikaṃ;
analyzed: aññassa atthāya yam kiñci santhatam yadi saṅghikam
translated: If a bedspread is belonging to the Sangha, for the sake of another,

original: Yattha katthaci vā ṭhāne, yena kenaci bhikkhunā.
analyzed: yattha katthaci vā ṭhāne yena kenaci bhikkhunā
translated: In whatever place, by whatever monk,

original: Yāva so na nisīdeyya, “gacchā”ti na vadeyya vā;🔽Tāva santhārakasseva, bhāro tanti pavuccati.
analyzed: yāva saḥ na nisīdeyya gacchāti na vadeyya vā  tāva santhārakassa iva bhāro tanti pavuccati
translated: As long as he has not sat down, or has not said, “Go away,”🔽The responsibility for the bedspread is said to be his.

original: Sace taṃ sāmaṇerena, santharāpeti santhataṃ;🔽Santharāpitabhikkhussa, palibodhoti dīpito.
analyzed: sace tam sāmaṇerena santhara apa iti santhatam  santharāpita bhikkhussa palibodhaḥ ti dīpitaḥ
translated: If a novice monk spreads a bedspread,🔽The responsibility is shown to be that of the monk for whom it was spread.

original: Santhataṃ bhikkhunā taṃ ce, bhāro tasseva tāva taṃ;
analyzed: santhatam bhikkhunā tam ce bhāro tassa iva tāva tam
translated: If that bedspread belongs to a monk, the responsibility is his as long as

original: Yāva āṇāpako tattha, āgantvā na nisīdati.🔽Bhikkhuṃ vā sāmaṇeraṃ vā, ārāmikamupāsakaṃ;
analyzed: yāva āṇāpako tattha āgantvā na nisīdati  bhikkhum vā sāmaṇeram vā ārāmikam upāsakam
translated: The one who told him has not come and sat down.🔽Having sent away a monk, a novice monk, a monastery worker, or a lay follower,

analyzed: an āpucchā saṅghikam sayanāsanam
translated: Without asking permission, a Sangha bed or bench,

analyzed: leḍḍuppātam atikkamma gacchataḥ paṭhame pade
translated: If he goes beyond throwing distance, in the first step

original: Dukkaṭaṃ, dutiye vāre, pācittiyamudīritaṃ.🔽Ṭhatvā bhojanasālāyaṃ, vatvā yo sāmaṇerakaṃ;
analyzed: dukkaṭam dutiye vāre pācittiyam udīritam  bhojana sālāyam vatvā sāmaṇerakam
translated: There is an act of wrong conduct; in the second step, an offense entailing confession has been declared.🔽If he has sat down in the dining hall and then says to a novice monk,

analyzed: asukasmin divāṭṭhāne paññāpehi iti mañcakam
translated: “Please put the bed at such-and-such a place during the day,”

original: Nikkhamitvā sace tasmā, ṭhānā aññattha gacchati;
analyzed: nikkhamitvā sace tasmā ṭhānā aññattha gacchati
translated: If he leaves it and goes elsewhere,

original: Pāduddhārena so bhikkhu, kāretabboti dīpito.🔽Tikapācittiyaṃ vuttaṃ, tikātītena satthunā;
analyzed: pāduddhārena so bhikkhu kāretabbaḥ iti dīpito  tika pācittiyam vuttam tika atītena satthunā
translated: The monk should be dealt with according to the rule.🔽The three offenses entailing confession are stated;

original: Tathā puggalike tena, dīpitaṃ tikadukkaṭaṃ.🔽Cimiliṃ taṭṭikaṃ cammaṃ, phalakaṃ pādapuñchaniṃ;🔽Bhūmattharaṇakaṃ vāpi, uttarattharaṇampi vā.
analyzed: tathā puggalike tena dīpitam tika dukkaṭam  cimilim taṭṭikam cammam phalakam pāda puñchanim  bhūmattharaṇakam vā api uttarattharaṇam pi vā
translated: The three kinds of bad actions are shown by the one who has three.🔽A mat, a mat made of bottle-gourd gourds, a mat made of erakā grass, a mat made of pieces of wood, a foot wiper,🔽A floor cover, or a bed cover,

analyzed: dāru mattika bhaṇḍāni patta ādhārakam eva vā
translated: Wooden or ceramic goods, or a bowl rack:

original: Abbhokāse ṭhapetvā taṃ, gacchato hoti dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: abbhokāse ṭhapetvā tam gacchataḥ hoti dukkaṭam
translated: If he leaves it outside and then goes away, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Sace āraññakenāpi, anovasse ca no sati;
analyzed: sace āraññakena api anovasse ca no sati
translated: If it is in the wilderness, and if there is no danger,

original: Laggetvā pana rukkhasmiṃ, gantabbaṃ tu yathāsukhaṃ.
analyzed: laggetvā pana rukkhasmiṃ gantabbam tu yathāsukham
translated: But he hangs it on a tree, he may go as he likes.

original: Yathā upacikādīhi, na khajjati na lujjati;
analyzed: yathā upacika ādīhi na khajjati na lujjati
translated: So that it is not eaten by termites or destroyed,

original: Tathā katvāpi taṃ sabbaṃ, gantuṃ pana ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: tathā katvā api tam sabbam gantum pana ca vaṭṭati
translated: He may do all that and then go.

analyzed: āpucchitvā api gacchataḥ
translated: If he leaves it without taking it down, or if he goes after informing,

analyzed: attanaḥ santake ruddhe āpadāsu pi bhikkhunaḥ
translated: Or if it belongs to him, or if there is an emergency,

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayo sabbe kathinena samā matā
translated: The origins, etc., are all the same as for the kaṭhina ceremony.

analyzed: kriyākriyam idam vuttam ayam eva visesa tā
translated: This is the doing and not doing, which is said to be the difference.

analyzed: paṭhama senāsana kathā  bhisicimilikā bhūmattharaṇam uttarattharam
translated: The first section for recitation on dwellings.

analyzed: taṭṭikā camma khaṇḍo ca paccatthara nisīdanam
translated: A bed, a mat, a spread, a coverlet, a straw mat, a hide, a piece of cloth, a spread on a bed, a sitting mat,

analyzed: santhāraḥ tiṇa paṇṇānam seyyā dasavidhā siyā
translated: A spread of grass or leaves: these are the ten kinds of beds.

analyzed: sabba channa paricchanne vihāre bhikkhu yaḥ pana
translated: In a dwelling that is completely roofed in or completely roofed over, if a monk

original: Etaṃ dasavidhaṃ seyyaṃ, santharitvāpi vā sayaṃ;
analyzed: etam dasavidham seyyam santharitvā api vā sayam
translated: Spreads out any of these ten kinds of beds, or he himself spreads one out,

analyzed: an uddharitvā an āpucchāḥ atikkamati tam sace
translated: And then departs without putting it away or informing anyone,

original: Ārāmassūpacāraṃ vā, parikkhepaṃ panassa vā;🔽Paṭhame dukkaṭaṃ pāde, pācitti dutiye siyā.
analyzed: ārāmassa upacāram vā parikkhepam panassa vā  paṭhame dukkaṭam pāde pācitti dutiye siyā
translated: If he goes beyond the vicinity of the dwelling or beyond the surrounding area,🔽Then for each foot he is at first at fault, and if he goes a second time, there is an offense entailing confession.

original: Senāsanassa seyyāya, ubhayesaṃ vināsato;🔽Gacchato santharitvanto-gabbhe pācitti vaṇṇitā.🔽Upacāre vihārassa, dukkaṭaṃ maṇḍapādike;
analyzed: senāsanassa seyyāya ubhayesam vināsataḥ  gacchataḥ santharitvantogabbhe pācitti vaṇṇitā  upacāre vihārassa dukkaṭam maṇḍapa ādike
translated: Because of the destruction of the bed and the dwelling,🔽For one who departs after spreading out a bed in an inner room, an offense entailing confession is declared.🔽In the vicinity of a dwelling, in a pavilion,

analyzed: gacchatoḥ santharitvā vā seyyā mattam vināsatoḥ
translated: For one who departs after spreading out a bed, there is an offense entailing confession for the destruction of the bed.

analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam saṅghike dasa vatthuke
translated: In the case of a dwelling belonging to the Sangha, in the ten cases, there are three offenses entailing confession;

analyzed: tathā puggalike tassa dīpitam tika dukkaṭam
translated: And in the case of one belonging to an individual, three offenses of wrong conduct are declared.

analyzed: vai āpuccham vā api gacchataḥ
translated: Or if he goes after informing,

analyzed: palibuddhe pi vā aññena attano santake pi vā
translated: Or if it’s obstructed by another, Or if it’s his own.🔽If he goes with expectation,

original: Sāpekkhova ca gantvā taṃ, tattha ṭhatvāpi pucchati;
analyzed: sa apekkhā uva ca gantvā tam tattha ṭhatvā api pucchati
translated: Or if he stands there and asks,

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ sabbe anantarasamā matā
translated: The origins, etc., are all treated in the same way as the preceding rule.

original: Dutiyasenāsanakathā.🔽Yo pubbupagataṃ bhikkhuṃ, jānaṃ anupakhajja ca;
analyzed: dutiya senāsana kathā  yaḥ pubbupagatam bhikkhum an upakhajja ca
translated: The second rule on dwellings.🔽If a monk knowingly uses a bed or a bench

original: Kappeyya saṅghikāvāse, seyyaṃ pācittiyassa ce.🔽Pādadhovanapāsāṇā, pavisantassa bhikkhuno;
analyzed: kappeyya saṅghikā vāse seyyam pācittiyassa ce  pāda dhovana pāsāṇā pavisantassa bhikkhuno
translated: In a dwelling where there is a monk who arrived there first,🔽If a stone for washing the feet is used by a monk who is entering

original: Yāva taṃ mañcapīṭhaṃ vā, nikkhamantassa vā pana.
analyzed: yāva tam mañca pīṭham vā nikkhamantassa vā pana
translated: Or if a bed or a bench is used by a monk who is leaving,🔽From the bed or the bench

analyzed: mañca pīṭhakataḥ yāva passa avaṭṭhānam eva tu
translated: Up to the place for urinating,

analyzed: etthantare idam ṭhānam upacāro ti vuccati
translated: This area is called “in use”.

analyzed: tattha bādhetu kāmassa upacāre tu bhikkhuno
translated: If a monk who wants to disturb another monk

analyzed: dasasu aññataram seyyam santharantassa dukkaṭam
translated: Spreads out a bed or a bench in that area, it’s an offense of wrong conduct.🔽If he sits down there,

original: Nisīdantassa vā tattha, nipajjantassa vā pana;
analyzed: nisīdantassa vā tattha nipajjantassa vā pana
translated: Or if he lies down there,🔽Or if he does both,

analyzed: tathā dve pi karontassa hoti pācittiya dvayam
translated: There are two offenses entailing confession.

analyzed: punappunam karontassa payoga gaṇanā vasā
translated: If one does it again and again, the offense is equal to the number of uses.

original: Tikapācittiyaṃ vuttaṃ, puggale tikadukkaṭaṃ.🔽Vuttūpacāraṃ muñcitvā, seyyaṃ santharatopi vā;
analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam puggale tika dukkaṭam  vuttu upacāram muñcitvā seyyam vā
translated: The offense is said to be one entailing confession for each person, and one of wrong conduct for each of the three.🔽If one moves away from the place where one was told to sleep, or if one spreads out a bed or a sitting mat,

analyzed: vihārassa upacāre vā ajjhokāse pi vā pana
translated: Or if one does it in the vicinity of the dwelling, or outside,

analyzed: santharāpayataḥ vā api tattha tassa nisīdataḥ
translated: Or if one has it spread out there, and then sits down,

original: Sabbattha dukkaṭaṃ vuttaṃ, nivāso ca nivārito.
analyzed: sabbattha dukkaṭam vuttam nivāso ca nivārito
translated: The offense is said to be one of wrong conduct in all these cases, and sleeping is prohibited.

original: Anāpatti gilānassa, sītāduppīḷitassa vā;🔽Āpadāsupi bhikkhussa, tathā ummattakādino.
analyzed: anāpatti gilānassa sītā duppīḍitassa vā  āpadāsu pi bhikkhussa tathā ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: There is no offense if one is sick, or if one is oppressed by cold or heat,🔽Or if there is a danger, or if one is insane or the first offender.

original: Samuṭṭhānādayo sabbe, paṭhamantimavatthunā;🔽Sadisāti ca viññeyyā, hotīdaṃ dukkhavedanaṃ.
analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ sabbe paṭhama antima vatthunā  sadisā ati ca viññeyyā hoti idam dukkha vedanam
translated: The origins, etc., are all the same as for the first offense entailing suspension.

original: Anupakhajjakathā.🔽Vihārā saṅghikā bhikkhuṃ, nikkaḍḍheyya sace pana;🔽Nikkaḍḍhāpeyya vā kuddho, tassa pācittiyaṃ siyā.🔽Bahubhūmāpi pāsādā, payogenekakena yo;🔽Nikkaḍḍheti sace tassa, ekā pācitti dīpitā.🔽Ṭhapetvā ca ṭhapetvā ca, nikkaḍḍhantassa antarā;
analyzed: an upakhajja kathā 🔽vihārā saṅghikā bhikkhum nikkaḍḍheyya sace pana 🔽nikkaḍḍhāpeyya vā kuddhaḥ tassa pācittiyam siyā 🔽bahu bhūmā api 🔽nikkaḍḍheti sace tassa ekā pācitti dīpitā 🔽ṭhapetvā ca ṭhapetvā ca nikkaḍḍhantassa antarā
translated: This rule should be understood as being similar to that one. It has one effect: it causes suffering.

analyzed: dvārānam gaṇanāyassa honti pācittiyaḥ pana
translated: If he counts the doors, There is an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: nikkhamāti vadantassa ayam nayaḥ
translated: If he says, “Go out,” The same rule applies to speech.

analyzed: āṇattiyā khaṇeya iva āṇāpentassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: As soon as the order is given, there is an offense of wrong conduct for the one who gives the order.

original: Sace so sakimāṇatto, dvārepi bahuke pana;
analyzed: sace saḥ bahuke pana
translated: If he is ordered to do so, And there are many doors,

analyzed: atikkāmā iti bahukāni bahūni ce
translated: He may pass through one or many.

analyzed: tassu upaṭṭhāna sāla ādi vihāraḥ upacārataḥ
translated: From the vicinity of the dwelling of the one who is to be expelled,

original: Kāyenapi ca vācāya, tathā nikkaḍḍhanepi ca.
analyzed: kāyena api ca vācāya tathā nikkaḍḍhane pi ca
translated: And also by body and speech, and also by making him leave.

analyzed: vihāraḥ su upacārāḥ vā vihārāḥ vā api ca itaram
translated: From the vicinity of the dwelling, or from another dwelling,

analyzed: nikkaḍḍhantassa sabbesam parikkhāram pi dukkaṭam
translated: For all who make him leave, there is an offense of wrong conduct, even for the requisites.

analyzed: asambaddhesu bhikkhussa parikkhāresu paṇḍitaḥ
translated: If the requisites of a monk are not connected to him,

original: Vatthūnaṃ gaṇanāyassa, dukkaṭaṃ paridīpaye.🔽Antevāsimalajjiṃ vā, tathā saddhivihārikaṃ;🔽Nikkaḍḍhantassa ummattaṃ, sayaṃ ummattakassa ca.
analyzed: vatthūnam gaṇanāyassa dukkaṭam paridīpaye  antevāsim alajjim vā tathā saddhivihārikam  nikkaḍḍhantassa ummattam sayam ummattakassa ca
translated: The wise one should declare an offense of wrong conduct for the counting of the items.🔽If he makes a pupil or a modest companion, or a student, leave,🔽Or if he is deranged, or if the other person is deranged,

analyzed: attanaḥ vasana ṭṭhānā tathā vissāsikassa vā
translated: Or if he makes him leave from his own dwelling, or from the dwelling of a confident,

analyzed: parikkhāram ca vā tesam anāpatti pakāsitā
translated: Or if he makes him leave the requisites belonging to them, there is no offense.

analyzed: tathā kalahakārakam
translated: If he makes him leave from the vicinity of the Sangha’s dwelling,🔽Or if he makes a troublemaker leave,

analyzed: idam tu ti samuṭṭhānam vedanā dukkha vedanā
translated: This originates in three ways: The pain is painful feeling.

analyzed: nikkaḍḍhana kathā
translated: The discussion of pulling down.

analyzed: majjhima āsīsa ghaṭṭāya vehāsa kuṭi yu upari
translated: When the head is bumped on the upper story, in a stilt house with a peaked roof,

original: Āhaccapādake mañce, pīṭhe vā pana bhikkhuno.
analyzed: āhacca pādake mañce pīṭhe vā pana bhikkhuno
translated: On a bed with detachable legs, or on a bench, or on a monk.

original: Nisīdantassa vā tasmiṃ, nipajjantassa vā pana;
analyzed: nisīdantassa vā tasmin nipajjantassa vā pana
translated: When sitting down on it, or when lying down on it,

analyzed: payoga gaṇanāya iva tassa pācittiyaḥ siyum
translated: The offense is according to the number of efforts, and it is a pācittiya.

original: Tikapācittiyaṃ vuttaṃ, puggale tikadukkaṭaṃ;🔽Heṭṭhā aparibhoge vā, sīsaghaṭṭāya vā pana.
analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam puggale tika dukkaṭam  heṭṭhā a paribhoge vā sīsa ghaṭṭāya vā pana
translated: The offense is a pācittiya for three, and for a person, it is a dukkaṭa for three;🔽When it is not for the purpose of using it, or when the head is bumped on it,

analyzed: avehāsa vihāre vā attano vā
translated: Or in a stilt house without an upper story, or in one’s own stilt house,

analyzed: vissāsika vihāre vā na dosummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: Or in a stilt house belonging to a trustworthy person, not one who is insane or intoxicated,

original: Yattha paṭāṇi vā dinnā, tattha ṭhatvā lageti vā;
analyzed: paṭāṇi vā dinnā tattha vā
translated: Where the windows are closed, or where one stands and fastens them,

analyzed: idam eḷaka lomena samuṭṭhānam samam matam
translated: The origin is considered to be the same as in the case of the stilt house.

analyzed: vehāsa kuṭi kathā
translated: The discussion of the stilt house.

analyzed: yāva dvārassa kosamhā aggaḷa ṭṭhapanāya tu
translated: As far as the threshold, for the purpose of fixing the bolt,

analyzed: bhikkhunā limpitabbam vā lepāpetabbam eva vā
translated: A monk should smear it or have it smeared.

analyzed: ñeyyaḥ āloka sandhīnam nayaḥ
translated: This is the rule for the work on the windows.

analyzed: chadanassa ṭhitena harite pana
translated: When standing on the roof, he should cover the two-thirds.

original: Adhiṭṭheyyaṃ tato uddhaṃ, adhiṭṭheti sace pana;🔽Tassa pācittiyaṃ hoti, dukkaṭaṃ tattha tiṭṭhato.
analyzed: adhiṭṭheyyam tatas uddham adhiṭṭheti sace pana  tassa pācittiyam hoti dukkaṭam tattha tiṭṭhataḥ
translated: If he then extends it beyond that,🔽he commits an offense entailing confession. While standing there, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Piṭṭhivaṃse ṭhito koci, chadanassa mukhavaṭṭiyā;🔽Yasmiṃ ṭhāne ṭhitaṃ bhikkhuṃ, olokento na passati.
analyzed: piṭṭhi vaṃse ṭhitaḥ koci chadanassa mukha vaṭṭiyā  yasmim ṭhāne ṭhitam bhikkhum olokentaḥ na passati
translated: If someone is standing on the roof ridge, on the roof peak, or on the roof edge,🔽in a place where the monk standing there cannot see him,

original: Tasmiṃ ṭhāne pana ṭhātuṃ, neva bhikkhussa vaṭṭati;
analyzed: tasmim ṭhāne pana ṭhātum na iva bhikkhussa vaṭṭati
translated: then the monk should not stand there,

analyzed: vihārassa patantassa patana ukāsataḥ hi tam
translated: because that is the place where the dwelling falls.

analyzed: ūna ka dvatti pariyāye saññinaḥ
translated: If it is less than two and a half cubits, but he perceives it as more,

analyzed: tattha vematikassa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: then he commits an offense of wrong conduct.🔽If it is two and a half cubits or more,

original: Na doso dvattipariyāye, leṇe tiṇakuṭīsu vā;
analyzed: na dosaḥ leṇe tiṇa kuṭīsu vā
translated: there is no offense if it is in a cave or a hut of grass;

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ sabbe sañcaritta samā matā
translated: the origins, etc., are all treated like in the rule on storing.

analyzed: dvi tti pariyāya kathā
translated: The rule on two and a half cubits.

original: Jānaṃ sappāṇakaṃ toyaṃ, tiṇaṃ vā mattikampi vā;
analyzed: jānam sappāṇakam toyam tiṇam vā mattikam pi vā
translated: If he sprinkles water, grass, or clay, knowing that they contain living beings,

original: Yadi siñceyya pācitti, siñcāpeyya parehi vā.
analyzed: yadi siñceyya pācitti siñca apeyya parehi vā
translated: he commits an offense entailing confession, as does anyone else who has him do it.

original: Acchinditvā sace dhāraṃ, mattikaṃ siñcato pana;
analyzed: a chinditvā sace dhāram mattikam siñcataḥ pana
translated: If he sprinkles clay after breaking the flow,

analyzed: ekasmin pi ghaṭe ekā pācitti paridīpitā
translated: then for each vessel, each offense entailing confession is declared.

analyzed: vicchindati sace dhāram payoga gaṇanā vasā
translated: If he breaks the flow, then the offense is according to the number of attempts;

analyzed: sammukham pi karontassa mātikam sandamānakam
translated: Even if he does it in the presence of, the offense is according to the number of attempts in the rule.

original: Ekāva ce siyāpatti, divasampi ca sandatu;
analyzed: ce
translated: If there is only one offense, then it continues for a day;

analyzed: bandhataḥ tattha tatthassa payoga gaṇanā siyā
translated: But for each place where he binds it, there is an offense for each attempt.

original: Sace sakaṭapuṇṇampi, mattikaṃ tiṇameva vā;🔽Udake pakkhipantassa, ekā pācitti ekato.
analyzed: sace mattikam tiṇam eva vā  udake pakkhipantassa ekā pācitti ekatas
translated: If he puts in water clay, grass, or chaff,🔽Even if it fills a cart, then for putting it in, there is one offense entailing confession.

analyzed: ekekam pakkhipantassa payoga gaṇanāya ce
translated: If he puts it in bit by bit, then for each attempt,

original: Khayaṃ vā āvilattaṃ vā, jalaṃ gacchati tādise.
analyzed: khayam vā āvilattam vā jalam gacchati tādise
translated: If the water becomes muddy or turbid,

analyzed: siñcāhi iti vadantassa hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ
translated: If he says, “Pour it in,” then there is an offense of wrong conduct;

analyzed: ekāya āṇattiyā ekā divasam pi ca siñcato
translated: For each statement, there is one offense, even if he pours it in for a day.

analyzed: appāṇe udake suddhe sappāṇam iti saññinaḥ
translated: If the water is clear and has no living beings, but he perceives that it has,

analyzed: sabbattha vimatissa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: Then everywhere, even if he is unsure, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: sabbattha apāṇa saññissa vā
translated: Everywhere if he perceives that it has living beings, if he does not do it on purpose, if he does not know,

analyzed: a jānataḥ anāpatti tathā ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: If he is insane, then there is no offense.

analyzed: sappāṇaka ttam toyassa vijānanam
translated: The water has living beings, he perceives that it has,

analyzed: vinā vadhaka cittena tiṇa ādīnam
translated: Without the thought of killing, he pours in grass, etc.

analyzed: cattārevassa aṅgāni niddiṭṭhāni mahesinā
translated: The four factors have been taught By the Great Sage.

original: Adinnādānatulyāva, samuṭṭhānādayo nayā.🔽Idaṃ paṇṇattivajjañca, ticittañcāti dīpitaṃ;
analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ  idam dīpitam
translated: The origins and so on are the same As for stealing.🔽This is what is shown: The offense entailing suspension, The three kinds of minds, and what is by rule.

analyzed: idam eva itthā niddiṭṭham tassa ca ssa visesanam
translated: This is what has been taught here, And the distinction of that.

analyzed: sappāṇaka kathā
translated: The discussion of living beings.

analyzed: senāsana vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: The second sub-chapter on dwellings is finished.

analyzed: bhikkhussa aṭṭhaṅga yuttassa
translated: For a monk with eight factors, The agreement to instruct the nuns;

analyzed: idha ñatti catutthena anuññātā mahesinā
translated: Here, by means of the motion and the three announcements, It was allowed by the Great Sage.

analyzed: yaḥ tāyā sammataḥ bhikkhu garu dhammehi aṭṭhahi
translated: Any monk who is agreed upon, In regard to the eight serious rules,

analyzed: ekam sambahulāḥ vā api bhikkhuni saṅgham eva vā
translated: Either one or many, or even the entire Sangha of nuns,

original: Osārentova te dhamme, ovadeyya sace pana;🔽Ovādapariyosāne, tassa pācittiyaṃ siyā.
analyzed: osārento uva te dhamme ovadeyya sace pana  ovāda pariyosāne tassa pācittiyam siyā
translated: If he instructs them in those rules,🔽At the end of the instruction, there is an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: aññena pana dhammena ovadantassa dukkaṭam
translated: But if he instructs them in other rules, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: ekatas upasampannam garu dhammehi vā tathā
translated: Likewise, if he instructs those who have been fully admitted only on one side, in regard to the eight serious rules,

analyzed: bhikkhūnam santikeya iva upasampanna bhikkhunim
translated: A nun who has been fully admitted in the presence of the monks,

analyzed: tathā liṅga vipallāse pācittā iva pakāsitā
translated: Likewise, if the gender is reversed, it is declared to be an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: sammatassa api bhikkhussa dukkaṭam samudīritaṃ
translated: It is said that even a monk who is agreed upon commits an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: ovādam a niyādetvā dhammena aññena bhāsato
translated: If one does not give the instruction, But speaks about something else in accordance with the Teaching,

analyzed: vutte pi aññena uvadato tathā
translated: If one says, “In unity,” But instructs in a different way,

analyzed: ca vutte pi garu dhammehi dukkaṭam
translated: And if one says, “In division,” There is an offense of wrong conduct for each of the principles.

analyzed: a gaṇhantassa ovādam a paccāharataḥ api tam
translated: If one does not accept the instruction, Or if one does not go back to the instruction,

original: Ṭhapetvā dukkaṭaṃ bālaṃ, gilānaṃ gamikaṃ siyā.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā dukkaṭam bālam gilānam gamikam siyā
translated: Except if one is a newly ordained, a sick, or a traveling nun.

original: Adhamme pana kammasmiṃ, adhammanti ca saññino;
analyzed: adhamme pana kammasmiṃ adhammanti ca saññinaḥ
translated: But if it is an illegitimate legal procedure, And the nuns perceive it as such,

analyzed: vagge bhikkhuni saṅghasmim tika pācittiyam siyā
translated: In a divided Sangha of nuns, there are three kinds of offenses entailing confession.

analyzed: tathā vematikassa api dhammakammanti saññinaḥ
translated: In the same way, if one is unsure, Or if one perceives it as a legitimate legal procedure,

original: Nava pācittiyo vuttā, samaggepi ca tattakā.
analyzed: nava ca tattakā
translated: In a united Sangha, there are nine offenses entailing confession.

original: Navakānaṃ vasā dvinnaṃ, aṭṭhārasa bhavanti tā;
analyzed: navakānam vasāḥ dvinnam aṭṭhārasa bhavanti tāḥ
translated: There are nine for the junior nuns, and two for the senior nuns. Thus there are eighteen.

analyzed: dukkaṭam dhamma kamme pi satta rasavidham siyā
translated: There is an offense of wrong conduct for a legitimate legal procedure. Thus there are seventeen kinds.

original: “Osārehī”ti vutto vā, pañhaṃ puṭṭho katheti vā;
analyzed: osārehi iti vuttaḥ vā pañham puṭṭhaḥ kathā iti vā
translated: If one is asked, “Do you admit this?” or “Do you see this offense?” and one replies, “I’ll tell you,”🔽Or if one is asked a question and one replies, “I’ll explain,”

original: Sikkhamānāya vā neva, doso ummattakādino.🔽Vācuggatāva kātabbā, paguṇā dvepi mātikā;
analyzed: sikkhamānāya vā na iva doso ummattaka ādino  kātabbā paguṇā dve pi mātikā
translated: Or if one is a trainee nun, There is no offense if one is insane, etc.🔽One should speak with a pure mind. Both the list and the explanation are complete.

analyzed: suttantato ca cattāro bhāṇa vārā pakāsitā
translated: The four sections of the Monastic Code are taught in the discourses.

analyzed: ekaḥ parikatha atthāya kathā maggaḥ pakāsito
translated: One, for the sake of discussion, the path of discussion was revealed;

analyzed: maṅgala amaṅgala tthāya tissoyā iva anumodanā  uposatha ādi atthāya kamma akamma vinicchayo
translated: For the sake of what is and is not a blessing, there are just three rejoicings.🔽For the sake of the observance day, etc., the analysis of what is and is not a legal procedure;

analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam tathā ekam uttama atthassa pāpakam
translated: And likewise one meditation subject, the worst for the sake of the best.

analyzed: ettakam uggahetvāna pañca vassaḥ bahu sutaḥ
translated: Having learned just this much, one who has five rains and is learned

analyzed: muñcitvā nissayam kāmam vasitum labhati saro
translated: May, if he wishes, give up dependence and live as he likes.

analyzed: vibhaṅgāḥ dve paguṇāḥ byañjanāt
translated: Two, the text and the analysis, are recited by word of mouth;

original: Catūsvapi nikāyesu, eko vā potthakopi ca.
analyzed: catūsu api nikāyesu ekaḥ vā potthakaḥ api ca
translated: In all four Piṭakas, one, or even a book.

analyzed: kamma akammam ca vattāni uggahetabba mettakam
translated: This much should be learned: what is and is not a legal procedure, and the recitations;

original: Sabbantimaparicchedo, dasavasso sace pana.🔽Bahussuto disāmokkho, yenakāmaṃgamo siyā;
analyzed: sabba antima paricchedaḥ dasa vassaḥ sace pana  bahu ssutaḥ disāmokkhaḥ yena kāmaṃgamaḥ siyā
translated: If he has ten rains, the last section, all.🔽He is learned, a leader in the directions, he may go where he likes;

analyzed: parisam labhate kāmam upaṭṭhāpetum issaraḥ
translated: He may, if he wishes, get a following, and he is able to look after it.

analyzed: yassa sa aṭṭha katham sabbam vācuggam piṭaka ttayam
translated: He who has the whole of the eight-part text, the three Piṭakas recited by word of mouth,

analyzed: saḥ ayam bahussutaḥ nāma bhikkhunovādakaḥ siyā
translated: Is called “learned,” and he may be an adviser to bhikkhunīs.

analyzed: tīṇi aṅgāni dīpaye
translated: The three factors beginning with “not being disappointed” should be illustrated;

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ nayā
translated: The method of the origins, etc., is the same as that of the “words in the singular number.”

analyzed: ovāda kathā  pācitti garu dhammehi dhammena aññena vā pana
translated: The instruction.🔽In the offense entailing confession, in the serious offense,

analyzed: hoti atthaṅgate sūriye ovadantassa bhikkhunim
translated: Or in any other way, if he instructs a nun after sunset.

analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam sammatassa api bhikkhuno
translated: It is said that there is an offense entailing confession for a monk who is agreed upon,

analyzed: ekatas upasampannam ovadantassa dukkaṭam
translated: But an offense of wrong conduct for instructing a nun who is fully ordained only on one side.🔽And likewise if he instructs a nun after sunset,

analyzed: tathā anatthaṅgate sūriye gate atthanti saññinaḥ
translated: Or if he thinks it is after sunset when it is not,

original: Tattha vematikassāpi, hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ.🔽Uddesādinayenassa, anāpatti pakāsitā;
analyzed: tattha vematikassa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam  uddesa ādi nayena assa anāpatti pakāsitā
translated: Then there is an offense of wrong conduct for one who is unsure.🔽The non-offenses are explained in the same way as for the recitation,

analyzed: anantara samā sesā samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ nayā
translated: And the rest of the origins, etc., are the same as for the previous rule.

analyzed: atthaṅgata sūriya kathā
translated: The rule on after sunset.

analyzed: bhikkhunim ovadantassa gantvā bhikkhunu passayam
translated: If a monk goes to the nuns’ dwelling place to instruct the nuns,

analyzed: garu dhammehi aññatra kālā pācittiyam siyā
translated: Then, except if it is the right time, there is an offense entailing confession for each serious offense.

analyzed: sace a sammataḥ hoti hoti pācittiya dvayam
translated: If he is not agreed upon, there are two offenses entailing confession.

original: Atthaṅgate ca sūriye, sace vadati tīṇipi.
analyzed: atthaṅgate ca sūriye sace vadati tīṇipi
translated: And three if he speaks after sunset.

analyzed: aññena pana dhammena vadataḥ dukkaṭa dvayam
translated: But if he speaks about something else, there are two offenses of wrong conduct.

analyzed: ekam pācittiyam hoti bhikkhuno ratti hetukam
translated: There is one offense entailing confession for a monk because of the night.

analyzed: sammatassa api bhikkhussa hoti pācittiya dvayam
translated: And there are two offenses entailing confession for a monk who is agreed upon,

original: Garudhammanidānassa, sammatattā abhāvato.🔽Tassevaññena dhammena, ovadantassa dukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: garu dhamma nidānassa sammata ttā abhāvato  tassa ivaññena dhammena ovadantassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: Because of the source of the rules, because of the non-existence of the motion.🔽When advising with another rule, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: sammata ttā anāpatti ekā pācitti rattiyam
translated: Because of the motion, there’s no offense. One offense entailing confession a night.

analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam dukkaṭam itara dvaye
translated: It’s said there are three offenses entailing confession, and two offenses of wrong conduct.

analyzed: ekatas upasampannam ovadantassa dukkaṭam
translated: When advising one who’s fully ordained in one part, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: tathā aññena dhammena gantvā bhikkhun upassayam
translated: And likewise when going to the nuns’ dwelling place with another rule,

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayo sabbe kathinena samā matā
translated: The origins, etc., are all treated the same as in the robe-making ceremony.

analyzed: bhikkhu upassaya kathā
translated: The discussion of the nuns’ dwelling place.

analyzed: cīvara ādīnam atthāya ovadanti iti bhikkhunim
translated: When advising a nun, saying, “For the sake of robe-cloth, etc.,

original: Vadato sammate bhikkhu, tassa pācittiyaṃ siyā.
analyzed: vadataḥ sammate bhikkhu tassa pācittiyam siyā
translated: If a monk speaks to one who’s been approved, he may commit an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: tika pācittiyam vuttam tathā iva tika dukkaṭam
translated: It’s said there are three offenses entailing confession, and likewise three offenses of wrong conduct.

analyzed: saṅghena asammatam bhikkhum vadantassa ca dukkaṭam
translated: When speaking to a monk who hasn’t been approved by the Sangha, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: tathā iva an upasampannam sammatam vā a sammatam
translated: And likewise when speaking to one who’s fully ordained, whether approved or not,

analyzed: na dosaḥ āmisa atthāya ovadantassa bhāsato
translated: There’s no offense when advising for the sake of material gain.

original: Tathā ummattakādīnaṃ, anāpatti pakāsitā;🔽Idañhi tisamuṭṭhānaṃ, vedanā dukkhavedanā.
analyzed: tathā ummattaka ādīnam anāpatti pakāsitā  idam hi ti samuṭṭhānam vedanā dukkha vedanā
translated: And likewise for one who’s insane, etc.

analyzed: āmisa kathā
translated: This has three origins: with body, with speech, and with body and speech. The painful feeling is physical.

original: Sace bhikkhuniyā bhikkhu, dadeyya pana cīvaraṃ;
analyzed: sace bhikkhuniyāḥ bhikkhu dadeyya pana cīvaram
translated: If a monk gives a robe to a nun, except in exchange,

analyzed: aññātikāya pācitti ṭhapetvā pārivattakam
translated: There is an offense entailing confession for one who is unrelated.

analyzed: cīvarassa paṭiggāha sikkhāpada samaḥ nayaḥ
translated: The rule on the acceptance of a robe is similar.

analyzed: avasesaḥ mataḥ saddhim samuṭṭhāna ādinā pana
translated: The rest is said together with the origin story.

original: Tattha bhikkhuniyā dinnaṃ, cīvaraṃ idha bhikkhunā;
analyzed: tattha bhikkhuniyā dinnam cīvaram idha bhikkhunā
translated: Here, “given by a nun” means “given by a monk”.

analyzed: tattha nissaggiyam suddha pācitti idha sūcitā
translated: Here, the confession is about a relinquishment.

analyzed: cīvara dāna kathā
translated: The discussion of giving a robe.

original: Cīvaraṃ yo hi sibbeyya, sibbāpeyya parena vā;
analyzed: cīvaram yaḥ hi sibbeyya sibbāpeyya parena vā
translated: If a monk has a robe sewn by a nun, or if he has another do it,

analyzed: aññātikāya pācitti hoti bhikkhuniyā pana
translated: There is an offense entailing confession for a nun who is unrelated.

original: Yaṃ vā nivāsituṃ sakkā, yaṃ vā pārupanūpagaṃ;
analyzed: yam vā nivāsitum sakkāḥ yam vā
translated: What can be worn and what can be used as an upper robe:

analyzed: idam ettha mahā esinā
translated: This is what is meant by “robe” in this case.

original: Sayaṃ sūciṃ pavesetvā, sibbantassa ca bhikkhuno;
analyzed: sayam sūcim pavesetvā sibbantassa ca bhikkhuno
translated: If a monk himself inserts the needle,

analyzed: sūcinī haraṇe tassa pācittiyam udīritam
translated: Then for each stitch there is an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: satakkhattum pi vijjhitvā sakim nīharataḥ pana
translated: But if he inserts the needle only once, even to sew a thousand stitches,

original: Ekaṃ pācittiyaṃ vuttaṃ, payogassa vasā bahū.
analyzed: ekam pācittiyam vuttam payogassa vasāḥ bahū
translated: Then there is one offense entailing confession, because the effort is one.

analyzed: sibbā ti pana āṇatto avisesena bhikkhunā
translated: If a monk tells a nun to sew, without specifying whether she is related or not,

original: Niṭṭhāpeti sace sabbaṃ, ekaṃ pācittiyaṃ siyā.
analyzed: niṭṭhāpeti sace sabbam ekam pācittiyam siyā
translated: If he finishes it all, there’s one offense entailing confession.

original: “Yamettha cīvare kammaṃ, bhāro sabbaṃ tavā”ti hi;
analyzed: yam ettha cīvare kammam bhāro sabbam tava ati hi
translated: “The work on the robe here is yours. The burden is all yours,”

original: Āṇatto bhikkhunā sabbaṃ, niṭṭhāpeti sace pana.🔽Bhikkhussāṇāpakasseva, ekāyāṇattiyā pana;
analyzed: āṇattaḥ bhikkhunā sabbam niṭṭhāpeti sace pana  ekāya āṇattiyā pana
translated: And if he’s told by the monk to finish it all,🔽Then there’s an offense entailing confession for the one who tells,

analyzed: honti pācittiya āpatti aneka arāpathe pathe
translated: For each telling, on the path of many offenses.

analyzed: punappunāṇa apentassa an eka āṇattiyam pana

original: Kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ, ticittañca tivedanaṃ.🔽Cīvarasibbanakathā.🔽Bhikkhu bhikkhuniyā saddhiṃ, saṃvidhāya panekato;🔽Paṭipajjeyya maggaṃ ce, aññatra samayā idha.

translated: It originates in body and mind; it’s an offense when there is a transaction, and it’s a contravention that’s clearable by confession.🔽It’s action with three doors, and it’s originated by body and mind. It’s verbal action, it’s action that is done, and it’s action that is stored up. It’s action that is both done and stored up. It’s action to be experienced as pleasure, and it’s action to be experienced as neither pleasure nor pain. It’s action to be experienced in the next rebirth, and it’s action to be experienced in subsequent rebirths. It’s action that is dark with dark result, and it’s action that is bright with bright result. It’s action that is dark and bright with dark and bright result. It’s action that is neither dark nor bright with neither dark nor bright result, leading to the destruction of action. It’s action that is done and accumulated, and it’s action that is done but not accumulated. It’s action that is accumulated but not done, and it’s action that is neither done nor accumulated. It’s action that is done and then oversteps, and it’s action that is overstepped but not done. It’s action that is overstepped and then done, and it’s action that is neither overstepped nor done. It’s action that is done and then oversteps, and it’s action that is overstepped but not done. It’s action that is overstepped and then done

translated: he should give two to the Sangha and keep one himself, or give one to the Sangha and keep two himself, but not all three.🔽If he receives less than that,
