analyzed: apaheṇaka pātheyyam avasesam pi vā tatas  santakam ñātaka ādīnam tad ūnakam
translated: or if he receives what belongs to his relatives,🔽then there’s no offense in receiving.

analyzed: gaṇhataḥ api anāpatti tathā ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: The same applies to one who is insane, etc.

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ sabbe sañcaritta samā matā
translated: The origins, etc., are all to be recited in the same way as for the offense entailing suspension.”

analyzed: kāṇa mātu kathā  aññena pana pañcannam bhojanānam pavārito
translated: The account of Kāṇamātā🔽If one who has refused five kinds of staple food

original: Pācittinatirittaṃ ce, puna bhuñjati bhojanaṃ.🔽Asanaṃ bhojanañceva, hatthapāsābhihāratā;
analyzed: ce punar bhuñjati bhojanam  asanam bhojanam ca iva hattha pāsā abhihāra tā
translated: eats staple food again, after the meal, as a penance,🔽the seat, the food, the hand, the mouth, and the refusal:

analyzed: kāya vācā paṭikkhepaḥ pañcaṅgehi pavāraṇā
translated: the invitation is with five factors.

original: Odano sattu kummāso, maccho maṃsanti sabbaso;
analyzed: odanaḥ sattu kummāsaḥ macchaḥ maṃsanti sabbaso
translated: Rice, flour, porridge, fish, meat: all these,

original: Nippapañcena niddiṭṭhaṃ, bhojanaṃ pañcadhā mataṃ.🔽Odano tattha sattannaṃ, dhaññānaṃ odano mato;🔽Bhajjitānaṃ tu dhaññānaṃ, cuṇṇaṃ “sattū”ti vuccati.
analyzed: nippapañcena niddiṭṭham bhojanam pañcadhā matam  odano tattha sattannam dhaññānam odanaḥ mato  bhajjitānam tu dhaññānam cuṇṇam sattū ti vuccati
translated: Are known as food in the fivefold classification of the Vinaya.🔽Rice is considered as the rice of the seven kinds of grain;🔽The flour is the powder of the ground grain.

analyzed: kummāsaḥ yava kummāsaḥ macchaḥ vuccati odako
translated: Porridge is the porridge of barley; fish is called the water-animal;

analyzed: maṃsam pi kappiya maṃsam ayam ettha vinicchayo
translated: Meat is the allowable meat. This is the decision here.

original: Sāli vīhi yavo kaṅgu, varako godhumo tathā;
analyzed: sāli vīhi yavaḥ kaṅgu varakaḥ godhumaḥ tathā
translated: Rice, barley, millet, wild gram, green gram, beans, and wheat,

analyzed: kudrūsakā uti sattā ite dhaññā dhaññena desitā
translated: These seven grains are taught as grain by grain.

analyzed: sabbam kudrūsena iva dīpitam
translated: All kinds of grass, such as Sāmaka, are indicated by kudrūsaka;

analyzed: nīvāro sāliyam vutto varake varaka corako
translated: Nīvāra is said to be rice; in varaka, varakacoraka.

original: Sattannaṃ pana dhaññānaṃ, odano yāgu vā pana;
analyzed: sattannam pana dhaññānam odanaḥ yāgu vā pana
translated: But of the seven kinds of grain, rice or gruel,

analyzed: aṅga sampattiyā yuttā sañjanā iti pavāraṇam
translated: When endowed with the requisites of the component parts, it causes the invitation to be successful.

original: Hatthena gahitokāse, odhiṃ dasseti yā pana;
analyzed: hatthena gahitā ukāse odhim dasseti yā pana
translated: But if she shows the rice in the space held by the hand,

analyzed: yāgusā idha sabbā api odano ti pavuccati
translated: All the gruel here is called rice.

original: Abbhuṇhā pana yā yāgu, uddhanoropitā tanu;
analyzed: abbhuṇhā pana yā yāgu tanu
translated: But the gruel which is not boiled, which is thin,

original: Sace odhiṃ na dasseti, na janeti pavāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: sace odhim na dasseti na janeti pavāraṇam
translated: If he does not show the sign, he does not give rise to the invitation.

original: Puna sā sītalībhūtā, ghanabhāvaṃ gatā sace;
analyzed: punar sā sītalībhūtā ghana bhāvam gatā sace
translated: If, having become cool, it has become solid again,

original: Odhiṃ dasseti so pubbe, tanubhāvo na rakkhati.
analyzed: odhim dasseti saḥ pubbe tanu bhāvaḥ na rakkhati
translated: If he shows the sign, he does not protect his former thinness.

analyzed: takka dhañña rasa ādīni āropetvā bahūni pi
translated: Having stored up much grain, rice, and so on,

analyzed: phala paṇṇa kaḷīrāni pakkhipitvāna tattha ca
translated: And having put in it fruits, leaves, and vegetables,

analyzed: taṇḍule muṭṭhi matte pi pakkhipitvā pacanti ce
translated: If they cook even just a handful of rice,

original: Odhiṃ pana ca dasseti, sañjaneti pavāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: odhim pana ca dasseti sañjaneti pavāraṇam
translated: But show the sign, they give rise to the invitation.

analyzed: rase dhañña rase khīre vā ākiritvānaḥ odanam
translated: Having mixed rice-essence or milk with the rice,

original: “Yāguṃ gaṇhatha, yāgu”nti, vatvā denti sace pana.
analyzed: yāgum gaṇhatha yāgunti vatvā denti sace pana
translated: If they give it out, saying, “Take rice-gruel,”

analyzed: kiñca api tanukā sañjanā iti pavāraṇam
translated: Even if it is thin, it gives rise to the invitation.

original: Taṃ pacitvā sace denti, yāgusaṅgahitā pana.
analyzed: tam pacitvā sace denti yāgu saṅga hitā pana
translated: If they give it after cooking it, it is included in the rice-gruel.

analyzed: chupanti maccha maṃsam vā yāguyā
translated: If they mix fish or meat with the thin rice-gruel,

analyzed: sace sāsapa mattam pi paññāyati pavāraṇam
translated: If even just a grain is visible, the invitation is given.

analyzed: maccha maṃsa rasaḥ suddhaḥ saṃsattaḥ rasa yāgu vā
translated: Pure fish or meat essence, or rice-gruel mixed with essence,

analyzed: na ca a kappiya maṃsam vā sañjaneti pavāraṇam
translated: Or any kind of unallowable meat does not give rise to the invitation.

analyzed: ṭhapetvā vutta dhaññānam odanam pana sabbaso
translated: Except for the rice that has been mentioned, all the boiled rice,

analyzed: na odanaḥ
translated: And the rice of the bamboo, the millet, and so on, the boiled rice is not allowed.

original: Puthukā vā tato tāhi, katabhattampi sattupi;
analyzed: puthukā vā tato tāhi
translated: The various kinds of cakes, and also the flour made from those,

original: Suddhā na pana pūvā vā, pavārenti kadācipi.
analyzed: suddhāḥ na pana pūvāḥ vā pavārenti kadācipi
translated: The pure flour, and also the pastries, are never allowed.

analyzed: khara pākena vīhīnam taṇḍule pana
translated: When they have been cooked in a frying pan, the rice, and also the grain,

original: Koṭṭetvā denti taṃ cuṇṇaṃ, sattusaṅgahitaṃ mataṃ.
analyzed: koṭṭetvā denti tam cuṇṇam sattu saṅgahitam matam
translated: Having been crushed, they give the powder, which is considered to be included in the seven kinds of grain.

original: Bhajjitānaṃ tu vīhīnaṃ, na pavārenti taṇḍulā;
analyzed: bhajjitānam tu vīhīnam na pavārenti taṇḍulāḥ
translated: But the rice, when they have been roasted, is not allowed;

original: Tesaṃ pana ca yaṃ cuṇṇaṃ, taṃ janeti pavāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tesam pana ca yam cuṇṇam tam janeti pavāraṇam
translated: But the powder that is made from them causes the invitation ceremony.

analyzed: khara pākena bhaṭṭhānam vīhīnam kuṇḍakam pi ca
translated: When they have been cooked in a frying pan, the rice, and also the grain,

analyzed: sattunam modakaḥ vā api sañjanā iti pavāraṇam
translated: The modaka made from the seven kinds of grain causes the invitation ceremony.

analyzed: sama pākena bhaṭṭhānam sukkhānam ātapena ca
translated: When they have been cooked in a frying pan, the dry grain, and also by the heat,

original: Kuṇḍakaṃ pana vīhīnaṃ, na janeti pavāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: kuṇḍakam pana vīhīnam na janeti pavāraṇam
translated: The grain, when it is roasted, does not cause the invitation ceremony.

original: Lājā vā pana teheva, katabhattampi sattu vā;
analyzed: lājāḥ vā pana tehā iva kata bhattam pi sattu vā
translated: The parched grain, and also the flour made from those, and the cakes,

original: Khajjakaṃ pana suddhaṃ vā, na janeti pavāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: khajjakam pana suddham vā na janeti pavāraṇam
translated: The pure fried grain does not cause the invitation ceremony.

analyzed: pūritam mad śamaṃsehi tam jana iti pavāraṇam
translated: When it is filled with fish and meat, it causes the invitation ceremony;

original: Yaṃ kiñci bhajjitaṃ piṭṭhaṃ, na pavāreti suddhakaṃ.🔽Yavehi katakummāso, pavāreti, na cāparo;
analyzed: yam kiñci bhajjitam piṭṭham na pavāreti suddhakam  yavehi kata kummāso pavāreti na ca aparaḥ
translated: If any broken rice is pure, he does not invite with that.🔽If it is a full-moon day for barley, he invites with that, not with another.

analyzed: maccha maṃsesu vattabbam pākaṭa ttā na vijjati
translated: In the case of fish and meat, it is obvious, so it is not mentioned.

analyzed: khādanto kappiyam maṃsam nisedha iti a kappiyam
translated: If, while eating, he prohibits the allowable meat,

original: Na so tena pavāreti, avatthuttāti dīpitaṃ.
analyzed: na saḥ tena pavāreti dīpitam
translated: he does not invite with that. It is said that the basis is not fulfilled.

analyzed: tathā iva a kappiyam maṃsam khādantaḥ kappiyam sace
translated: If, while eating, he prohibits the unallowable meat,

analyzed: nisedheti pavāreti vatthuka ttā ati vaṇṇitam
translated: he invites with that. It is said that the basis is fulfilled.

original: Maṃsaṃ pana ca khādanto, kappiyaṃ vā akappiyaṃ;🔽Pavāreti nisedheti, kiñci kappiyabhojanaṃ.
analyzed: maṃsam pana ca khādanto kappiyam vā a kappiyam  pavāreti nisedheti kiñci kappiya bhojanam
translated: If, while eating, he invites with or prohibits the allowable or unallowable meat,🔽or any allowable food,

analyzed: sace a kappiyam maṃsam khādantaḥ uva a kappiyam
translated: If, while eating, he prohibits the unallowable meat,

original: Nisedhaṃ na pavāreti, tathā aññaṃ akappiyaṃ.🔽Sace ajjhohaṭaṃ hoti, sitthamekampi bhikkhunā;
analyzed: nisedham na pavāreti tathā aññam akappiyam  sace ajjhohaṭam hoti sittham ekam pi bhikkhunā
translated: he does not invite with that, nor with any other unallowable meat.🔽If there is any food in the bowl, in the hand, or in the mouth,

original: Patte hatthe mukhe vāpi, bhojanaṃ pana vijjati.
analyzed: patte hatthe mukhe vā api bhojanam pana vijjati
translated: even if it is just a grain of rice that has been received,

analyzed: pavāraṇa pahonam ce paṭikkhipati bhojanam
translated: If he refuses the invitation to eat,

original: Pavāreti sace natthi, na pavāreti katthaci.
analyzed: pavāreti sace natthi na pavāreti katthaci
translated: he invites if there is none, but not if there is any.

original: Gilitvā ca mukhe bhattaṃ, sesamādāya gacchati;
analyzed: gilitvā ca mukhe bhattam sesam ādāya gacchati
translated: Having eaten, he takes the rest, and goes away.

original: Antarā ca nisedhento, na pavāreti bhojanaṃ.
analyzed: antarā ca na bhojanam
translated: He stops in the middle, and doesn’t invite in regard to the meal.

original: Mukhe ca bhattaṃ gilitañca hatthe;🔽Bhattaṃ tu aññassa ca dātukāmo;
analyzed: mukhe ca bhattam gilitam ca hatthe  bhattam tu aññassa ca dātu kāmo
translated: Having eaten, and food in the mouth, in the hand,🔽He wants to give to another,

original: Patte ca bhattaṃ puna dātukāmo;🔽Paṭikkhipanto na pavārito so.
analyzed: patte ca bhattam puna dātu kāmaḥ  paṭikkhipantaḥ na pavārito so
translated: And wants to give again from the bowl.🔽He rejects, and he’s not invited.

original: Asanassa upacchedā, na pavāreti soti hi;
analyzed: asanassa upacchedā na pavāreti so ti hi
translated: Because of the cutting off of the seat, he doesn’t invite.

analyzed: kathayanti mahā paññā kāraṇa akāraṇaññunaḥ
translated: The greatly wise, who know cause and effect, say this.

original: Gaṇhato pacchimaṃ aṅgaṃ, dadato purimaṃ pana;
analyzed: gaṇhataḥ pacchimam aṅgam dadataḥ purimam pana
translated: The last factor is for the one who receives, the first for the one who gives.

original: Ubhinnaṃ aḍḍhateyyaṃ ce, vinā hatthaṃ pasāritaṃ.
analyzed: ubhinnam aḍḍhateyyam ce vinā hattham pasāritam
translated: If both are worth more than 1 1/2 māsaka coins, except if the hand is extended.

analyzed: tasmin abhihaṭam ṭhāne pavāraṇa pahonakam
translated: In that place where it’s brought, the amount for the invitation,

analyzed: tādisam bhuñjamānaḥ uva nisedha iti pavāritaḥ
translated: While eating like that, he rejects, and he’s invited.

original: Hatthe ādhārake vāpi, pattaṃ ūrūsu vā ṭhitaṃ;
analyzed: hatthe ādhārake vā api pattam ūrūsu vā ṭhitam
translated: If the bowl is placed in the hand or on the lap,

analyzed: āharitvā sace bhikkhu bhattam gaṇhāti bhāsati
translated: and the monk says, “Take the food,”

analyzed: anantare nisinnaḥ iva tam paṭikkhipataḥ pana
translated: If he rejects it while sitting right next to him,

analyzed: abhihārassa ca abhāvā natthi tassa pavāraṇā
translated: because there’s no bringing, there’s no invitation for him.

analyzed: bhatta pacchim paṇāmetvā ṭhapetvā puratas idam
translated: Having sent away the food-preparer, and having placed it in front of him, saying, “Take this,”

analyzed: gaṇhāhi iti ca vutte pi ayam eva vinicchayaḥ
translated: and also saying, “Take this,” the same decision applies.

analyzed: anantarassa bhikkhussa dīyamāne pana itaro
translated: But when it is being given to the next monk, the other,

original: Pidahanto sakaṃ pattaṃ, hatthehi na pavārito.
analyzed: pidahantaḥ sakam pattam hatthehi na pavārito
translated: covering his own bowl with his hands, is not refused.

original: Kāyenābhihaṭaṃ bhattaṃ, paṭikkhipati yo pana;🔽Kāyena vāpi vācāya, hoti kassa pavāraṇā.
analyzed: kāyena abhihaṭam bhattam paṭikkhipati yaḥ pana  kāyena vā api vācāya hoti kassa pavāraṇā
translated: But if he refuses the food that has been brought with his body,🔽it is the one who has refused with his body or with speech that has the invitation.

analyzed: ekaḥ abhihaṭe bhatte pavāraṇa bhayā pana
translated: But if, out of fear of the invitation, he says, “Bring it,”

analyzed: ākira ākira koṭṭetvā koṭṭetvā pūrayāti ca
translated: and then says, “Throw it away, throw it away,” and “Fill it, fill it,”

original: Sace vadati tassāpi, na panatthi pavāraṇā;
analyzed: sace vadati tassa api na panatthi pavāraṇā
translated: if he says, “If you want, take it,” there is no invitation for him.

analyzed: iccā iva āha mahā theraḥ mahāpaduma nāmakaḥ
translated: This is just what the Elder Mahāpaduma said.

original: Samaṃsañhi rasaṃ netvā, gaṇhathāti rasaṃ vade;
analyzed: samaṃsan hi rasam netvā gaṇhatha ati rasam vade
translated: Having brought the taste of meat, saying, “Take the taste,”

original: Taṃ sutvā ca nisedhento, neva hoti pavārito.
analyzed: tam sutvā ca nisedhentaḥ na iva hoti pavāritaḥ
translated: having heard that, and refusing it, he is not refused.

analyzed: gaṇha maccha rasam sāram gaṇha vā
translated: “Take the essence of fish-taste,” or “Take the essence of meat,”

analyzed: idam gaṇhāti vā vutte paṭikkhepe pavāraṇā
translated: or if he says, “Take this,” there is an invitation when he refuses.

original: Sace maṃsaṃ visuṃ katvā, “gaṇha maṃsarasa”nti vā;
analyzed: sace maṃsam visum katvā gaṇha vā
translated: But if he says, “Take the essence of meat,” having made the meat separate,

original: Vadeyyatthi ca maṃsaṃ ce, paṭikkhepe pavāraṇā.
analyzed: vadeyya atthi ca maṃsam ce paṭikkhepe pavāraṇā
translated: If he says, “There is meat,” and refuses, the invitation is canceled.

analyzed: odanena ca pucchantam muhuttam
translated: If he asks about the rice, and is told to wait a moment,

original: Gahaṇatthaṃ ṭhapentassa, neva tassa pavāraṇā.🔽Kaḷīrapanasādīhi, missakaṃ macchamaṃsakaṃ;
analyzed: gahaṇa attham ṭhapentassa na iva tassa pavāraṇā  kaḷīra panasa ādīhi missakam maccha maṃsakam
translated: And if he sets it aside for the purpose of storing it, his invitation is not canceled.🔽If it is mixed with kale, beans, etc., or with fish or meat,

analyzed: kaḷīra sūpakam gaṇha panasa byañjananti vā
translated: Or if he is told, “Take the kale soup,” or “The beans as a relish,”

original: Vadanti ce paṭikkhepe, neva hoti pavāraṇā;
analyzed: vadanti ce paṭikkhepe na iva hoti pavāraṇā
translated: If he says, “I refuse,” the invitation is canceled.

analyzed: apavāraṇa hetūnam nāmena pana vuttataḥ
translated: Because the reasons for refusing are stated by name.

analyzed: maccha sūpanti vā vutte maṃsa sūpanti vā pana
translated: If he is told, “Fish soup,” or “Meat soup,”

original: “Idaṃ gaṇhā”ti vā vutte, hotiyeva pavāraṇā.🔽Eseva ca nayo vutto, ñeyyo maṃsakarambake;
analyzed: idam gaṇhāti vā vutte hotiyā iva pavāraṇā  esa iva ca nayaḥ vuttaḥ ñeyyaḥ maṃsa karambake
translated: Or “Take this,” the invitation is still valid.🔽This is the rule given for meat broth.

analyzed: sabbesu maccha maṃsehi missakesu ayam nayo
translated: The same rule applies to all fish and meat mixed together.

original: Bhattasammissitaṃ yāguṃ, āharitvā sace pana;🔽“Yāguṃ gaṇhā”ti vuttasmiṃ, na pavāreti vārayaṃ.
analyzed: bhatta sammissitam yāgum āharitvā sace pana  yāgum gaṇhāti vuttasmin na pavāreti vārayan
translated: If he has brought back rice gruel mixed with rice,🔽And if he is told, “Take the gruel,” he should not invite with the rice.

analyzed: bhattam gaṇhāti vutte tu pavāreti paṭikkhipam
translated: But if he is told, “Take the rice,” he should invite with the rice, refusing the gruel.

analyzed: yena vā a pucchitaḥ tassa atthi tāya ati kāraṇam
translated: The reason is that he is invited by the one who is asked.

original: “Yāgumissakaṃ gaṇhā”ti, vutte tattha ca yāgu ce;
analyzed: yāgu missakam gaṇhāti vutte tattha ca yāgu ce
translated: If he says, “Take the rice with the curry,” and there is curry there,

original: Samā bahutarā vā sā, na pavāreti so kira.
analyzed: samā bahutarā vā sā na pavārā iti sā u kira
translated: Either the same amount or more, he should not invite.

original: Mandā yāgu, bahuṃ bhattaṃ, sace hoti pavāraṇā;
analyzed: mandā bahum bhattam sace hoti pavāraṇā
translated: If there is little curry and much rice, if there is an invitation,

original: Idaṃ sabbattha niddiṭṭhaṃ, kāraṇaṃ pana duddasaṃ.
analyzed: idam sabbattha niddiṭṭham kāraṇam pana duddasam
translated: This is the rule everywhere, but the reason is hard to see.

original: Rasaṃ bahurase bhatte, khīraṃ vā bahukhīrake;
analyzed: rasam bahu rase bhatte khīram vā bahu khīrake
translated: If there is rice with many curries, or milk with much rice,

original: Gaṇhathāti visuṃ katvā, deti natthi pavāraṇā.🔽Gacchanteneva bhottabbaṃ, gacchanto ce pavārito;
analyzed: gaṇhatha ati visum katvā deti natthi pavāraṇā  gacchantena iva bhottabbam gacchantaḥ ce pavārito
translated: If he says, “Take separately,” and gives, there is no invitation.🔽If he is invited while walking, he should eat while walking. If he is invited while standing,

analyzed: bhuñjitabbam ṭhitena iva ṭhatvā yadi pavāritaḥ
translated: He should eat while standing.

original: Udakaṃ vāpi patvā so, sace tiṭṭhati kaddamaṃ;
analyzed: udakam vā api patvā saḥ sace tiṭṭhati kaddamam
translated: If he is invited while standing in water or mud,

original: Atirittaṃ tu kāretvā, bhuñjitabbaṃ tato puna.
analyzed: atirittam tu kāretvā bhuñjitabbam tato puna
translated: If he makes it overflow, he may then eat.

original: Pīṭhake yo nisīditvā, pavāreti sace pana;
analyzed: pīṭhake yaḥ nisīditvā sace pana
translated: If he invites while sitting on a bench,

analyzed: āsanam a vicāletvā bhuñjitabbam yathāsukham
translated: He may eat comfortably without moving the seat.

original: Sace mañce nisīditvā, pavāreti tato pana;
analyzed: sace mañce nisīditvā tatas pana
translated: If he invites while lying on a bed,

original: Ito saṃsarituṃ etto, īsakampi na labbhati.
analyzed: itas saṃsaritum ettas na labbhati
translated: He is not allowed to move even a little.

original: Tena mañcena naṃ saddhiṃ, vaṭṭataññatra nenti ce;
analyzed: tena mañcena nam saddhim ce
translated: If they carry him away together with the bed,

original: Evaṃ sabbattha ñātabbaṃ, viññunā vinayaññunā.🔽Nipajjitvāva bhottabbaṃ, nipanno ce pavārito;
analyzed: evam sabbattha ñātabbam viññunā vinaya ññunā  nipajjitvā ava bhottabbam nipannaḥ ce pavāritaḥ
translated: This is how it should be understood everywhere by the wise, by those skilled in the Monastic Law.🔽Having lain down, he should eat; if he is lying down, he should be invited;

analyzed: hutvā bhuñjitabbam tathā iva ca
translated: He should eat, having become a “rooster-in-vow,” and in the same way.

analyzed: atha alam etam sabban ti vattabbam tena bhikkhunā
translated: Then he should say, “This is all for me,” and that monk,

analyzed: atirittam karontena onam etvāna bhājanam
translated: making it leftover, should lower his bowl.

original: Kappiyaṃ pana kātabbaṃ, na patteyeva kevalaṃ;
analyzed: kappiyam pana kātabbam na patteya iva kevalam
translated: But it should be made allowable; not just in the bowl.

original: Pacchiyaṃ yadi vā kuṇḍe, kātuṃ vaṭṭati bhājane.
analyzed: yadi vā kuṇḍe kātum vaṭṭati bhājane
translated: If it is in a dish, or in a pot, it is allowable to make it allowable in the vessel.

analyzed: pavāritānam apavāritānam
translated: For those who have been invited and those who haven’t been invited,

analyzed: pana vaṭṭatā iva
translated: but for others it is allowable.

analyzed: yena atirittam tu katam ṭhapetvā
translated: Except for the one who has made it leftover,

analyzed: tam eva ca ikam paribhuñjitabbam
translated: he should eat just that one.

analyzed: kappiyam pana kāretvā bhuñjantassa iva bhikkhunaḥ
translated: But if a monk is eating after making it allowable,

original: Byañjanaṃ vāpi yaṃ kiñci, patte tassākiranti ce.
analyzed: byañjanam vā api yam kiñci patte ce
translated: and if they pour any kind of seasoning into his bowl,

original: Atirittaṃ tu kāretvā, bhuñjitabbaṃ tathā puna;
analyzed: atirittam tu kāretvā bhuñjitabbam tathā puna
translated: he should make it leftover again, and then eat it.

original: Yena taṃ akataṃ yaṃ vā, kātabbaṃ tena taṃ visuṃ.
analyzed: yena tam a katam yam vā kātabbam tena tam visum
translated: He should do that separately from the one who did not make it allowable.

analyzed: katam akappiya ādīhi atirittam tu sattahi
translated: Made allowable, etc., and leftover by seven things,

original: Na gilānātirittañca, taṃ hotinatirittakaṃ.🔽Yopi pātova ekampi, sitthaṃ bhutvā nisīdati;🔽Upakaṭṭhūpanītampi, kātuṃ labhati kappiyaṃ.
analyzed: na gilāna atirittam ca tam hotin atirittakam  yaḥ api ekam pi sittham bhutvā nisīdati  upakaṭṭhu upanītam pi kātum labhati kappiyam
translated: If it’s not excessive for the sick, it’s not excessive for the healthy.🔽If one who has eaten a single grain of cooked rice in the morning🔽Sits down to receive what is allowable, even if it’s brought to him.

analyzed: āhāra atthāya yāma ādi kālikam paṭigaṇhato
translated: If one receives food for the purpose of eating it at the wrong time,

original: Anāmisaṃ tamevassa, dukkaṭaṃ paribhuñjato.🔽Tathā anatirittanti, saññino atirittake;
analyzed: anāmisam tam eva assa dukkaṭam paribhuñjato  tathā saññinaḥ atirittake
translated: It’s not a wrong means of livelihood, but a misdeed for one who eats it.🔽Likewise, if one who is not sick receives what is not excessive

original: Tattha vematikassāpi, dukkaṭaṃ paridīpitaṃ.🔽Anāpattātirittaṃ tu, kārāpetvāna bhuñjato;
analyzed: tattha vematikassa api dukkaṭam paridīpitam  anāpatta atirittam tu bhuñjataḥ
translated: But thinks it is, and if one is unsure about it, it’s also taught to be a misdeed.🔽But if it’s not excessive and one receives it, thinking it is,🔽And then eats it, there’s no offense. The same applies to what is excessive for the sick,

analyzed: gilānassa atirittam vā tathā ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: And to one who is insane, etc.

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayo sabbe kathinena samā matā
translated: All the origins, etc., are the same as for the kaṭhina cloth.

analyzed: kappiyākaraṇam ca iva bhojanam ca kriyākriyam
translated: The making allowable, the eating, and the action and its result:

analyzed: paṭhama apavāraṇa kathā  yaḥ pana an atirittena pavāreyya pavāritam
translated: The first section on invitations is finished.🔽If one invites, having received what is excessive,

original: Jānaṃ āsādanāpekkho, bhutte pācitti tassa tu.🔽Dukkaṭaṃ abhihāre ca, gahaṇe itarassa hi;
analyzed: jānam āsādana apekkhaḥ bhutte pācitti tassa tu  dukkaṭam abhihāre ca gahaṇe itarassa hi
translated: And if one knows that the other is expecting to get something, then when the other has eaten, there’s an offense entailing confession for the inviter.🔽For the one who is invited, there’s a serious offense for the effort in receiving,

analyzed: ajjhohāra payogesu ca dukkaṭam
translated: And a serious offense for the effort in eating, and for all the efforts in eating.

analyzed: pācitti paridīpitā
translated: At the end of the meal, an offense entailing confession is specified.

analyzed: abhihāraka bhikkhussa sabbam tassa iva dassitam
translated: For a monk who is bringing it, everything is shown to belong to him.

original: Pavāritoti saññissa, bhikkhusmiṃ apavārite;🔽Vimatissubhayatthāpi, dukkaṭaṃ paridīpitaṃ.
analyzed: pavārito ti saññissa bhikkhusmiṃ a pavārite  vimatiḥ su ubhayatthā api dukkaṭam paridīpitam
translated: When he perceives that the invitation has been refused, when a monk has refused the invitation,🔽When there is doubt or fear, a wrong-doing is specified.

analyzed: anāpatta atirittam vā deti ce
translated: There is no offense if he has not had enough, or if he has it made and then gives it,

analyzed: gilānassa avasesam vā aññassa atthāya deti vā
translated: Or if it is the remainder of what belongs to one who is sick, or if he gives it for the benefit of another.
The rest is all without remainder, considered to be the same as the preceding.

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ
translated: The origins, etc., are the same as for the offense entailing confession for criticizing.

analyzed: dutiya pavāraṇa kathā
translated: The second discussion of the invitation ceremony.

original: Khādanīyaṃ vā bhojanīyaṃ vā;🔽Kiñci vikāle yo pana bhikkhu;
analyzed: khādanīyam vā bhojanīyam vā  kiñci vikāle yaḥ pana bhikkhu
translated: Any fresh or cooked food,

analyzed: khādati bhuñjati vā api ca tam
translated: If a monk eats or consumes it at the wrong time,

analyzed: saḥ jina vuttam dosam upeti
translated: He commits an offense prescribed by the Buddha.

analyzed: yama āmisa gatam ca itthā vana mūla phala ādikam
translated: Here, if it is from the human realm,

analyzed: veditabbam idam pana
translated: This should be understood as being due to confusion about the right time.🔽Roots, tubers, stems,

original: Mūlaṃ kandaṃ muḷālañca, matthakaṃ khandhakaṃ tacaṃ;🔽Pattaṃ pupphaṃ phalaṃ aṭṭhi, piṭṭhaṃ niyyāsameva ca.
analyzed: mūlam kandam muḷālam ca matthakam khandhakam tacam 🔽pattam puppham phalam aṭṭhi piṭṭham niyyāsam eva ca
translated: Flowers, fruits, seeds, husks,

analyzed: mūla khādanīya ādīnam mukha matta nidassanam
translated: The root, the stalk, etc., are shown in the mouth,

original: Bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭavatthāya, nāmatthesu nibodhatha.🔽Mūlakaṃ khārakañceva, vatthulaṃ taṇḍuleyyakaṃ;
analyzed: bhikkhūnam pāṭava tthāya nāmatthesu nibodhatha  mūlakam khārakam ca iva vatthulam taṇḍuleyyakam
translated: For the sake of the bhikkhus’ clear understanding,🔽In the case of the root, the stalk, the leaf, the flower, and the fruit,

analyzed: tambakam ca caccu vaja kalīpi ca
translated: The bark, the inner bark, the branch, the twig, and the dust-heap articles.

analyzed: mūlāni evamādīnam āmise pana
translated: The roots, etc., of these and other vegetables,

original: Saṅgahaṃ idha gacchanti, āhāratthaṃ pharanti hi.🔽Chaḍḍenti jaraṭṭhaṃ chetvā, yaṃ taṃ vajakalissa tu;
analyzed: saṅgaham idha gacchanti āhāra attham pharanti hi  chaḍḍenti jaraṭṭham chetvā yam tam vajakalissa tu
translated: Are included here, for they serve as food.🔽Having cut off the old, they throw it away,🔽Which is the dust-heap article. It is said that this is for life,

original: Taṃ yāvajīvikaṃ vuttaṃ, sesānaṃ yāvakālikaṃ.🔽Haliddi siṅgiverañca, vacattaṃ ativisaṃ vacaṃ;
analyzed: tat yāvajīvikam vuttam sesānam yāvakālikam  haliddi siṅgiveram ca vacattam ativisam vacam
translated: The rest are for a limited time.🔽Turmeric, ginger, garlic, the three spices,

analyzed: usīram bhadda muttam ca tathā kaṭukarohiṇī
translated: Ushira, bhaddamutta, and the bitter cucumber.

analyzed: iccā ivamādikam aññam pañcamūla ādikam bahu
translated: Thus and in other ways there are many,🔽Such as the five-rooted, etc., which should be understood as the roots,

analyzed: nānā pakārakam mūlam viññeyyam yāvajīvikam
translated: Which are for life.

analyzed: masā ālu piṇḍala ādīnam vallīnam āluvassa ca
translated: The bulb of the masalu, the piṇḍola, etc., the creeper, the ālu,

analyzed: kandaḥ uppala jātīnam tathā
translated: The bulb of the lotus family, and also of the paduma family,

analyzed: kadalī siggu tālānam māluvassa ca veḷuyā
translated: The bulb of the plantain, the siggu, the tāla, the māluva, and the bamboo,

analyzed: kaserūnam kandaḥ ambāṭakassa ca
translated: The root of the satāvari, the kaseruka, and the ambaṭṭhaka,

analyzed: id ca ivamādayaḥ kandā
translated: These and other such roots

original: Dassitā yāvakālikā;🔽Dhoto so āmise vutto;🔽Kando yo khīravalliyā.
analyzed: dassitā yāvakālikā  dhoto so āmise vutto  kandaḥ yaḥ khīravalliyā
translated: Are shown as being for a limited time.🔽The root of the milk-hedge plant, when washed, is said to be for a limited time.

analyzed: adhas taḥ lasuṇam ca iva khīra kākoli ādayaḥ
translated: The garlic, and the khīraka, the kākoli, and so on,

analyzed: kandā vākya patha atītā viññeyyā yāvajīvikā

analyzed: puṇḍarīka muḷālam ca muḷālam padumassa ca

analyzed: evamādim anekam pi muḷālam yāvakālikam

analyzed: haliddi siṅgiverānam muḷālam yāvajīvikam
translated: The muḷāla of the turmeric, the siṅgīvera, and the veḷu, is for as long as one lives.

analyzed: tāla hintāla kuntāla kaḷīraḥ ketakassa ca  matthakam mūlakassa ca
translated: The kaḷīra of the tāla, the hintāla, the kuntāla, the ketaka,🔽The top of the kadalī, the nāḷikeraka, and the root of the mūlaka,

analyzed: ucchu veḷu naḷa ādinam
translated: The ucchu, the veḷu, the naḷa, and so on, of the khajjirika, the raka, the vetta,

original: Sattannaṃ pana dhaññānaṃ, kaḷīro sāsapassa ca.🔽Iccevamādayoneke, matthakā yāvakālikā;
analyzed: sattannam pana dhaññānam kaḷīro sāsapassa ca  iti ca ivamādayaḥ na eke matthakāḥ yāvakālikā
translated: And the kaḷīra of the seven kinds of grain, and the sāsapam,🔽These and many other such tops are for a limited time.

analyzed: aññe haliddi ādīnam matthakāḥ yāvajīvikā
translated: Others, the top of the turmeric and so on, are for as long as one lives.

analyzed: chinditvā pana
translated: The tāla, the kuntāla, and so on, when cut down and fallen,

analyzed: gataḥ jaraṭṭhabundaḥ saḥ saṅgaham yāvajīvike
translated: The old bundle has gone, the bundle for life is included.

analyzed: khandhakhādanīyam nāma ucchu khandhaḥ pakāsito

analyzed: sālakalyāṇiyā khandho tathā pathaviyam gataḥ
translated: The handful of Sālakali, and likewise the handful on the ground.

analyzed: evam uppala jātīnam daṇḍakaḥ yāvakālikaḥ
translated: Thus the handful of the Upajāti, the handful for the time being;

analyzed: paṇṇa daṇḍu ppala ādīnam paduma jātiyā
translated: The handful of leaves, the handful of lotus, etc., all of the lotus species.

analyzed: yāvajīvika saṅkhātā kara madda ādi daṇḍakā
translated: The handful for life is called, the handful of sugarcane, etc.;

analyzed: sarasaḥ
translated: And the handful of the well-versed one, the handful of the eloquent one for the time being.

analyzed: mūlakam khārako caccu tambako taṇḍuleyyako
translated: The root, the alkali, the shell, the tobacco, the rice,

original: Vatthulo cīnamuggo ca, ummā vajakalī tathā.
analyzed: vatthulaḥ cīnamuggaḥ ca ummā vajakalī tathā
translated: The cloth, the Chinese mung bean, the umma, the vajaka, and likewise.

original: Jajjharī kāsamaddo ca, sellu siggu ca nāḷikā;
analyzed: jajjharī kāsamaddaḥ ca sellu siggu ca nāḷikā
translated: The jajjhari, the kāsamadda, the sellu, the siggu, the nāḷikā;

analyzed: varuṇaḥ aggimanthaḥ ca jīvantī sunisannakaḥ
translated: The varuṇa, the agga, the mantha, the jīvantī, the sunisannaka.

original: Rājamāso ca māso ca, nipphāvo migapupphikā;
analyzed: rājamāsaḥ ca māso ca nipphāvaḥ migapupphikā
translated: The rājamāsa, the māsa, the nipphāva, the migapupphikā;

analyzed: vaṇṭakaḥ bhūmiloṇī iti evamādim anekakam
translated: The vaṇṭaka, the bhūmiloṇī, thus and so on in many ways.

original: Pattakhādanīyaṃ nāma, kathitaṃ yāvakālikaṃ;🔽Itarā ca mahāloṇi, dīpitā yāvajīvikā.
analyzed: pattakhādanīyam nāma kathitam yāvakālikam  itarā ca mahāloṇi dīpitā yāvajīvikā
translated: The edible by the handful is called, the handful for the time being is explained;🔽And the great salt, the outcome for life is shown.

analyzed: kathitam ambapallavam
translated: The handful for the time being is called, the tender mango shoot is explained;

analyzed: nimbassa kuṭajassa api paṇṇam sulasiyā api ca
translated: Of the nimba, the kuṭaja, the sulasi,

analyzed: kappāsika paṭolānam tesam puppha phalāni ca
translated: Of the kaṇikāra, the paṭola, and of the flowers and fruits of these,

analyzed: phaṇijja kajjukānam ca paṇṇam tam yāvajīvikam
translated: Of the phaṇijjaka and the jujube, the leaves of these are for life-long use.

analyzed: aṭṭhannam mūlaka ādīnam puppham nipphāvakassa ca
translated: Of the eight roots, etc., the flowers of the nipphāka,

original: Tathā pupphaṃ karīrassa, pupphaṃ varuṇakassa ca.🔽Pupphaṃ kaserukassāpi, jīvantī siggupupphakaṃ;
analyzed: tathā puppham karīrassa puppham varuṇakassa ca
translated: And likewise the flowers of the karīra, the flowers of the varuṇaka,🔽The flowers of the kaseruka, the jīvantī, the sigru, the flowers of the pupphaka,

analyzed: paduma uppala jātīnam pupphānam kaṇṇikā api ca
translated: The flowers of the lotus, the uppaṭipus, the kaṇṇikā,

analyzed: nāḷikerassa tālassa taruṇam ketakassa ca
translated: The tender fruit of the coconut palm, the tāla, and the ketaka,

analyzed: iccā ivamādikam puppham anekam yāvaka ālikam
translated: Thus, these and other flowers are for temporary use.

analyzed: yāvaka ālika pupphāni ṭhapetvā pana sesakam
translated: Having set aside the flowers for temporary use, all the rest,

analyzed: yāvajīvika pupphanti dīpaye sabbam eva ca
translated: One should know, are flowers for life-long use.

analyzed: tilaka makula sāla mallikā nam
translated: The tilaka, the makulasa, the sāla, the mallikā,

analyzed: kakudha kapittha kakunda kaḷīnam

analyzed: kuravaka karavīra pāṭalīnam
translated: The kuravaka, the karavīra, the pāṭalī,

analyzed: kusumam idam pana yāvajīvikam  amba ambāṭaka jambūnam phalam ca panasassa ca
translated: These flowers are for life-long use.🔽The fruits of the mango, the ambaṭaka, the rose-apple, and of the breadfruit tree,

analyzed: mātuluṅga kapitthānam phalam tintiṇikassa ca
translated: The fruits of the mātuṅga, the kapittha, the tintiṇī, and the tintiṇikā,

analyzed: tālassa nāḷikerassa phalam khajjūriyā api ca

analyzed: labujassa ca cocassa mocassa madhukassa ca

analyzed: badarassa karamaddassa phalam vātiṅgaṇassa ca

analyzed: rājāyatana phalam pussa phalam timbarukassa ca
translated: The fruit of the rājāyata, the pussa, the timbarusa,

analyzed: evamādim anekam pi phalam tam yāvakālikam  tiphalam pipphalī jātiphalam ca kaṭukapphalam

analyzed: pana sambāṭa kaṭṭhīni sālaṭṭhi labujaṭṭhi ca

analyzed: evamādīni gacchanti yāvakālika saṅgaham

analyzed: punnāga madhuka aṭṭhīni sellaṭṭhi tiphalaṭṭhi ca

analyzed: evamādīni aṭṭhīni niddiṭṭhāni anāmise
translated: These and other bones, too, are stated by Anāthapiṇḍika.

analyzed: sattannam pana dhaññānam aparaṇṇānam eva ca  piṭṭham panasa sālānam labu jambāṭakassa ca
translated: But of the seven kinds of grain, and also of the other kinds,🔽The powder of the bread-fruit, the jack-fruit, the rose-apple,

analyzed: tāla piṭṭham tathā dhotam piṭṭham yam khīravalliyā
translated: The powder of the palmyra fruit, likewise, the powder of the milk-hedge plant,

analyzed: evamādim anekam api kathitam yāvakālikam
translated: These and many other kinds are said to be allowable for a time.

analyzed: tāla piṭṭham ca piṭṭham yam khīravalliyā
translated: The unwashed palmyra powder, the powder of the milk-hedge plant,

analyzed: assa gandha ādi piṭṭham ca hoti tam yāvajīvikam
translated: The powder of the assafœtida, etc., are allowable as long as life lasts.

analyzed: niyyāsaḥ ucchu nibbattaḥ ekaḥ satta aha kāliko
translated: The exudation is produced from the sap, it is allowable for seven days,

analyzed: avasesaḥ ca hiṅga ādi niyyāsaḥ yāvajīviko

analyzed: mūla ādīsu mayā kiñci mukha mattam nidassitam

analyzed: etassa iva anusārena sesaḥ ñeyyaḥ vibhāvinā
translated: By following this same method the rest should be understood by the discerning.

analyzed: bhuñjissāmi vikāleti āmisam paṭigaṇhataḥ
translated: When he receives a material thing thinking “I will eat it out of time,”

analyzed: kāle vikāla saññissa kāle vematikassa ca
translated: If it is time he perceives it as out of time, and if it is time he is doubtful,
