analyzed: na iva chinditu kāmaḥ ce nikhaṇitvā pamāṇataḥ
translated: If he did not want to cut it off, he should bury it up to the measure.

original: Uttānaṃ vāpi aṭṭaṃ vā, bandhitvā paribhuñjato.
analyzed: uttānam vā api aṭṭam vā bandhitvā paribhuñjataḥ
translated: If he used it after binding it, either on its back or on its side,

analyzed: mañca kathā
translated: The bed frame.

original: Mañcaṃ vā pana pīṭhaṃ vā, tūlonaddhaṃ kareyya yo;
analyzed: mañcam vā pana pīṭham vā tūla ūnaddham kareyya yaḥ
translated: If one makes a bed or a bench With cotton wool,

analyzed: tassa uddālanakam vuttam pācittiyam anītinā
translated: It is said that he should pull out the cotton wool, And it is said that there is an offense entailing confession.

original: Anāpatti panāyoge, bandhane aṃsabaddhake;🔽Bibbohane parissāve, thavikādīsu bhikkhuno.
analyzed: anāpatti pana ayoge bandhane aṃsabaddhake  bibbohane parissāve thavika ādīsu bhikkhunaḥ
translated: There is no offense if it is not for oneself, If it is a strap for the shoulder,🔽If it is a pillow or a cover, Or if it is a mat or the like.

original: Aññena ca kataṃ laddhā, uddāletvā nisevato;
analyzed: aññena ca katam laddhā uddāletvā nisevato
translated: And if he obtains one made by another, And uses it after pulling out the cotton wool,

analyzed: sañcaritta samāḥ nayā
translated: It is the same as the rule on trading, In regard to the next one.

analyzed: tūla ūnaddha kathā
translated: The cotton wool.

original: Nisīdanaṃ karontena, kātabbaṃ tu pamāṇato;🔽Pamāṇātikkame tassa, payoge dukkaṭaṃ siyā.
analyzed: nisīdanam karontena kātabbam tu pamāṇato  pamāṇa atikkame tassa payoge dukkaṭam siyā
translated: When making a sitting mat, It should be made to the right size.🔽If it exceeds the right size, There is an offense of wrong conduct for the effort.

analyzed: paṭilābhena sa chedam pācittiyam udīritam
translated: When it is finished, it is said, There is an offense entailing confession.

original: Dvīsu ṭhānesu phāletvā, tassa tisso dasā siyuṃ.
analyzed: dvīsu ṭhānesu phāletvā tassa tissaḥ dasāḥ siyuṃ
translated: If he tears it in two places, It should have three tines.

analyzed: anāpatti pamāṇena karontassa tad ūnakam
translated: There is no offense if he makes it, But less than the right size,

analyzed: vitāna ādim karontassa sañcaritta samā nayā
translated: If he makes a canopy or the like, It is the same as the rule on trading.

analyzed: nisīdana kathā
translated: The discussion of sitting mats.

original: Roge kaṇḍupaṭicchādi, kātabbā hi pamāṇato;🔽Pamāṇātikkame tassa, payoge dukkaṭaṃ siyā.🔽Paṭilābhena sacchedaṃ, pācittiyamudīritaṃ;
analyzed: roge kaṇḍu paṭicchā ādi kātabbā hi pamāṇato  pamāṇa atikkame tassa payoge dukkaṭam siyā  paṭilābhena sa chedam pācittiyam udīritam
translated: In a disease, a covering for the itch, should be made to the right size;🔽If it exceeds the right size, there is an offense of wrong conduct for the effort.🔽When it is finished, there is an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: anantarasamaḥ mataḥ
translated: The method for not committing an offense is considered to be the same as the immediately following one.

analyzed: kaṇḍu paṭi chādi kathā  pamāṇena iva kātabbā tathā vassika sāṭikā
translated: The discussion of a covering for the itch.🔽It should be made to the right size, and so too a rainy season robe;

analyzed: pamāṇa atikkame tassa anantarasamaḥ nayaḥ
translated: If it exceeds the right size, the method is the same as the immediately following one.

analyzed: vassika sāṭika kathā  cīvarena sace tulya ppamāṇam sugatassa tu
translated: The discussion of a rainy season robe.🔽If a monk makes a robe that is the same size as the one of the Accomplished One,

original: Cīvaraṃ bhikkhu kāreyya, karaṇe dukkaṭaṃ siyā.🔽Paṭilābhena sacchedaṃ, pācittiyamudīritaṃ;
analyzed: cīvaram bhikkhu kāreyya karaṇe dukkaṭam siyā  paṭilābhena sa chedam pācittiyam udīritam
translated: there is an offense of wrong conduct for the making.🔽When it is finished, there is an offense entailing confession.

analyzed: anāpatti nayaḥ mataḥ
translated: The method for not committing an offense is considered to be the same as the immediately following one.

original: Dīghaso ca pamāṇena, nava tassa vidatthiyo;
analyzed: dīghasaḥ ca pamāṇena nava tassa vidatthiyaḥ
translated: In length it is nine standard handspans of the Accomplished One,

analyzed: tiriyam cha viniddiṭṭhā sugatassa vidatthiyā
translated: and in width it is laid down as six standard handspans of the Accomplished One.

original: Aññena ca kataṃ laddhā, sevato dukkaṭaṃ bhave;
analyzed: aññena ca katam laddhā sevataḥ dukkaṭam bhave
translated: If he gets one made by another that is longer, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayaḥ sabbe sañcaritta samā matā
translated: All the origins, etc., are considered to be the same as in the case of the wandering on for alms.

analyzed: nanda kathā
translated: The discussion of Nandaka.

analyzed: rāja vaggaḥ navamaḥ
translated: The ninth sub-chapter on kings is finished.

analyzed: iti vinaya vinicchaye pācittiya kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The discussion of the offense entailing confession in the section on the Monastic Law is finished.

analyzed: pāṭidesanīya kathā
translated: The rules entailing acknowledgment🔽A monk who enters a house

original: Yo cantaragharaṃ bhikkhu, paviṭṭhāya tu hatthato;
analyzed: yaḥ cantara gharam bhikkhu paviṭṭhāya tu hatthataḥ
translated: and receives with his own hands🔽any kind of food

original: Aññātikāya yaṃ kiñci, tassa bhikkhuniyā pana.🔽Sahatthā paṭiggaṇheyya, khādanaṃ bhojanampi vā;
analyzed: aññātikāya yam kiñci tassa bhikkhuniyā pana  sahatthā paṭiggaṇheyya khādanam bhojanam pi vā
translated: from an unrelated nun,🔽whether fresh or cooked food,

analyzed: gahaṇe dukkaṭam bhoge pāṭidesaniyam siyā
translated: then at the time of receiving it, there is an offense of wrong conduct. When he eats it, there is an offense entailing acknowledgment.

analyzed: vā byūhe sandhi siṅghāṭakesu vā
translated: If he receives it while standing in a street, in a cul-de-sac, at an intersection, or at a shop,

original: Hatthisālādike ṭhatvā, gaṇhatopi ayaṃ nayo.🔽Rathikāya sace ṭhatvā, deti bhikkhuni bhojanaṃ;
analyzed: hatthi sāla ādike ayam nayaḥ  rathikāya sace ṭhatvā deti bhikkhuni bhojanaṃ
translated: or while standing in a place such as an elephant stable, the method is the same.🔽If a nun gives food while standing in a street,

original: Āpatti antarārāme, ṭhatvā gaṇhāti bhikkhu ce.
analyzed: āpatti antarārāme ṭhatvā gaṇhāti bhikkhu ce
translated: and a monk receives it while standing in a monastery,

analyzed: etthantara gharam tassā paviṭṭhāya hi vākyataḥ
translated: then the house is the monastery, and the words “who has entered” are understood.

analyzed: bhikkhussa ca ṭhita ṭṭhānam na pamāṇam ti vaṇṇitam
translated: The place where the monk is standing is not a measure.

analyzed: tasmā bhikkhuniyāḥ ṭhatvā ārāma ādīsu dentiyāḥ
translated: Therefore, if a nun gives food in a monastery, etc.,

original: Vīthiyādīsu ce ṭhatvā, na doso paṭigaṇhato.
analyzed: vīthiya ādīsu ce na dosaḥ paṭigaṇhato
translated: and if a monk receives it while standing in a street, etc., there is no offense.

analyzed: yāma kālika sattāha kālikam yāvajīvikam
translated: If it is one-day medicine, seven-day medicine, or lifetime medicine,

analyzed: āhāra atthāya gahaṇe ajjhohāre ca dukkaṭam
translated: When he receives it for the purpose of food, there’s an offense of wrong conduct for each act of receiving.

analyzed: āmisena a sambhinna rasam sandhāya bhāsitam
translated: This was said with reference to food that’s not mixed with flavors.

analyzed: siyā
translated: There’s an offense entailing acknowledgment when it’s mixed with flavors.

analyzed: ekatas upasampanna hatthataḥ paṭigaṇhato
translated: When receiving from the hand of someone who’s fully ordained in a single Buddhist sect,

analyzed: kālikānam catunnam pi āhāra atthāya dukkaṭam
translated: there’s an offense of wrong conduct for each of the four kinds of allowable food when it’s for the purpose of food.

analyzed: ñātikāya pi aññāti saññinaḥ vimatissa vā
translated: When the other person is a relative, but you perceive them as a non-relative, or you’re unsure of it,

analyzed: dukkaṭam ñāti saññissa tathā aññātikāya vā
translated: there’s an offense of wrong conduct when the other person is a non-relative, but you perceive them as a relative.

original: Dāpentiyā anāpatti, dadamānāya vā pana;🔽Nikkhipitvāntarārāmā-dīsu ṭhatvāpi dentiyā.
analyzed: dāpentiyāḥ anāpatti dadamānāya vā pana  nikkhipitvā antarārāma ādīsu dentiyā
translated: There’s no offense if the other person gives it;🔽if they give it after taking it out of the monastery grounds;

original: Gāmato nīharitvā vā, deti ce bahi vaṭṭati;
analyzed: gām atas nīharitvā vā deti ce bahi vaṭṭati
translated: if they give it after taking it out of the village;

analyzed: paccaye sati bhuñjāti deti ce kālikattayam
translated: if they give the three kinds of allowable food, saying, “Eat when there are conditions”;

original: Hatthato sāmaṇerīnaṃ, sikkhamānāya vā tathā;🔽Idaṃ eḷakalomena, samuṭṭhānaṃ samaṃ mataṃ.
analyzed: hatthataḥ sāmaṇerīnam sikkhamānāya vā tathā  idam eḷaka lomena samuṭṭhānam samam matam
translated: if it’s from the hand of a novice nun or a trainee nun;

original: Paṭhamapāṭidesanīyakathā.🔽Avutte “apasakkā”ti, ekenāpi ca bhikkhunā;🔽Sacejjhoharaṇatthāya, āmisaṃ paṭigaṇhati.
analyzed: paṭhama pāṭidesanīya kathā 🔽a vutte apasakkāti ekena api ca bhikkhunā 🔽āmisam paṭigaṇhati
translated: The origin of the offense is the same as that for the offense entailing confession that is committed with wool.

analyzed: gahaṇe dukkaṭam bhoge pāṭidesaniyam siyā
translated: In taking, there’s an offense of wrong conduct; in the enjoyment, it may be a confession offense.

analyzed: ekatas upasampannam na vārentassa dukkaṭam
translated: If one who is not fully ordained is not prevented, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: tathā iva anupasampanna ayupasampanna saññinaḥ
translated: So too if one who is not fully ordained is not fully ordained, but one perceives them as such;

analyzed: tattha vematikassa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: and if one is unsure of it, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Anāpattittano bhattaṃ, padāpeti na deti ce;
analyzed: anāpattittano bhattam padāpeti na deti ce
translated: There’s no offense if one asks for one’s own food and doesn’t get it for another;

original: Tathā aññassa bhattaṃ vā, na dāpeti padeti ce.
analyzed: tathā aññassa bhattam vā na dāpeti padeti ce
translated: so too if one asks for another’s food and gets it for another.

original: Yaṃ na dinnaṃ taṃ dāpeti, na dinnaṃ yattha vāpi ca;
analyzed: yam na dinnam tam dāpa iti na dinnam vā api ca
translated: If one asks for what hasn’t been given, or for what has been given anywhere,

original: Tattha tampi ca sabbesaṃ, samaṃ dāpeti bhikkhunī.
analyzed: tattha tam pi ca sabbesam samam dāpeti bhikkhunī
translated: then that nun is equal in offense with all of them.

analyzed: vosāsantī ṭhitā sikkhamānā vā sāmaṇerikā
translated: If one asks while standing, or if the other is a trainee nun or a novice nun,

original: Bhojanāni ca pañceva, vinā, ummattakādino.🔽Kathinena samuṭṭhānaṃ, samānanti pakāsitaṃ;
analyzed: bhojanāni ca pañca iva vinā ummattaka ādinaḥ  kathinena samuṭṭhānam pakāsitam
translated: and if it’s one of the five kinds of food, except if one is insane or the first of the rules.🔽The origin story of the robe-making season is announced as the same.

analyzed: kriyākriyam idam vuttam ti cittam ca ti vedanam
translated: This is said to be the action and the non-action, the three kinds of awareness, and the three kinds of feelings.

analyzed: dutiya pāṭidesanīya kathā
translated: The second rule entailing acknowledgment is finished.

analyzed: sekkhanti sammate bhikkhu laddha sammutike kule
translated: “A trainee nun” means a nun who has been approved. In a family that has invited the Sangha,

analyzed: ghara upacāra ukkamanā pubbā iva a nimantito
translated: in a house, going beyond the invitation,

analyzed: a gilānaḥ gahetvā ce paribhuñjeyya āmisam
translated: if one who is not sick receives fresh or cooked food,

analyzed: gahaṇe dukkaṭam bhoge pāṭidesaniyam siyā
translated: In the case of the taking, there is an offense of wrong conduct; In the case of the enjoyment, there may be an offense entailing acknowledgment.

analyzed: yāma kālika sattāha kālike yāvajīvike
translated: In the case of what is for one day only, what is for seven days, what is for life,

original: Gahaṇe paribhoge ca, hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ.🔽Asekkhasammate sekkha-sammatanti ca saññino;
analyzed: gahaṇe paribhoge ca hoti āpatti dukkaṭam  asekkha sammate ca saññinaḥ
translated: In the case of the taking and the enjoyment, there is an offense of wrong conduct.🔽In the case of what is regarded as “in training” and what is regarded as “not in training,”

analyzed: tattha vematikassa api tathā iva paridīpitam
translated: And in the case of what is regarded as “in training” and what is regarded as “not in training,”

original: Anāpatti gilānassa, gilānassāvasesake;🔽Nimantitassa vā bhikkhā, aññesaṃ tattha dīyati.🔽Gharato nīharitvā vā, denti ce yattha katthaci;
analyzed: anāpatti gilānassa gilānassa avasesake  nimantitassa vā bhikkhā aññesam tattha dīyati  gharataḥ nīharitvā vā denti ce yattha katthaci
translated: There is no offense if he is sick; if he is helping one who is sick;🔽If he is invited; if he is given almsfood after taking it from his house;🔽If they take it out from the house and give it anywhere;

original: Niccabhattādike vāpi, tathā ummattakādino.🔽Anāgate hi bhikkhumhi, gharato paṭhamaṃ pana;
analyzed: niccabhatta ādike vā api tathā ummattaka ādino  anāgate hi bhikkhumhi gharataḥ paṭhamam pana
translated: Or if they give it to one who is a regular recipient of alms or to one who is insane.🔽If, before the monk arrives,

original: Nīharitvā sace dvāre, sampatte denti vaṭṭati.
analyzed: nīharitvā sace dvāre sampatte denti vaṭṭati
translated: They take it out from the house and give it at the door when he arrives, it is allowable.

original: Bhikkhuṃ pana ca disvāva, nīharitvāna gehato;
analyzed: bhikkhum pana ca disvāva nīharitvāna gehataḥ
translated: But if they see the monk and then take it out from the house

analyzed: na vaṭṭati sace denti samuṭṭhāna iḷakū pamam
translated: and give it, it is not allowable, like the story of the well.

analyzed: tatiya pāṭidesanīya kathā  gahaṭṭhena a gahaṭṭhena itthiyā purisena vā
translated: The third offense entailing acknowledgment is finished.🔽If a householder or a non-householder,🔽A woman or a man,

original: Ārāmaṃ upacāraṃ vā, pavisitvā sace pana.
analyzed: ārāmam upacāram vā sace pana
translated: Enters a monastery or its vicinity,

analyzed: itthannāmassa te bhattam yāgu vā āharīyati
translated: “They’re bringing rice or rice porridge for so-and-so,”

analyzed: evam ārocitam vuttam paṭisaṃviditam ti hi
translated: And it’s said that this is called “announced and consented to”.

analyzed: āharīyatu tam pacchā yathā rocitam eva vā
translated: “Let them bring it later,” or “as announced,”

original: Tassa vā parivārampi, aññaṃ katvā bahuṃ pana.
analyzed: tassa vā parivāram pi aññam katvā bahum pana
translated: Or they make a lot of other things for him,🔽And if they bring cakes, rice, and so on,

original: Yāguyā viditaṃ katvā, pūvaṃ bhattaṃ haranti ce;
analyzed: yāguyā viditam katvā pūvam bhattam haranti ce
translated: After announcing the rice porridge,

analyzed: idam api viditam vuttam vaṭṭati iti kurundiyam
translated: This is also said to be announced, and it’s allowable, according to Kurundi.🔽But if other families

analyzed: kulāni pana aññāni deyya dhammam pana attano
translated: and he himself give requisites,

original: Haranti tena saddhiṃ ce, sabbaṃ vaṭṭati tampi ca.
analyzed: haranti tena saddhim ce sabbam vaṭṭati tam pi ca
translated: And if they bring them together with him, all that is allowable too.🔽But if it’s not announced,

analyzed: an ārocitam evam yaṃ yaṃ ārāmam an ābhatam
translated: and it’s not brought to the monastery,

analyzed: tam asaṃviditam nāma sahadhammika ñāpitam
translated: That’s called “unannounced and consented to”,🔽and it’s allowable if it’s announced together with the other.

original: Yaṃ asaṃviditaṃ katvā, ābhataṃ pana taṃ bahi;
analyzed: yam a saṃviditam katvā ābhatam pana tam bahis
translated: But if it’s brought outside after being unannounced,

analyzed: ārāmam pana pesetvā kārāpetvā tam āhare
translated: he should have it brought to the monastery after having it prepared by sending someone there.

original: Gantvā vā antarāmagge, gahetabbaṃ tu bhikkhunā;
analyzed: gantvā vā antarāmagge gahetabbam tu bhikkhunā
translated: Or the monk should have it brought to the monastery after going to get it on the way.🔽But if he doesn’t do this,

analyzed: sace evam a katvā tam ārāme upacārataḥ
translated: and he brings it to the monastery,

analyzed: gahetvā ajjhoharantassa gahaṇe dukkaṭam siyā
translated: then there’s an offense of wrong conduct for the taking,🔽if he then stores it and eats it.

analyzed: ajjhohāra payogesu pāṭidesaniyam matam
translated: In the case of the offenses entailing acknowledgment, it is considered to be the acknowledgment.

analyzed: paṭisaṃviditā iya iva a saṃvidita saññinaḥ
translated: When it is clear, but one perceives it as unclear,

analyzed: tattha vematikassa api hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: then even if one is unsure, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: paṭisaṃvidite tassa gilānassa avasesake
translated: When it is clear, but one is unsure about the remainder of the sick person,

analyzed: baha ārāme gahetvā vā antoyevassa bhuñjato
translated: or if one takes it outside the monastery zone, or if one eats it inside,

analyzed: tattha jāta phala ādīni anāpattā iva khādataḥ
translated: then there is no offense in eating fruits that grow there.

original: Samuṭṭhānādayo sabbe, kathinena samā matā.🔽Catutthapāṭidesanīyakathā.🔽Iti vinayavinicchaye pāṭidesanīyakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: samuṭṭhāna ādayo sabbe kathinena samā matā  catuttha pāṭidesanīya kathā  iti vinaya vinicchaye pāṭidesanīya kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The origins, etc., are all the same as in the case of the robe-making ceremony.🔽The explanation of the fourth class of offenses entailing acknowledgment is finished.

analyzed: sekhiya kathā
translated: The explanation of the offenses entailing acknowledgment in the Khandhaka of the Vinaya is finished.🔽The training rules for the female lay followers

analyzed: yaḥ an ādariyena iva puratas pacchatas pi vā
translated: If one wears the sarong hanging down in front or behind

original: Olambetvā nivāseyya, tassa cāpatti dukkaṭaṃ.🔽Hatthisoṇḍāditulyaṃ tu, nivāsentassa dukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: olambetvā nivāseyya tassa ca āpatti dukkaṭaṃ  hatthi soṇḍa ādi tulyam tu nivāsentassa dukkaṭam
translated: out of disrespect, then there is an offense of wrong conduct.🔽But if one wears it like the trunk of an elephant, there is an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: āpatti bhīrunā niccam vatthabbam parimaṇḍalam
translated: One who is fearful of offenses should always wear it in the proper way.

analyzed: jāṇu maṇḍalataḥ heṭṭhā aṭṭha aṅgula ppamāṇakam
translated: Below the ankle bones, eight fingerbreadths in size,

original: Otāretvā nivatthabbaṃ, tato ūnaṃ na vaṭṭati.
analyzed: otāretvā nivatthabbam tatas ūnam na vaṭṭati
translated: one should wear it covering that. It is not allowable to wear it shorter.

analyzed: a sañcicca asatissa api a jānantassa kevalam
translated: If one does not do it on purpose, if one does not know,

analyzed: anāpatti gilānassa āpadā summattaka ādinaḥ
translated: There’s no offense if she’s sick, if she’s insane, if she’s the first offender.

analyzed: parimaṇḍala kathā
translated: The training rule on the circular shape

original: Ubho koṇe samaṃ katvā, sādaraṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ;
analyzed: ubho koṇe samam katvā sādaram parimaṇḍalam
translated: Having made the two corners even, one should respectfully put on the sarong evenly all around;

analyzed: katvā a karontassa dukkaṭam
translated: If one does not do it this way, one commits an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: avisesena vuttam tu idam sikkhāpada dvayam
translated: But these two training rules were given without distinction;

original: Tasmā ghare vihāre vā, kattabbaṃ parimaṇḍalaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai ghare vihāre vā kattabbam parimaṇḍalam
translated: Therefore, whether in a house or in a dwelling, one should put on the sarong in a circular way.

analyzed: dutiyam
translated: The second.

original: Gaṇṭhikaṃ paṭimuñcitvā, katvā koṇe ubho samaṃ;
analyzed: gaṇṭhikam paṭimuñcitvā katvā koṇe ubho samam
translated: Having fastened the belt, having made the two corners even,

analyzed: chādetvā maṇibandham ca gantabbam gīvam eva ca
translated: one should cover the wrists and the neck.

original: Tathā akatvā bhikkhussa, jattūnipi urampi ca;
analyzed: tathā a katvā bhikkhussa jattūni urampi ca
translated: If a monk does otherwise, if he exposes his chest and his shoulders,

analyzed: vivaritvā yathākāmam gacchataḥ hoti dukkaṭam
translated: and if he walks as he likes, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: tatiyam
translated: The third.

analyzed: galavāṭakataḥ sīsam ca maṇibandhataḥ
translated: Above the collar bone and below the wrists,

original: Hatthe piṇḍikamaṃsamhā, heṭṭhā pāde ubhopi ca.
analyzed: hatthe heṭṭhā pāde ubho pi ca
translated: and below the knee and above the ankle bones,

analyzed: chādetvā nisīdati
translated: if he exposes the rest and covers the rest, and then sits down,

original: Hoti so suppaṭicchanno, doso vāsūpagassa na.
analyzed: hoti saḥ su paṭicchannaḥ dosaḥ vāsūpagassa na
translated: he is properly covered, and there is no offense for him in receiving alms.

analyzed: catuttham
translated: The fourth.

original: Hatthaṃ vā pana pādaṃ vā, acālentena bhikkhunā;
analyzed: hattham vā pana pādam vā a cālentena bhikkhunā
translated: A monk should not move his hands or feet,

analyzed: su vinītena gantabbam chaṭṭhe natthi visesa tā
translated: One should go with self-control; there’s no difference in the sixth.

analyzed: pañcama chaṭṭhāni
translated: The fifth and sixth.

analyzed: satī matā vikārena pekkhinā
translated: Mindful, with a composed manner, looking ahead a yoke’s length,

analyzed: su saṃvutena gantabbam bhikkhunā ukkhitta cakkhunā
translated: well-restrained, one should go, with eyes cast down,

original: Yattha katthaci hi ṭṭhāne, ekasmiṃ antare ghare;
analyzed: yattha katthaci hi ṭṭhāne ekasmin antare ghare
translated: In whatever place, in one house in between,

analyzed: ṭhatvā parissaya abhāvam oloketum pi vaṭṭati
translated: it’s allowable to look for the absence of danger.

original: Yo anādariyaṃ katvā, olokento tahiṃ tahiṃ;
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam katvā olokentaḥ tahim tahim
translated: Whoever, out of disrespect, looks here and there,

analyzed: saced intara ghare yāti dukkaṭam aṭṭhamam tathā
translated: and goes into a house where people are copulating, it’s the eighth offense of wrong conduct, likewise.

analyzed: sattama aṭṭhamāni
translated: The seventh and eighth.

analyzed: ekatas ubhatas vā api hutvā ukkhitta cīvaraḥ
translated: Whether alone or with a companion, having lifted up one’s robe,

analyzed: indakhīlakataḥ antaḥ gacchataḥ hoti dukkaṭam
translated: one should go inside the distance of a stretched-out arm; it’s wrong conduct otherwise.

analyzed: navamam
translated: The ninth.

analyzed: tathā nisinna kāle api nīharantena kuṇḍikam
translated: And also when sitting, if one removes a bag,

analyzed: an ukkhipitvā dātabbā dosaḥ vāsūpagassa na
translated: one should give it after lifting it up; there’s no offense for one who’s staying there.

analyzed: dasamam
translated: The tenth.

original: Paṭhamo vaggo.🔽Na vaṭṭati hasantena, gantuñceva nisīdituṃ;
analyzed: paṭhamaḥ vaggo  na vaṭṭati hasantena gantum ca iva nisīditum
translated: The first sub-chapter on “going” is finished.🔽It’s not allowable to go or sit down laughing;

analyzed: vatthusmim hasanīyasmim sita mattam tu vaṭṭati
translated: but when there’s something to laugh at, it’s allowable to just smile.

analyzed: paṭhama dutiyāni
translated: The first and second.

analyzed: appa saddena gantabbam catutthe pi ayam nayo
translated: One should go there quietly; The same method applies to the fourth.

analyzed: mahā saddam karontassa ubhayattha api dukkaṭam
translated: If one makes a loud noise, There’s an offense for both.

analyzed: tatiya catutthāni  kāya ppacālakam katvā bāhu sīsa ppacālakam
translated: The third and the fourth.

original: Gacchato dukkaṭaṃ hoti, tatheva ca nisīdato.🔽Kāyaṃ bāhuñca sīsañca, paggahetvā ujuṃ pana;
analyzed: gacchataḥ dukkaṭam hoti tathā iva ca nisīdataḥ  kāyam bāhuñca sīsañca paggahetvā ujum pana
translated: If one goes, swaying one’s body, Or swaying one’s arms and head, There’s an offense of wrong conduct. The same applies to sitting.🔽But one should go and sit straight, Holding one’s body straight, one’s arms, and one’s head.

original: Gantabbamāsitabbañca, sameniriyāpathena tu.🔽Nisīdanena yuttesu, tīsu vāsūpagassa hi;
analyzed: gantabbam āsitabbam ca same niriyāpathena tu  nisīdanena yuttesu tīsu vāsūpagassa hi
translated: One should go and sit in a proper way.

analyzed: anāpatti iti ñātabbam viññunā vinayaññunā
translated: One who is sensible and knows the Monastic Law should know that there’s no offense for one of the three who is staying for the night

analyzed: dutiyaḥ vaggo
translated: The second sub-chapter is finished.

original: Khambhaṃ katvā sasīsaṃ vā, pārupitvāna gacchato;
analyzed: khambham katvā sa sīsam vā gacchataḥ
translated: If one goes, making a pillar, Or covering one’s head,

original: Dukkaṭaṃ muninā vuttaṃ, tathā ukkuṭikāya vā.
analyzed: dukkaṭam muninā vuttam tathā ukkuṭikāya vā
translated: The Awakened One said there’s an offense, As well as if one goes squatting.

analyzed: hattha pallatthikāya api dussa pallatthikāya vā
translated: If one sits in a house, with one’s hands on one’s knees, Or with one’s robe on one’s knees,

analyzed: tassa antara ghare hoti nisīdantassa dukkaṭam
translated: There’s an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Dutiye ca catutthe ca, chaṭṭhe vāsūpagassa tu;
analyzed: dutiye ca catutthe ca chaṭṭhe vāsūpagassa tu
translated: In the second, the fourth, and the sixth, For one who is staying for the night,

analyzed: anāpatti iti sāruppā chabbīsati pakāsitā
translated: There’s no offense, it’s proper. The twenty-six have been explained.

analyzed: chaṭṭham
translated: The sixth.

analyzed: sakkaccam sati yuttena bhikkhunā patta saññinā
translated: A monk who is mindful, who is heedful, who is aware of his almsbowl,

original: Piṇḍapāto gahetabbo, samasūpova viññunā.🔽Sūpo bhattacatubbhāgo, “samasūpo”ti vuccati;
analyzed: piṇḍapātaḥ gahetabbo viññunā  sūpaḥ bhatta catubbhāgo sama sūpaḥ ti vuccati
translated: Should receive almsfood, like a wise man who is level-headed.🔽A measure of rice is a quarter of a measure of soup; this is called “level-headed”.

analyzed: mugga māsa kulatthānam sūpaḥ sūpaḥ ti vuccati
translated: Soup of mung beans, kidney beans, or chickpeas is called “soup”.

analyzed: anāpatti asañcit ca gilānassa raserase
translated: There’s no offense if it’s unintentional, if he’s sick, if it’s a relish,

analyzed: tathā iva ñātaka ādīnam aññatthāya dhanena vā
translated: Or if it’s for a relative, etc., or if it’s for the benefit of someone else or with one’s own money.

analyzed: sattama aṭṭhama navamāni
translated: The seventh, eighth, and ninth.

original: Antolekhāpamāṇena, pattassa mukhavaṭṭiyā;🔽Pūritova gahetabbo, adhiṭṭhānūpagassa tu.
analyzed: antar lekhā pamāṇena pattassa mukha vaṭṭiyā  pūritaḥ iva gahetabbaḥ adhiṭṭhāna upagassa tu
translated: The bowl should be filled up to the line for the upper end of the bowl,🔽But only if it’s for the purpose of keeping it.🔽If he fills it up to the rim, it’s for the purpose of making an offering.

analyzed: tattha thūpīkatam katvā gaṇhataḥ yāvakālikam
translated: Whatever is received is for a specific purpose.

original: Yaṃ kiñci pana bhikkhussa, hoti āpatti dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: yam kiñci pana bhikkhussa hoti āpatti dukkaṭam
translated: Any offense for a monk is a serious offense.

analyzed: adhiṭṭhāna upage patte ca
translated: In a bowl that’s for the purpose of keeping, and in the three that are for a specific purpose,

original: Sese thūpīkataṃ sabbaṃ, vaṭṭateva na saṃsayo.
analyzed: sese thūpīkatam sabbam vaṭṭatā iva na saṃsayaḥ
translated: In the rest, all that’s received is for the purpose of making an offering. There’s no doubt about this.

original: Dvīsu pattesu bhattaṃ tu, gahetvā pattamekakaṃ;
analyzed: dvīsu pattesu bhattam tu gahetvā pattam ekakam
translated: If he receives food in two bowls and then fills one bowl

original: Pūretvā yadi peseti, bhikkhūnaṃ pana vaṭṭati.
analyzed: pūretvā yadi peseti bhikkhūnam pana vaṭṭati
translated: And gives it to the monks, this is allowable.

analyzed: patte pakkhippamānam yam ucchu khaṇḍa phala ādikam
translated: If he drops into the bowl a piece of curd, a fruit, etc.,

original: Orohati sace heṭṭhā, na taṃ thūpīkataṃ siyā.
analyzed: orohati sace heṭṭhā na tam thūpīkatam siyā
translated: If he climbs down, it’s not to be regarded as a shrine.

analyzed: puppha takkolaka ādīnam ṭhapetvā ce vaṭaṃsakam
translated: Except for flowers, betel, and so on, and a fan,

original: Dinnaṃ ayāvakālittā, na taṃ thūpīkataṃ siyā.🔽Vaṭaṃsakaṃ tu pūvassa, ṭhapetvā odanopari;
analyzed: na tam thūpīkatam siyā  vaṭaṃsakam tu pūvassa ṭhapetvā odana upari
translated: If he gives, it’s not to be regarded as a shrine.🔽But if he gives a fan together with a cake,

original: Piṇḍapātaṃ sace denti, idaṃ thūpīkataṃ siyā.
analyzed: piṇḍapātam sace denti idam thūpīkatam siyā
translated: placing it on top of the rice, it’s to be regarded as a shrine.

original: Bhattassūpari paṇṇaṃ vā, thālakaṃ vāpi kiñcipi;
analyzed: bhattassa upari paṇṇam vā thālakam vā api kiñcipi
translated: If he places a leaf or a plate on top of the food,

analyzed: ṭhapetvā paripūretvā sace gaṇhāti vaṭṭati
translated: and fills it up, it’s allowable to take it.

original: Paṭiggahetumevassa, taṃ tu sabbaṃ na vaṭṭati;
analyzed: paṭiggahetum eva assa tat tu sabbam na vaṭṭati
translated: But if he takes it all, it’s not allowable.

analyzed: gahitam su gahitam pacchā bhuñjitabbam yathāsukham
translated: What’s been taken is well taken. Later, he may eat it as he likes.

analyzed: tatiyaḥ vaggo
translated: The third sub-chapter on almsfood is finished.

original: Paṭhamaṃ dutiyaṃ vutta-nayaṃ tu tatiye pana;🔽Uparodhimadassetvā, bhottabbaṃ paṭipāṭiyā.
analyzed: paṭhamam dutiyam vutta nayam tu tatiye pana  uparodhim adassetvā bhottabbam paṭipāṭiyā
translated: The first and second are to be recited in the same way. But in the third,🔽after showing the bowl to the one who gives the food, he should eat in order.

original: Aññesaṃ attano bhattaṃ, ākiraṃ pana bhājane;
analyzed: aññesam attanaḥ bhattam ākiram pana bhājane
translated: If he mixes the food of others with his own in a bowl,

analyzed: ce doso tathā uttari bhaṅgakam
translated: if he’s forgetful, there’s no offense. So too, if he eats the leftovers.

analyzed: tatiyam
translated: The third rule.

original: Catutthe yaṃ tu vattabbaṃ, vuttaṃ pubbe asesato;
analyzed: catutthe yam tu vattabbam vuttam pubbe asesato
translated: What should be said about the fourth has all been said before.

analyzed: pañcame matthakam dosaḥ madditvā paribhuñjataḥ
translated: The fifth is when, after mashing, he eats the head of a grain.🔽There’s no offense if he’s sick,

analyzed: anāpatti gilānassa paritte pi ca sesake
translated: Or if there’s only a little left,

analyzed: ekatas pana madditvā saṃkaḍḍhitvāna bhuñjataḥ
translated: Or if he mashes it all together and then eats it.

analyzed: catuttha pañcamāni
translated: The fourth and the fifth.

original: Yo bhiyyokamyatāhetu, sūpaṃ vā byañjanampi vā;
analyzed: yaḥ bhiyyokamyatā hetu sūpam vā vā
translated: If, for the sake of getting more, he hides curry or rice,

analyzed: paṭicchādeyya bhattena tassa ca āpatti dukkaṭaṃ
translated: He commits an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: chaṭṭham
translated: The sixth.

original: Viññattiyaṃ tu vattabbaṃ, apubbaṃ natthi kiñcipi;
analyzed: viññattiyam tu vattabbam apubbam natthi kiñci pi
translated: But in the case of asking, there’s nothing new to be said;

original: Aṭṭhame pana ujjhāne, gilānopi na muccati.
analyzed: aṭṭhame pana ujjhāne gilānaḥ api na muccati
translated: But in the eighth, even if he’s sick, he’s not released from the offense.

analyzed: dassāmi dāpessāmi iti olokentassa bhikkhuno
translated: If he says, “I’ll give,” or “I’ll have it given,”🔽And he looks on while a monk receives it,🔽He should be understood to be without offense,

analyzed: anāpatti iti ñātabbam na ca ujjhāna saññino
translated: But only if he has no intention to steal.

analyzed: aṭṭhamam
translated: The eighth.🔽But a large peahen’s egg

analyzed: mahantam pana moraṇḍam kukkuṭaṇḍam ca khuddakam
translated: And a small chicken’s egg,🔽The size of the middle of those two

analyzed: tesam majjha ppamāṇena kattabbaḥ kabaḷaḥ pana
translated: Is the right size for a mouthful.

analyzed: khajjake pana sabbattha mūla khādaniya ādike
translated: But in the case of fresh food, such as roots,

analyzed: phala aphale anāpatti gilāna ummattaka ādinaḥ
translated: There’s no offense in the case of fruits and fruit-like things,🔽Or if he’s sick, or if he’s insane, and so on.

analyzed: navamam
translated: The ninth.🔽But it should be eaten in small pieces,

analyzed: adīghaḥ pana kātabbaḥ ālopaḥ parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: Not large, not round.

analyzed: khajja tuttari bhaṅgasmin anāpatti phala aphale
translated: When eating what’s been chewed and swallowed, There’s no offense with fruits and vegetables.

analyzed: dasamam
translated: The tenth.

analyzed: catutthaḥ vaggo
translated: The fourth sub-chapter is finished.

analyzed: anāhaṭe mukha dvāram appatte kabaḷe pana
translated: When it hasn’t been brought to the mouth, And when the mouthful hasn’t been swallowed,

analyzed: attano ca mukha dvāram vivarantassa dukkaṭaṃ
translated: And when he opens his own mouth: It’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: paṭhamam
translated: The first.

original: Mukhe ca sakalaṃ hatthaṃ, pakkhipantassa dukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: mukhe ca sakalam hattham pakkhipantassa dukkaṭam
translated: When he puts his whole hand in his mouth: It’s an offense of wrong conduct.

original: Mukhe ca kabaḷaṃ katvā, kathetuṃ na ca vaṭṭati.
analyzed: mukhe ca kabaḷam katvā kathetum na ca vaṭṭati
translated: And when he talks with food in his mouth, That’s not allowable.

original: Vacanaṃ yattakenassa, paripuṇṇaṃ na hoti hi;
analyzed: vacanam yattakena assa paripuṇṇam na hoti hi
translated: When his words are not complete,

analyzed: mukhasmiṃtattake sante byāharantassa dukkaṭam
translated: And when he talks with food in his mouth: It’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: mukhe harītaka ādīni pakkhipitvā kathā iti yaḥ
translated: When he talks with harītaki fruits, etc., in his mouth,

original: Vacanaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ ce, kathetuṃ pana vaṭṭati.
analyzed: vacanam paripuṇṇam ce kathetum pana vaṭṭati
translated: And his words are complete, Then it’s allowable to talk.

analyzed: dutiya tatiyāni
translated: The second and third.

analyzed: yaḥ piṇḍukkhepakam bhikkhu kabaḷa chedakam pi vā
translated: When a monk eats by throwing mouthfuls into his mouth,

original: Makkaṭo viya gaṇḍe vā, katvā bhuñjeyya dukkaṭaṃ.
analyzed: makkaṭaḥ gaṇḍe vā katvā bhuñjeyya dukkaṭam
translated: Or by picking at it like a monkey, Or by picking at it like a monkey in a cage: It’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: catuttha pañcama chaṭṭhāni  niddhunitvāna hattham vā bhattam
translated: The fourth, fifth, and sixth.🔽When he wipes his hands on his bowl, Or on the bowl of another, Or on the floor, or on the ground, Or on the leaves of a palm tree,

analyzed: vā api tathā capu vā
translated: Or when he wipes his hands on grass, Or on a piece of wood, or on a piece of pottery, Or when he wipes his hands on his robe, Or on his bowl, or on his sitting mat,🔽Or when he wipes his hands on his water strainer, Or on his water-strainer bag, Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel, Or on his water-sipping vessel bag,🔽Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel stand, Or on his water-sipping vessel stand bag, Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel stand mat, Or on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat,🔽Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat, Or on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat bag, Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat bag mat, Or on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat bag mat bag,🔽Or when he wipes his hands on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat bag mat bag mat bag, Or on his water-sipping vessel stand bag mat

analyzed: anādara vasena iva bhuñjataḥ hoti dukkaṭam
translated: If he eats with disrespect, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.🔽There’s no offense for the seventh or eighth,

analyzed: sattame aṭṭhame natthi doso
translated: Or for eating scraps.

analyzed: sattama dasamāni
translated: Seven kinds of intoxication.

analyzed: pañcamaḥ vaggo
translated: The fifth sub-chapter is finished.

original: Katvā evaṃ na bhottabbaṃ, saddaṃ “suru surū”ti ca;
analyzed: katvā evam na bhottabbam saddam suru suru iti ca
translated: Having done, one should not eat; The sounds “suru suru” and “suru suru”;

original: Hatthanillehakaṃ vāpi, na ca vaṭṭati bhuñjituṃ.
analyzed: hattha nillehakam vā api na ca vaṭṭati bhuñjitum
translated: Or licking the hands: it’s not allowable to eat.

original: Phāṇitaṃ ghanayāguṃ vā, gahetvā aṅgulīhi taṃ;
analyzed: phāṇitam ghana yāgum vā gahetvā aṅgulīhi tam
translated: Having taken molasses or thick rice porridge with the fingers,

analyzed: mukhe aṅguliyaḥ bhottum pavesetvā api vaṭṭati
translated: It’s allowable to put the fingers in the mouth and eat.

analyzed: na pattaḥ lehitabbaḥ u vā
translated: One should not lick the bowl or one’s fingers;

analyzed: jivhāya na ca nillehitabbakaḥ
translated: Or one’s lips with the tongue.

analyzed: catuttham
translated: The fourth.

original: Sāmisena tu hatthena, na ca pānīyathālakaṃ;
analyzed: sa āmisena tu hatthena na ca
translated: One should not hold the drinking water vessel with a hand that’s soiled;

original: Gahetabbaṃ, paṭikkhittaṃ, paṭikkūlavasena hi.🔽Puggalassa ca saṅghassa, gahaṭṭhassattanopi ca;
analyzed: gahetabbam paṭikkhittam paṭikkūla vasena hi  puggalassa ca saṅghassa ca
translated: It’s prohibited, because it’s repulsive.🔽For an individual, for the Sangha, for a householder, for seven people,

original: Santako pana saṅkho vā, sarāvaṃ vāpi thālakaṃ.
analyzed: santakaḥ pana saṅkhaḥ vā sarāvam vā api thālakam
translated: Or for a single person: a bowl, a cup, a saucer, or a vessel.

original: Tasmā na ca gahetabbaṃ, gaṇhato hoti dukkaṭaṃ;
analyzed: tasmā na ca gahetabbam gaṇhataḥ hoti dukkaṭam
translated: Therefore it should not be held; if one holds it, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: anāmisena hatthena gahaṇam pana vaṭṭati
translated: But it’s allowable to hold it with a hand that’s not soiled.

analyzed: pañcamam
translated: The fifth.

analyzed: uddharitvā api bhinditvā gahetvā vā paṭiggahe
translated: If he takes it out, breaks it, Takes it, or receives it,

analyzed: nīharitvā anāpatti chaḍḍentassa gharā bahi
translated: Or if he takes it out and there’s no offense in discarding it outside the house.

analyzed: chaṭṭham
translated: The sixth.

original: Chattaṃ yaṃ kiñci hatthena, sarīrāvayavena vā;
analyzed: chattam yam kiñci hatthena sarīra avayavena vā
translated: If he holds up an umbrella with his hand or with a part of his body,

analyzed: sace dhārayamānassa dhammaṃ deseti dukkaṭam
translated: And then teaches the Teaching, there’s an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: sattamam
translated: The seventh.

analyzed: ayam eva nayaḥ vuttaḥ daṇḍa pāṇimhi puggale
translated: The same rule applies to a person holding a staff:

analyzed: catu hattha ppamāṇaḥ iva daṇḍaḥ majjhima hatthato
translated: The staff should be a cubit long, measured from the middle of the forearm.

analyzed: aṭṭhamam  tathā iva sattha pāṇissa dhammaṃ deseti dukkaṭam
translated: The eighth.🔽If he teaches the Teaching to one holding a knife,

original: Satthapāṇī na hotāsiṃ, sannayhitvā ṭhito pana.
analyzed: sattha pāṇī na hotā asim sannayhitvā ṭhitaḥ pana
translated: There’s an offense of wrong conduct. But there’s no offense if he doesn’t hold a knife, but is holding something else.
